content:
Slide Deck Overviews
 https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ZpLT1WKStiVNM7ZWPGagejVHGvYTu9N9Zxn2T9jzrQw/edit#slide=id.p (added 9/20/23)

 OC Links: https://app.wizer-training.com/learning/365c18b2e8d34f9db0e12ee56c846761 

 OC Entities
 OCHCA: OC Health Care Agency, a division within the County of Orange

 MHRS: Mental Health & Recovery Services, a division within OCHCA

 O&E: Outreach & Engagement Team

 AMHS CSU: Crisis Stabilization Unit - 3 teams, 2 of which are county-contracted (non-County users)

 CYS CSU: Crisis Stabilization Unit - 1 team, which is county-contracted (non-County users)

 Office of Suicide Prevention, a department under MHRS

 OC IT: The government of Orange County is a large governing body under which there are divisions, HCA being one of them. Each division has its own IT department. And OC IT is the governing body's IT.
 OC HCA IT: Health Care Agency Information Technology

 TAR Unit: Treatment Authorization Request

 Residential Treatment

 ART: Assessment Response Team for Substance Use Programs

 Programs
 AIHCS
 Adult In Home Crisis Services

 Part of OC Links app

 CAT Mobile (Crisis Assessment Team)
 Part of OC Links app

 Crisis Residential Program (CRP) Bed Board (aka Crisis Residential Unit)
 System for CRP staff to intake clients and track availability

 CSU Bed Board
 Crisis Stabilization Unit

 System for CSU staff to intake clients and track bed availability

 Client management system for CSU Bed Board to maintain a single client record

 Part of OC Links app

 User list contains non-County users

 LE Bed Board
 Public-facing display of CSU bed availability for law enforcement

 Part of OC Links app

 IHCS
 Referral coordination system for IHCS teams (Integrated Home Care Services)

 Outreach & Engagement (O&E) Admin
 System for O&E supervisors to receive referrals from OC Links and assign to outreach workers

 Part of OC Links app

 Outreach & Engagement (O&E) Mobile
 Response and dispatch system for O&E team

 OC Links
 Response and dispatch system for OC Links Navigators and CAT clinicians

 Part of OC Links app

 OC Navigator
 Public-facing tool to help residents find and connect to resources

 OC Warmline (aka NAMI or National Alliance on Mental Illness)
 System for OC Warmline mentors to receive support requests and track warm hand-offs. This is a county-contracted organization.

 PEI (Prevention & Early Intervention)
 A funding source to provide preventative care for individuals with serious mental illness. Orange County Health Care Agency contracts with about 26 providers who are PEI-funded.

 SUD System
 Referral coordination system for SUD (substance use disorder) ART

 SUD Residential Bed Board
 System for SUD residential programs to track availability

 Treatment Authorization Request
 Portal to create and submit TAR forms among MHRS programs

 UAF Survey
 Survey for O&E outreach workers to record client count, demographics, and service provision per site

 Part of OC Links app

 Enterprise-Level Initiatives
 EHR Integration
 Automate feeding data from Chorus into an EHR (electronic health record system) to maintain a single client record

 Referrals & Linkages
 Establish closed loop referrals and confirmed linkages within MHRS programs

 Reporting

 Staff Scheduling
 Scheduling system for OC Links admin and OC Links Navigators

 Scheduling system for CAT admin and CAT staff. Displays real-time clinician availability.

 Ad Hoc Data Requests 
 The people in the table below have permission to request data exports on an ad hoc basis, if needed. only requests from the people listed below will be honored. Requests from anyone on the program side should be routed back to Sharon. 
 Requests must be submitted via the OCHCA Help Center Form 
 The requestor should choose the drop down for "data request" 
 They must also include the "secret code" No request is allowed to be processed without verifying this code. 
 As of 12/20/23 the code is espresso 
 The next time the code should be updated is March 31, 2024 
 IMPORTANT : Should you have any doubt that the person requesting the data is not who they say they are or the request seems different than a typical request, call the requestor at a known number to verify by voice. 
 Approved Requestors: 
 "Ishikawa, Sharon" < sishikawa@ochca.com >, 
 "Hsiung, Thomas" < THsiung@ochca.com >, 
 "Danioko, Sidy" < sdanioko@ochca.com >, 
 "Anderson, Kyle" < KAnderson@ochca.com >

title: OC Links Status Sync
content:
runs through OC Links to CAT flow 
 Questions for Chorus
 Can we link the dispatch form to an SMS to the clinician? Right now they're calling. 
 A: Yes. Easy to send an SMS to someone in Chorus. Can include a link

 Questions for Tim
 If not hospitalized and diverted to resources, what constitutes a 'clear' status?

 Sharath runs through wireframe 
 Wireframes: Desktop and mobile view for clinician dashboards
 TBD if creating a new message in the mobile view means creating message in case, or creating message to a person. 
 Does clinician only have access to messages connected to a case? Right now, staff messaging is in the next deliverable. 
 Message sections of dispatch, etc. 
 Could track edits for time. Need to be able to change it on desktop and mobile.
 Threads are complicated.
 Search messages are possible through Chorus.
 Top issues to think through 
 How to display case info

 toggling between case activity and details and status

 optimize mobile (dispatch) vs desktop (navigator)

 Next steps 
 Design work on mobile view

 Confirm that we're not working on global messaging, and just case by case

 Edit icon for Ribbon? 

 BoS meeting 3/15 @ 11am
 Brendan finished with Aunt Bertha research on Wednesday
 Kris has something to review on Wednesday about branding
 Waiting for website approval of copy 
 Sharath working on dispatch msgs for OC Links. Message boards. User flow. Full wireframe for Nav side and CAT side for messages.
 Brendan competitor research til Wed. Taking on platform work. 
 General timeline and milestones.
 Project website deadline

 CAT deployment

 Navigator end of March revision. 

 CAT sprint dependent on what Sharath gets. Then choose a direction and loop in Tim at the end of the week. 
 Need to clarify information architecture 

 Ben will take a look at information architecture 

 Courtney can review information architecture when she starts next Monday 

 Everything is in Figma rn. User flow will be developed there

 Wednesday - Brendan competitor research, Kris and Sharath wireframe. 
 CAT at the end of May. 
 Integration with possible other systems? Like Slack, Tableau

 OC Navigator end of March. 
 Three main activities
 Identify pilot side and work with them what that would look like 
 Brief meeting with Flor

 Finish SDOH assessment 
 Score it so results are relevant to answers

 Description of category pages for the top categories (Mienah) (Xuan) 
 Make it different from now pow and AB

 More compact display of the results 

 Searching and filtering for resources (keep it basic)
 Resources open now

 Subcategories 

 Filters for people who didn't take screener

 Brendan can do user interviews before launch, to help with troubleshooting.

 CAT Wireframes 
 Feedback
 Different homepage: need to design a dashboard that could also lists new cases so clinicians can access a new case without going through a SMS link

 If case is rejected, what happens? Screen to request more information, or explain why?

 Read Only and click to 'Edit' button for text fields. Make it clear which fields can be edited.

 Case status: consider including a status on mobile dashboard. Quick Action button that changes according to status (Arrived, Clear, etc.)

 Simplify view of case page. No need for 'Current Case'. 

 Make 'Messages' more prominent. What's the notification look? 

 Work on hierarchy of different sections.

 1 
 complete 
 Information architecture (names of tables and field names) Lead:

 Can we link the dispatch form to an SMS to the clinician? Right now they're calling.

 Sharath runs through wireframe 
 TBD if creating a new message in the mobile view means creating message in case, or creating message to a person. 
 Feedback
 Could track edits for time. Need to be able to change it on desktop and mobile.

 Search messages are possible through Chorus.

 optimize mobile (dispatch) vs desktop (navigator)

 Design work on mobile view

title: OC Links Navigator ‚Äì Master Project Document
content:
Unmet needs
 Persona 
 UX Outcome 
 Success Goals/Metrics 

 OC Links Navigator
 If we do a great job of providing warm-line dispatching services, navigators will expediently collect necessary data of calls and cases. 
 Reduce case call time.

 Improve data quality.

 If we do a great job on providing warm-line dispatching services, navigators will efficiently and accurately determine the client's eligibility for resources . 
 Warm transfers to suicide and language hotlines. 

 Reduce time checking if resource is available

 If we do a great job of providing warm-line dispatching services, navigators will quickly connect to an available and appropriate CAT clinician efficiently. 
 Share accurate and relevant client history with CAT clinician.

 If we do a great job on providing warm-line dispatching services, navigators will effectively track which cases are open and need a CAT clinician or resolution. 
 Help OCNs track and manage tasks.

 If we do a great job on providing warm-line dispatching services, navigators will easily and accurately record dispatch information such as date/time, staff member assigned, and the result of the dispatch. 
 More easily and efficiently collect accurate reporting data. 

 Ease of use improves volume and quality of data.

 note We should confirm with stakeholders and users how they would define the success criteria.

 We should confirm with stakeholders and users how they would define the success criteria.

 Objectives
 Create a platform for OC Links navigators to take calls, connect to resources, and invoke dispatch as necessary. This is to optimize their efficiency, and to integrate their system holistically.
 Create a platform for CAT technicians to receive dispatches and report/manage cases. This is to reduce manual paperwork, to more efficiently manage cases, and to more efficiently report their cases' status back to CAT admin.
 Create a platform for CAT Supervisor to collect data on case updates, and track time and amount of case spent per clinician for scheduling.
 User personas
 https://chorusapp.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/OC/pages/1195966503/Personas#Professional-Personas → Social worker 
 Archetypes → Frontline worker
 Proto-personas: https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lQWnBDw=/ → OC Links Navigators
 Additional UX Artifacts
 Sitemap: https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lQKmDQs=/ 
 Research - OC Links 
 Jobs we want to cover
 Some history
 Orange County Health Care Agency has contracted Chorus to build out a dashboard for their warm-line navigators to answer calls and chats from OC citizens and connect them to healthcare resources. OC Links has been around since October 2013.

OC Links was using iCarol up until Jan/Feb 2021. However, they used only about 10% of that platform's offerings, and therefore decided to go with something more bespoke in order to meet their needs.
 Constraints
 This product will be running on the Chorus platform. Responsive web. CAT clinicians will also be on this website, and will have the same user configurations.
 Explorations + Decisions
 Outline what kinds of approaches were considered, and the benefits and drawbacks of each. What decisions did we make, and why? 
 Releases
 Statuses: To do In progress Blue Blocked Red Waiting for feedback Yellow Done Green If this project has releases, outline them here. 
 Release Name 
 Value it adds 
 Scope 
 Status 
 Completed date 

 OC Links Phase II
 Provide OC Links Navigators ability to dispatch CAT
 MVP for dispatching (Location: CAT Tab) 
 Navigator should be able to view complete list of clinicians in the drop down

 Navigator triggers the case text alert by selecting a clinician from the drop down.

 Navigator should be able to see which clinicians are assigned to a case so they don't select them.

 CAT Case Chat 
 Assigned navigators get notified of new messages in staff chat in their cases

 Navigator can enter chat via dashboard and get notifications from: 
 OC Links case details page

 Profile 

 Mapping 
 Navigator can see the case location on a map

 Unknown feasibility: Navigator can verify the case location on a map 

 People Roster 
 Look up who works at OC Links and CAT, see their job role and what languages they speak.
 What their schedules are 

 In progress Blue 

 NAMI warm-line pilot
 Pilot the warm-line to get feedback on resources.
 https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lCQmd9A=/ 
 Reference this doc ( working document ): NAMI Pilot Product Requirements Doc 
 to do 

 OC Links Future Phase
 Intranet Chat
 Private messaging.

 Navigator should be able to add others to a given chat.

 Admins add schedule shifts for their staff

 Assigning clinicians + dispatch based on schedules in system

 Next steps

title: 10/22/2020 - Chorus/OC/NAMI Meeting
content:
Zoom meeting 1:30-2:30pm
 Attendees
 NAMI Staff
 Mariam Harris, Warmline Director

 Evan Cagle, IT, 

 Stephanie Alvarez, Operations manager

 Lisbeth Bustamante, Admin assistant

 Chorus: Armen, Julian, Xuan
 Orange County: Flor, Bhuvana, Timothy Sigafoos, Sharon Ishikawa
 Agenda: Discuss NAMI warm line, tech/workflow needs, and OC Navigator project 
 NAMI has used iCarol for the past 10 years. They like it but it has many limitations. Very open to changing to the Navigator. 

 Armen gave an overview of the Navigator. We want to understand how to make this better than iCarol and work better for WarmLine. 

 MH : We use iCarol to log inbound calls. Vast amount of resources. They get attached to a call log. Can receive texts and chats and do follow up. They want customization. Volume is increasing, currently 8k/month. Want a smoother system for resources. Have consistency issues in data in iCarol. 

 SA: Also use iCarol for scheduling and communications among staff. We definitely need those two features. And RinkCentral, their phone provider. 

 Flaw of iCarol - hasn't changed anything in the past 10 years

 Close to 2000 resources currently. Don't want to migrate all that over because hard to find resourecs. Want the main agencies and each of their programs, not multiple listings of programs. About 500 agencies. 

 Keyword searches are glitchy 

 Scheduling
 Calendar on iCarol shows staff schedule, whether they're remote or in the office. Will text staff that they have a shift coming up. If we change the shifts, we can adjust on iCarol and alert the next staff. It's very basic and works for us. We would like a different interface, seamless system. 

 Mariam would like to be able to send out a email and text notice without the option to reply. iCarol is complicated to manually enter the schedules. Can be time consuming. 

 iCarol has chat feature and notice feature. Chat feature doesn't work well so they don't use it. 

 Events page is glitchy. They want something like a whiteboard or virtual bulletin page. Needs bigger font, a reply function.

 On Call feature, can track if this is an established versus new caller. Perhaps if there is a profile you can carry call-to-call. It brings up all the calls that person has had so far, calling in with that phone number. There's a button that you click if this is a new caller or established caller. This helps the mentor manually enter this in. Can put all persons' numbers on their profile.

 42 people in OC, 22 FTE. During the day, up to 12 mentors. In 1 hour, we have up to 8. 

 RingCentral is used for their calls. It's not integrated in iCarol, but would like it to be. That way the number is automatically populated and the profile is pulled up. 

 Reporting/Dashboards
 Can pull reports from dashboards - how many resources, how many calls came in, what was repeated. Those numbers aren't accurate due to iCarol. The data analyst has to pull the raw data, sorts it out, and then sends it out.

 Wants accurate data on dashboard where you can identify the dates, etc. Monthly data, weekly data, six months, and yearly. 

 Referrals
 Do a warm transfer to the Suicide hotline and language hotline

 For all others, we give phone numbers.

 Could share history with others, like OC Links. 

 Wish List
 Integration with phones 

 When call comes, call log is auto-populated

 Flexible scheduling features

 Consistent information about resources, and specific information, such as 5150 eligibility criteria to share with other staff. 

 Ability to label the calls in different colors so lead staff can triage and follow up appropriate. Red for urgent. Green- information. Yellow- etc.

 Chat & text functions. Text is connected to the main number. And text history gets logged into iCarol. Allows room for supervisor to chime in or take over the chat, especially in times of crisis. And, when you're chatting or texting, to easily pull a resource and paste it into the chat. 

 Quick phrases would be ideal.

title: CAT Clinician ‚Äì Master Project Document
content:
Unmet needs 
 Persona 
 UX Outcome 
 Success Goals/Metrics 

 CAT Clinician
 If we do a great job of dispatching CAT clinicians, they will be able to easily and effectively review relevant information of their assigned case to make preparation decisions. 
 Clearer coordination of case updates to managers and dispatch.
 These data-points would be accurately collected:
 Caller name

 Client name

 Client DOB

 Location + Bed/Unit + Gate Code

 Call back phone numbers

 Description (Perceived Risk)

 If we do a great job of dispatching CAT clinicians, they will be able to provide seamless and accurate work status updates while retaining focus on their task of priority .
 Accurately track the clinician's job.

 Collect accurate data about the CAT clinician on their case. 

 If we do a great job of supporting CAT clinicians, they will be able to easily and effectively find the appropriate resource in a database. 
 Provide an easy way to look up, retrieve, and find contact a resource.

 Add and update a resource information as necessary.

 If we do a great job of supporting CAT clinicians, they will be able to seamlessly communicate with OC Links team to coordinate necessary steps for a case. 
 Improve care coordination between OC Links and Crisis Team/

 CAT Admin
 If we do a great job of providing CAT admin the ability to do managerial tasks, they will be able to ensure their staff is working an appropriate amount and schedule them accordingly.
 Attain accurate data to report upon.

 If we do a great job of providing CAT admin the ability to do managerial tasks, they will be able to easily add, edit, or delete staff members from OC Links. 
 Provide access to OC Links navigators to do their job, and remove them once they leave for HIPAA compliance. 

 Objectives
 Create a platform for OC Links navigators to take calls, connect to resources, and invoke dispatch as necessary. This is to optimize their efficiency, and to integrate their system holistically.
 Create a platform for CAT technicians to receive dispatches and report/manage cases. This is to reduce manual paperwork, to more efficiently manage cases, and to more efficiently report their cases' status back to CAT admin.
 Create a platform for CAT Supervisor to collect data on case updates, and track time and amount of case spent per clinician for scheduling.
 User personas
 https://chorusapp.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/OC/pages/1195966503/Personas#Professional-Personas → Social worker 
 Archetypes → Frontline worker
 Proto-personas: https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lQWnBDw=/ → CAT clinician
 Personas: https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lMYymQ0=/ 
 User research
 3-22-21 Service Chief Study Notes: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1JeXrwA3l6guIjDrSegjZNurkeuXstefw?usp=sharing 
 3/22 Key Takeaways 

 3-30-21 CAT Clinician Interviews: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1ZJMp4wA2GnU6jyHnW4YBlzis269qsOWd?usp=sharing 
 3/30 Key Takeaways 

 4-9-21 CAT Dispatch Notes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/11cXbXgCnH2qiUh0k0f3nIsOtLw6HxWtHQl68ryr2Izo/edit?usp=sharing 
 4/9 Key Takeaways 

 CAT Dispatch Usability Testing 
 Some history
 Orange County Health Care Agency has contracted Chorus to build out a dashboard for their warm-line navigators to answer calls and chats from OC citizens and connect them to healthcare resources. OC Links has been around since October 2013.

OC Links was using iCarol up until Jan/Feb 2021. However, they used only about 10% of that platform's offerings, and therefore decided to go with something more bespoke in order to meet their needs.
 Sitemap
 https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lQKmDQs=/?moveToWidget=3074457357133737731&cot=14 
 Artifacts

 Created by Tim

 CAT dispatch form 
 Required fields from dispatchers in yellow

 Group chat of everyone, both OC Links and CAT teams, in a chat

 CAT Dispatch User Flow 
 When to collect time stamps from CAT Clinician indicated with red spark

 Constraints 
 This product will be running under the umbrella of OC Links. Each CAT clinician will have the same permissions and user flows as OC Links Navigators. 
 The product will be running on Chorus' platform, on responsive web. CAT clinicians will be using web on their county-issued devices, which include Apple mobile devices, iPads, and laptops.
 Explorations + Decisions
 Tim's design, Chorus notes in purple:

title: Bed Board ‚Äì Master Project Document
content:
Unmet needs 
 Persona 
 UX Outcome 
 Success Goals/Metrics 

 CSU ODOT (On Duty Office Technician)
 Real-time CSU facility bed/chair availability to interested parties, which include: CAT clinicians, OC Links Navigators, Admin, and Law Enforcement.
 Sync with other CSU facilities about which clients they are processing.
 Reduce manual time-on-task work for providing updates on facilities.

 Have clearer coordination between involved parties on behalf of the client.

 Save time by preventing other facilities duplicating the laborious process of intaking the same client.

 CSU Clinical OD
 Sync with other CSU facilities about which clients they are processing.
 Have clearer coordination between involved parties on behalf of the client.

 Save time by preventing other facilities duplicating the laborious process of intaking the same client.

 Save time so more focus can be 

 CSU Admin
 Monitor and manage CSU intake data.
 Detect patterns and optimize efficiency. 
 Note: still broad, they've said "We don't know what we don't know."

 Law Enforcement
 If LE has someone and needs to find a bed, they can pull up the info and go straight to what is available. They wouldn't have to go through the current process (which is unknown to Flor).
 Might be a need for LE to mark that they're moving someone to a bed, but don't have time to input information. Need a way to 'reserve' a spot. 
 Need to prevent multiple LE from showing up to one spot

 Solution - Perhaps a simple passcode for LE to access the bed board. Would need to look into legality.

 CAT Clinician
 View CSU bed availability to determine if this is a viable option for the client.
 Work successfully with CSU staff to find a bed for the client

 Objectives
 Create a website that reflects the status of a given CSU (Crisis Stabilization Unit) bed availability for receiving partners. The service should provide a live update of open beds, total available beds, and waitlist status.
 User personas
 Proto-personas: https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lQWnBDw=/ → CSU Staff
 Research 
 Relevance 

 https://chorusapp.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/OC/pages/1195966503/Personas#Professional-Personas 
 Admin Support Staff = CSU Staff + CSU Admin
 Case Worker = CAT Clinician?

 Archetypes 
 Frontline Supporter = CSU Staff
 Auditor = CSU Admin, Law Enforcement

 Jobs we want to cover
 Role 
 Job to be done 

 CSU OD + ODOT
 As a CSU ODOT, I need to provide the open bed count on my facility's beds available.
 As a CSU ODOT or OD, I need to communicate who I am starting to evaluate for intake to reduce redundancy with other facilities. 

 CSU Supr. CCN or Service Chief
 As a CSU Supr. CCN or Service Chief, I need to keep track of the facility's activity to learn trends about activity for process evaluation.

 Some history
 note As of July 1, 2021
 In use at HCA CSU

 Trained College Hospital Access Department, to begin training week of July 6

 Product requirements with law enforcement meeting 

 As of July 1, 2021
 In use at HCA CSU

 Trained College Hospital Access Department, to begin training week of July 6

 Product requirements with law enforcement meeting 08 Jul 2021 

 As a part of the OC Links project , a dashboard needs to be created to show CSU resources' status.

 Current solution, which was not rolled out, was to update an excel spreadsheet in a shared drive on Box. Excel spreadsheet template can be referenced here:

 Waitlists not needed

 Terms sheet 

 Notes
 3/22 Meeting
 CSUs - #2 and #3 are contractors
 County (15 beds)

 College Hospital (12 beds)

 Exodus (24 beds = 8 child + 16 adult)

 Who will be using this? 
 On-duty clinician will upkeep the bed board (person answering the phones, doing intakes). Need to establish a number of how many people would need access
 LVTs, LVNs, and RNs

 What do users need to see? 
 Main Board 

 They don't need to see funding or names: only what beds are filled and which aren't. Changes hour by hour. CSUs keep people less than 24 hours. Average turnover 8-12 hours in a CSU
 Other CSUs need to see the entire bed board, not just their own page. When a CSU is at capacity, they generate the referral package to another CSU. 

 Legal Status & Referral Source are pull-down options. Match with IRIS (integrated records information system)

 No need for a waitlist. Would transfer to ED if all CSU spots were full. 

 Pending referral page 
 Pending admission into CSU. Once picked up by LE, patient would need an eval by a CSU Provider before being admitted into a CSU. 

 Additional stakeholder group 
 Adding a stakeholder group - law enforcement (LE)

 Not sure what views they need to see
 Might be similar to OC Links view (open spots/closed spots)

 Goal: if LE has someone and needs to find a bed, they can pull up the info and go straight to what is available. They wouldn't have to go through the current process (which is unknown to Flor).

 Might be a need for LE to mark that they're moving someone to a bed, but don't have time to input information. Need a way to 'reserve' a spot. 
 Need to prevent multiple LE from showing up to one spot

 Solution - Perhaps a simple passcode for LE to access the bed board. WOuld need to look into legality. 

 Current Process 
 communicating by phone and fax. (County and College Hospital). Exodus just opened so still setting up processes.

 CAT Interaction 
 Cat clinician calls CSU when they have a client who needs to be transferred. CSU prioritizes these clients bc they're out in the field and not in a safe environment. CSU tries to get the CAT clinician back in the field asap. Open to liaison between CAT and CSU. 

 Need to run reports but not sure of scope. Matthew directed us to Nancy (?). Would progress from raw data dump to in-platform data analytics.

 Bed Board Internal Meeting Notes 
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Y_2p5MjXIHIzmZ9C7gvwn47dfB4dk-S1JCsI4wdW_Zw/edit?usp=sharing 
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Exgyc1iO2SdpODms2qvUO_vf4Ci2SXMipvijx98Rp5g/edit?usp=sharing 
 Statuses for Bed Board
 Out of date as of 4/26
 Status 
 Meaning 

 Reviewing
 Pending incoming referrals that are being reviewed

 Unable to Accommodate
 Client may be too medically compromised to come to the CSU and would need to go directly to inpatient unit; or CSU is at full census, or CHCH CSU is unable to accommodate due to no R&S room.

 Confirmed
 Confirmed means the client was admitted to an Inpatient BHU hospital which could be in Orange County or Out of County with OC MCAL.

 Accepted
 Client has been accepted to CSU and we're pending their arrival.

 Last Update ‚Äì 4/16 by Nicole Keefe, CSU Supervisor
 Constraints 
 Responsive web OC Links platform. Desktop usage.

 Working off of PCs. Working off of either chrome or internet explorer. Windows 10.

 Explorations + Decisions

 1 Updated resource listings 
 A user wants accurate, up-to-date information.
 HIGH Red 
 Crowdsourcing has been considered as an option. 

 2 Shareable resources
 A user wants to share a resource or list via print, text, or email. 
 HIGH Red 

 3 Match resource results with SDOH results
 A user wants resources that fit their profile and needs.
 HIGH Red 
 Eventually, the screener will be expanded to include more specific questions

 4 Filter resources
 A user wants to only view resources they are eligible for or that are relevant to their situation.

 HIGH Red 
 Include individual-level and program-level filters.
 Lack of knowledge about eligibility requirements frustrates users.

 5 Subcategories & resource information 
 HIGH Red 
 https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lHWe4FE=/ 

 6 Directions to a resource, and ability to send directions
 A user wants to know how to get to a resource. 
 A user wants to share directions with another person.
 HIGH Red 

 7 Annotate resources and lists
 Case worker wants to note barriers to service.
 Family member wants to note the org's primary contact. 
 Seeker wants to note down when they should follow up with the org. 
 HIGH Red 

 8 Connect button
 A user wants to connect to a resource. 
 A provider wants to refer their client to a resource.
 HIGH Red 

 9 Trusted lists 
 A user wants to
 create a list

 share a list

 make it private

 view others' lists 

 HIGH Red

 A user wants to learn how to use the OC Navigator.
 HIGH Red

 HIGH Red

 HIGH Red 
 User permissions

 Program and service administrators need to edit their resource listings

title: NAMI Meetings
content:
Meeting overview
 Provide a brief overview of what this meeting is about and any other information that might be helpful to attendees. 
 Meeting goals

 Key attendees
 Mariam Harris, Warmline Director

 Evan Cagle, IT, NAMI

 Enrique Estrada, IT, NAMI

 Hilda Franco, Supervisor for Warmline

 Stephanie Alvarez, Operators Mgr for Warmline

 Eeman Khairzada, Resource Specialist

 Lisbeth Bustamante, Admin

 Armen, Ben, Xuan, Kris, Brendan, Courtney, Visith

 Flor, Program Mgr 

 Sharon, MHSA Coordinator

 Mark Lawrenz, Division Mgr, PEI

 Bhuvana Rao

 Olga Gore, Health Program Specialist

 Processes

 Open action items
 1249181697 Meeting minutes
 Use color to help distinguish minutes of one meeting from another. 
 Date 
 Attendees 
 Agenda 
 Notes, decisions and action items 

 Eeman
 Kris, Courtney, Brendan, Xuan
 Categories & Subcategories
 12 categories with subcategories

 Organizing resources for export 
 NAMI will pair the resources into the right categories 
 mid-August for cleaned up dataset 

 Resources to be double categorized/subcategorized
 In iCarol, search hints will help with the population. 

 Stephanie 
 3 ways to search
 search bar 

 categories - talk to Eeman about what the categories should be 
 She suggested 20 categories and maybe an other 

 geographic filters

 no one searches by taxonomy

 Green resources - top resources
 every month, admin chooses the top resources being given out and changes them to green 

 121 
 incomplete 
 Stephanie will send us a new file with categories 

 Top resource information (keep it brief)
 call - services, location and phone number 

 email - location, address, hours

 FAQ type list
 Downloaded from PDF 

 They are working on guidebooks to help staff while they're on a call. Mostly text, with some links to websites. 

 Mentors receive an email with a guidebook every day and notes from workshop. 
 10,000 logged calls per month - Stephanie will ask how many calls refer to resources and traffic days 

 122 
 incomplete 
 check to see if Visith could analyze call reports. To Courtney, what questions do we want to answer? 

 Will use iCarol to communicate with other mentors and take chats. 
 Lists
 Anyone in NAMI should be able to see lists

 Stephanie
 Lisbeth Bustamante
 Olga Gore
 Bhuvana Rao
 Armen
 Ben
 Brendan
 Courtney
 Kris
 Visith
 Xuan
 Introductions

 Q&A
 How do you use iCarol to search for resources? 
 Primarily search by keyword

 Maps help them find resources by city, zip code, state, country

 iCarol has a category list, but not used often because it takes too long to search for resources and it's not user friendly
 There are 35 categories and they want to narrow down to 10. 

 Would like icons per category to help search; currently it's all text and links 

 Hurdle: resources have specific guidelines and criteria that are hard for them to figure out. Examples:
 What housing resource helps homeless people? 

 What program can take the patient right now? 

 Main problem: they can find resources, but it just takes too long. 
 They have a resource specialist who is more familiar with the resources. They want to avoid their mentors assigned to a resource specialist, and that the mentors are able to find resources on their own. 

 How do you decide which resources to refer to callers? 
 It depends on the caller's emotional state. We don't want to overwhelm them with resources. We'll give them 3 and invite them to call us back. 

 We have our top 25 ones we promote often. We have a good relationship with the agency and know they do good work.

 Stephanie shared her iCarol screen 
 Could sort resources in alphabetical order and by proximity

 Sharing resources
 Could save as pdf but don't do that to avoid info overload

 Currently, they copy paste information into the NAMI Warmline gmail account and send it to the caller.

 They want to be able to send information within the OC Navigator
 they want to just put in a person's email or phone and it sends the whole thing to them. 

 How are resources updated and verified? 
 Current steps
 Within iCarol, staff can view which resources haven't been verified in the past month or year, and mass email those agencies to update within 30 agencies. 

 Programs would then update their own information. 

 If they don't update within 30 days, the resource specialist updates it. We'd like the same feature, where it auto-mass emails resources that haven't updated. 

 Wants: 
 A similar process to their current method.

 Quality information

 Eligibility Information 
 Current:
 Basics: age and gender. No detail, such as geographic area

 Mentors always tell callers to double check with the program.

 How do you share resources with the caller/texter? 
 For the most part, give them resource info over the phone or email. 

 We can text through the iCarol chat system if the person initiated the conversation through text. 

 What resource information do you share with the person? 
 Name of agency, phone number, hours (especially if urgent)

 If over email, they'll add a short description. They'd never send a full description bc it'd be overwhelming. 

 Other features that are helpful? 
 'Recommended Referrals' related to the resource being viewed (automatic based on the description entries, and also based on other mentors' past activity) and 

 'Attachments' such as a brochure or other document

 Would be helpful to highlight changes that were updated on resource pages
 They send updates on agencies weekly to staff. They send updates on resource every 6 months. 

 Ability to pin resources or mark them as favorites

 FAQ for resources
 Where can i get help with housing? What are the next steps for a certain issue? 

 Idea to make lists for their top 25 issues / questions i.e. what to do in case of emergencies, current events, mass shooting, national help for covid. 
 They give them resources, but also steps for more specific issues (see screenshot) 

 lists would help with speed, can select this list and choose the best fit resources. 

 Notes/Annotation 
 Admin team can leave notes but they don't use this feature. 

 Experience? 
 To become an expert, really takes time and experience with resources, calls, complaints, etc.
 Resource specialist has been with them for years so she knows agencies very well

 Senior mentors also know resources well and some of them have used these resources too (they are peers). 

 Mentors are part time. They don't check email daily.

 VietRISE example: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QWKqlFjKZsXZaXvBeuaM9WkgwYXHW7VWWD0_jbIhgZk/edit?fbclid=IwAR24Gpz_RLjgD20EJqPZKN4zUx3LpE1MtXL9MsZ0mpSOCixV3EFTZSY3SwU#gid=1363012617 
 Training 
 3 weeks training, each peer has different capabilities. Their experience also determines how many hours they get to work. 
 Give them top resources. 

 iCarol training. 

 Call listening-in. 

 iCarol - can attach resources to our call report. Can also do a follow up. 

 Tracking 
 need to track how many resources they've referred to every month

 also track how many resources per caller

 Next steps
 User interviews 
 low vision mentor

 hard of hearing mentor

 Fully remote - plan to move into a hybrid model in the next month

 Stephanie will send us contacts tomorrow. 5/21

 All key attendees
 iCarol
 Are there any issues with iCarol searching resources?
 not user friendly. keyword search doesn't use. 

 resources need to be attached to call/text, able to email/send it 

 Resources - NAMI Warmline
 1500 resources, but want to minimize the number because finding what they need is an issue. No categorization. Types of calls vary from day to night.
 Solution: categories, custom lists

 117 
 complete 
 Stephanie Alvarez to clean up resources and send an export of resources 

 118 
 complete 
 NAMI will map out their resources 

 119 
 complete 
 Chorus to comb through resources and begin thinking about organization, structure 

 120 
 complete 
 Chorus set up follow up call 

 Scheduling - NAMI Warmline
 Need to schedule lead, mentor, on-call mentor

 Internal chat
 General communication about operations rather than case-based, unlike current CAT project

 Timeline
 Concerns: downtime and data loss during transition. An issue for Phase 2. 

 Pilot with OC Nav
 Phase 1: Use the OC Nav alongside iCarol 
 How can we link resources to the call log? They often link to a variety of resources. 
 Use OC Nav Share link to copy/paste link into iCarol

 Screenshots

title: OC Nav - Master Project Document
content:
Unmet needs 
 Why are we doing this? What does the user expect to accomplish that they can't? Why is it important that we fix it for them? 
 Users want to understand their needs.

 Users want to understand the needs of a friend/family member.

 Users want to understand how to best support their friends/family member in need.

 Users want to find and access local resources with up-to-date information. 

 Users want to feel more connected to their providers.

 Objectives
 What do we want to accomplish with this project? 
 Decrease gaps in service

 Increase continuity of care

 Normalize seeking mental health services 

 Raise awareness of local services 

 User personas
 Personas 
 Individual and Family Personas 
 Help seeker - seeking services for themselves 

 Helper - helping a loved one, client, or community member

 Explorer - browsing for information

 Professional and Provider Personas 
 Medical provider - refers patient to OC Navigator to find additional resources

 Case manager/social worker - looks for resources to refer to client

 Administrative support - updates resource listings, referral statuses, and connects clients to providers 

 Jobs we want to cover
 When I am feeling unwell and unsure, I would like help to find resources so that I can help myself.

 When I am feeling unwell and unsure, I would like to find resources I am eligible for so that I can help myself.

 As a user, I want to know how I can best help someone I know in need.

 As a user, I want to know what social/community resources are available to me.

 As a user, I would like to retrieve information about resources that I've heard about before.

 As a user, I would like to know about resources around certain need(s) I'm interested in finding help in.

 Some history

title: CAT Dispatch Usability Testing
content:
1. Executive Summary
 Overview
 Validate conceptually and from a usability perspective current mocks. 
 Can users successfully complete tasks that are essential to their role? 

 Verify usability of mobile designs for conducting tasks related to dispatching of cases.

 Understand pathways on mobile for them.

 Designs tested: https://www.figma.com/proto/89aOnpdiXgSvjrZOgRAGve/OC-Links?page-id=1653%3A0&node-id=1693%3A22525&viewport=36%2C240%2C0.08368200808763504&scaling=min-zoom 

 Discussion Guide: https://docs.google.com/document/d/19hznm-8fuLgKmtBf_o30IOo72ZzIci8ViY9Uvheg4xE/edit# 

 Usability study conducted April 16 ‚Äì 20, 2021
 N=6
 3 Adult CAT Clinicians

 3 Youth CAT Clinicians

 User Stories for CAT Clinician 
 As a CAT clinician, I want to quickly respond to a dispatch so that I can quickly respond to the crisis.

 As a CAT clinician, I want to quickly understand a case dispatch so that I can quickly prepare.

 As a CAT clinician, I want to provide case updates to dispatch so that they know the crisis is being attended to.

 As a CAT clinician, I want to communicate with the team to update details and coordinate logistics.

 As a CAT clinician, I want to find the appropriate resource with up-to-date information so that I can resolve the crisis appropriately.

 Results
 CAT Clinicians can accept a dispatch through the UI , but will need a few key details before going. 

 CAT Clinicians can navigate to and from the dashboard , although the cases in the dashboard were not always obviously interactive. 

 CAT Clinicians could navigate through the app as a whole, using the hamburger menu. However, exploring the other pathways inside case details was not always obvious to users and many needed to be prompted. 

 CAT Clinicians need a way to give and receive dispatching for offline. 

 Details for dispatch brief, case details, dashboard, and resources were mostly there , but could be optimized with more relevant information. 

 2. Detailed results
 Miro board for detailed notes from each user interview. 
 Video recordings for each user interview. 
 Mini Interviews
 User 
 How long have they been with CAT? 
 What do they use their work phone for most often? 
 Hopes and fears around passing dispatch off to OC Links 

 P1 
 5 years
 Mainly calls and texts as part of communication with others on her shift, checks email.
 She's unsure how it'll go with OC Links dispatching bc she hasn't worked with them yet bc she's Noc shift. She sees benefit to have more people in field, but also cautious about learning curve during crisis.

 P2 
 3 years
 She uses her phone mostly for communicating with dispatch, hospitals, CRPs, resources, arranging transportation. She both calls and texts.

 P3 
 3 years
 Calls to reporting party, emails, text messages to coworkers, sending ambulance vouchers via Adobe Acrobat.

 P4 
 2.5 years
 She will use her work phone to check emails, group thread text, log into mtgs, token to access to log into Citrix on her desktop. Doesn't use the mobile version.

 P5 
 3 years
 COVID-19 has accelerated their use of communicating by phone, since they're telecommuting sometimes
 Fears about new dispatch process: we've had issues w/ OCLN understanding what we do. "We understand what we do." so easier to dispatch. OCLN need to explain our services. Sometimes they'll go out and call will need to be cancelled for this reason. Ex: parent calling when child has a tantrum.
 Also some details get lost: Ppl not getting correct number or address also an issue.

 P6 
 10 months
 Checking in with dispatch when I'm out, talking with clients and collateral parties (police, family)
 "Sounds like a good idea, alleviates pressure of having a bunch of dispatches. Gives you more time to keep up on documentation.
 "Not worried, bc OCLN are doing training."

 Tasks with prototype
 Task success: 
 üü¢ = coped at the first attempt
 üü† = coped but with difficulties
 üî¥ = couldn't cope at all
 üí° = a side idea
 ‚ùó = emphasized statement‚Äîa user gets emotional about it
 !! = the most crucial for a user, described in detail.
 User 
 Responding to a dispatch 
 Updating case details + location 
 Communicating while on the case 
 Dashboard 
 Resources 

 P1 
 üü¢ Able to accept
 Wanted to know more information about the example client's medical condition, to determine if CAT should go out

 Address should note what type of location it is (school, residence, group home, ER, etc.)

 Language should show client and family language preferences

 Could be helpful to specify caller's relationship outside of description

 Insurance type helpful (Private v. Medi-Cal v. unfunded), determines which paperwork she brings

 Better for her to have more information up front. She likes the dropdown. 

 üü¢ Could update time
 Didn't really scroll on her own

 Time stamps different than what she uses:
 **Need to include date as well as time (she works before and after midnight)

 Date/time dispatched

 Date and time of arrival

 Wait time before assessment (for PD or RN)

 Assessment start date/time

 Assessment end date/time 

 CYBH doesn't track ambulance vouchers, do so internally

 She liked the navigation part. She usually uses google maps to look up location first, then will use her car's navigation while driving.

 Noted that she often goes to areas with bad reception, like ERs for example, which she goes to often.

 üü¢ Could navigate to chat
 Important for her to be able to chat with the dispatcher directly. Calling important for PHI.

 üü† She expected to go back to the dispatch brief
 She expected to go back to the case dispatch when she was accepting the call

 She thought it was nice to see dashboard, to see who is out in the field. But not a priority for her, she usually knows who is on her shift.

 She thinks this view can be helpful to see whether it's a busy night, to see if she'll have to go out right away.

 She commonly refers to resources that are county approved.

 Description and website would help in overview, as well as phone number in detail view.

 P2 
 üü¢ Able to accept
 Easier to read than the PDF

 SSN + MRN useful for Medi-cal. More important than the description.

 Dispatched ≠ Time Contacted

 üü† Needed quite a bit of guiding
 She would prefer to have outcomes on the top

 She would want to message the dispatcher directly

 Did not scroll on her own, would have missed dispatch PDF if she had not been led. Might be too far down for her to edit it.

 For disposition, important to include "call cancelled." Also important to provide a multi-select option, in case the outcome is more than one (ex: DTS + DTO)

 üü† Needed to be guided here
 Did not notice the people icon in the chat

 She would expect the phone icon to call the main line

 She would want to contact the dispatcher directly

 üü¢ Could navigate to dashboard
 Unhelpful to see other cases. 

 If a repeat case, they might try to see who else is on, for client history.

 She would expect to see the cases for the current day only.

 She understood hamburger menu.

 üü¢ Could navigate to resources
 She liked that resources was blank to start. She is very familiar with resources in the community, so she usually knows which ones she wants to refer to.

 The ones she's less familiar with are local food banks or shelters, as they change a lot too.

 She thought the resource card was helpful, but needed the hours. Helpful to know how soon they can call.

 P3 
 üü¢ Able to accept
 Did not see client's name right away, would bring down intuitiveness rating because of this

 MRN and SSN helpful

 Liked this brief version view: "I'm not digging around here."

 Crisis type not needed, could gather from description

 Missing: 
 County history w/ client

 Substance abuse info

 Weapons on them

 Propensity to violence

 üü¢ Could update and edit time, chat, and go to directions
 Liked the time stamps: "It's like pizza hut!"
 "That's cool. I like that I don't have to check my watch."

 Liked that the times updated on their own. Important to also have flexibility to edit. She mentioned "Add" instead of "Save" would make more sense.

 For ambulance in outcomes, expected a dropdown because they only work with a few.

 Important to provide more than one option for disposition
 Dispositions used:
 5150 (adult)

 5585 (child)

 6000 (voluntary)

 DTS

 DTO

 GD

 Successful diversion (not hospitalized)

 Call cancelled

 No one at scene

 Uses Waze to look up directions. "I'm not the best with directions," important for her to look up directions.
 She usually has to call the caller before going to confirm address. Happens often enough that address is incorrectly entered.

 She personally always starts from the office because she lives far away. She would print the PDF form before going.

 üü† Could chat, but contacting directly had weird navigation for her.
 Noted the flow of going back from profile to chat was not intuitive

 Currently rare for them to contact an OC links navigator.

 üü¢ Could navigate to dashboard
 She liked seeing all of the current cases. She understood the filter.

 It would be helpful to see any pending cases and where they are. This would help for her to plan ahead, if she can have dinner yet, where she's going

 She liked seeing the status update. Didn't seem to notice the progress bar below.

 She thought the dot meant there was an update, something's changed.

 She noted that they don't usually use client's initials unless it's in an email, for privacy purposes. "You never know who's looking over your shoulder."

 üü¢ Could navigate to resources using hamburger menu
 She felt there were too many filters. It could be too much. "The more I put in, the more it takes away from what I'm getting." Wants to see a good array of stuff when filtering

 She liked the favorites list concept. Since she often uses the same ones.

 In filters, insurance and city weren't very important since adults can travel.

 She didn't like that the resources page was blank, she is usually looking for the ones she goes to often. e.g. OC links, NAMI warmline.

 Less common resources she'll have to look up: housing, shelter, substance use stuff, job stability, office of family and consumer affairs

 The website would be helpful to see what they do.

 P4 
 üü¢ Able to accept
 SSN usually not given.

 FIN missing. MRN can help, but FIN is what they use.

 If it's a residential call, doesn't mention whether police have been called

 If it's a hospital, missing bed number and clearance status

 Language could be higher up on the page.

 üü¢ Understood time stamp right away, and could get to map
 She liked the time stamp feature but thought it would be better for later in the call.

 Also thought outcome wouldn't be needed until the end. 

 Noted some details missing from dispatch PDF, such as FIN, location, and if hospital, bed number.

 She will start to do bed search activity form from EHR in the field

 They currently double document, she usually does EHR first

 She liked seeing the location

 üü¢ Understood chat and its features
 Understood people icon

 She would want the ability to both communicate with group and the person. 

 She would want to call and text someone individually. Calling important for PHI, and if she has a lot of info
 "[In the case] I'm in a really weird situation."

 She expected to see OD, service chief, and OCLN

 She usually contacts dispatcher, rarely OCLN

 üü¢ Navigated to open cases
 Noted the filters for cases right away

 Noticed the progress bar, understood it

 She likes seeing her cases. If she clicked on it and it took her to the full thing that'd be helpful (seems she didn't know it was interactive)
 She would want to see the dispatch form and outcome for a closed case

 When she's doing paperwork, she's doing multiple cases at once. So helpful to see in a view like this.

 She likes to note the kids' parents' number or FIN

 She thought the dot meant it was an open case.

 Order of info on the card: she liked caller and client, DOB, and status. May time stamp. Could be helpful to have insurance or language or family language

 üü¢ Navigated to resources
 She liked the filter categories she saw

 She usually gives out a list of resources

 Resource page is a nice-to-have, not a must-have

 She likes that Chorus has a list of resources to help become more aware of new resources. Sometimes she'll call the county

 She likes prioritization of info, she'd want bed availability on top. Saves her a lot of time to have bed availability.

 Likes idea of curated list. "Cuts down on time I'm searching."

 She personally likes to have other lists too.

 P5 
 üü† Did not see accept button
 He noted he could not accept the case at this point. He wanted to know age of caller, to determine if an adult was there. If not, they would need to try to contact them and/or have PD conduct a wellness check

 Missing COVID symptoms information

 Would be good to note which insurance, particularly if it's Kaiser. They have their own CAT team and are out-of-network for CAT.

 üü¢ He was able to use time stamps, ran out of time to ask about location.
 He thought priority order of info was "about right."

 He thought arrival and clear times were helpful, noted he has a hard time remembering to note those.
 "There's something always going on, it's hard to keep track."

 Noted that for dispatch time, there are various reasons someone would not leave right away. He was concerned about the purpose of tracking this time and how it would be used. 
 Noted in EHR, time contacted = dispatched. Different than leaving.

 üü† Did not notice the chat feature in the design on his own
 He didn't notice the team chat feature right away.

 Texting is easier for teammates with him.
 "To do it twice doesn't seem necessary."

 He would expect to have in the chat: CAT being dispatched, dispatcher, bed searcher, service chief, and OD if they still have one.

 Helpful to be able to contact someone individually, but depends on situation. 
 "If we're missing information then it's important to reach out."

 üü† Did not expect to navigate here, but understood it after seeing it.
 Didn't notice the filters for the other cases in this view right away

 üü¢ Navigated to resources
 Usually refer to same CSUs and outpatient programs, 80% of the time
 Usually, he's looking up for a parent/child. He's writing it down for them, on a disposition form. Regional outpatient centers on there, but there's more

 Wondered about personal customization of a list. Or saved resources on a page.

 Likes the idea of having resources all in one place. 

 Information helpful
 He liked resource info. Phone # and address are most important.

 He likes bed availability. Usually refers to a crisis residential unit based on availability. Usually has to call.

 On details page, he suggested a description. Maybe a notes section. "But most of it's here."

 He didn't expect to be able to tap into it to find details.

 P6 
 üü¢ Able to accept
 Wanted to know more information such as:
 weapons on them

 substance abuse history

 hospital history

 medical history

 diagnosis/diagnoses

 medication

 Would want to also check with client about:
 Insurance/Medi-Cal

 What client is doing exactly at that moment

 Substance abuse

 Weapons

 üü¢ Understood the case details and location pages, and their functionality.
 Initial impressions: assumed it was the CAT tab from Chorus

 Suggested putting case updates info into chronological order, which would be:
 Dispatch PDF

 Time stamps

 Outcome

 For time stamps, she correctly guessed how it would work. She expected to add live time and be able to edit it.
 Noted that inputting time this way would take some getting used to.

 Outcome: she would edit as she goes, all at once would be easier bc less steps. She usually notes as she goes along. She doesn't do voucher from the field.

 Address is nice and clear, "I can put it into my app." Wondered if it would be an interactive map.

 Time stamps she uses
 Dispatched = time clinician left.

 Arrival = time you got to scene

 Assessment = how long you spent w/ the client
 How long she speaks on the phone

 How long she speaks to client face-to-face

 How long it takes to drive to hospital or the scene

 How long she spends at hospital

 How long she waits for ambulance or PD

 Clear = when done

 üü† Needed to be led here, did not expect to have this feature.
 Had no expectation of what would be in there

 She would contact CAT colleague to look at EHR

 She would often contact CAT dispatch, usually talks to them in person when she's in the office. From the field, texting is tough bc HIPAA

 üü† Did not expect to navigate here, but understood it after seeing it.
 Took a second to notice the "my cases" title, not noticeable to her

 Info on card helpful. Gives a good review. Likes the age and address.

 She doesn't know if she needs to see her recent cases. She keeps her own logs to track. Uses it to track her hours for her license.
 An excel doc the service chiefs gave. She notes: date, client name, disposition, where we are in the case, address

 Going back to dashboard was a little confusing for her. She doesn't think she would want to go back to a view like this if she's on a case.

 She thought dot meant it was open. She saw the progress bar, understood its meaning.

 She liked that the dot was to denote a notification.

 üü¢ Could navigate to resources
 Resource - she wasn't sure if she'd use this. Maybe frequent resources would be saved

 She gives a resource sheet usually

 Thought the category filters helpful, such as hours, accepting new patients, and language. not sure about insurance.

 List seems more helpful to have, than searching and filtering.

 She liked seeing bed availability, especially in real-time. Would save time calling.

 She understood she could tap on it

 In details page, she liked seeing bed count with pending, and phone number. But would be good to know what the gender of the bed count would be.

 3. Further actions
 View 
 Key Finding 
 Next Steps 

 Dispatch brief
 More information up front is better 
 While some info is good to have here, clinician would see want to and expect to see the full dispatch PDF before leaving.

 Address should include what type of location it is:
 Residence
 Residence type (house, condo complex, etc)

 Hospital
 Bed number

 Clearance status

 Group home

 School

 Children and Adult dispatches differ in information 
 MRN and SSN helpful for Adult CATs. Child CAT use FIN more often.

 For adult, substance abuse, weapons, and history of violence are important details for preparing.

 Youth CAT needs to know status of parent involvement, and if not at site, whether an adult is present.

 Reorganize information in this view based on what CATs prioritize
 Client name inside 

 Caller + relationship + if they are an adult (for CYBH cases)

 For CYBH: has parent/legal guardian been contacted?

 Substance abuse info

 County history

 Medical history, diagnosis

 Weapons on them, propensity to violence

 Address + location type

 COVID-19 symptoms + if anyone at site is positive

 Provide a way to quickly view the dispatch PDF, either by email or a pathway through the page. 

 Provide different information for Child v. Adult dispatch. Perhaps create a different form altogether, to only display what is relevant for that CAT.

 Provide a way for clinicians to respond to dispatches if in an area with low network reception.

 Case Details ‚Äì Case Updates
 Time Stamps helpful feature, with some considerations needed 
 Time stamps should include date as well as time, for those that work before and after midnight. 

 Seemed helpful for many, who are on the go and don't always remember to mark down their times

 Outcome should be shown towards the end of their case journey 
 Disposition should be a multi-select

 Ambulances should be a dropdown, since they work with only a few of them

 Ambulance voucher not always relevant for CYBH CAT

 Pain-point of double-entering 
 Ensure that information being tracked does not cause too much double-entering, like how they currently do in excel.

 Provide the ability to both mark current time in time stamps, as well as edit.

 Provide ability to not just mark the time but the date as well.

 Explore ways to build trust in documenting time stamps. Perhaps include note about how these would be used and why.

 Provide a way for clinicians to provide updates if in an area with low network reception, or system goes offline.

 Keep track of what information can be automated

 Case Details ‚Äì Message Thread, Communication
 Our chat will likely not be the main mode of a case's communication 
 Important for team to make calls, and not text or chat, for several reasons:
 Handling of PHI

 Faster

 Easier

 Contacting the dispatcher/OC Links Navigator directly is important; general OC Links line not helpful because they will get put on hold.

 Currently rare for the CAT clinician while in the field to contact the OC Links Navigator.

 Most clinicians do not use Skype while out in the field, only when they are dispatching or bed searching.

 OCHCA should level-set expectations on how and when teammates should communicate with one another. 
 Add a "Roster" page, to provide a way for user to contact a colleague directly.
 For OC links Navigator, important for the clinician to contact them directly and not the OC links general line, because it would take too long. 

 Optional: Explore an easy pathway for calling/texting a colleague, or easy download of OC Links + CAT teams contacts.
 Down-the-road: intranet chat

 Case Details ‚Äì Location
 Location is helpful to see 
 Most expected it to be interactive or to open up their own native app for maps.

 Many clinicians often call the caller before leaving to confirm the address, not having a valid 

 Provide information on what type of location the address is (residence, school, etc.), which should be collected from the CAT call.
 Is it possible to validate address via Google Maps API?

 Is it also possible to validate the location type via Google maps API?

 Later on: Provide a native app integration, when feasible.

 Dashboard
 Dashboard of their cases is helpful for logging their own paperwork on cases after. But not necessary for while out on the field. 
 Two clinicians mentioned it would be helpful in terms of seeing call volume.

 One mentioned pending would be helpful.

 Another mentioned helpful to reference if CAT receives a repeat client, so they can see which clinician had the client previously.

 Clinicians often thought the dot meant the case was live or there was an update.

 Provide heuristic to indicate card is interactive, so that they can go to more details.

 Provide same amount of information that dispatchers would see, including "Pending" view.

 Dashboard usage should also be to remind CAT clinicians about follow-ups.

 Create a new GUI to indicate a message notification.

 Resources
 Most CAT clinicians refer to the same list of resources, currently a paper form they provide 
 Adult form 

 Child resources 

 Clinicians refer to the same resources "80% of the time." Rare for CAT to need to look up a new resource. 

 Information provided helpful, but some noted a description of the facility and their hours would be helpful to see.

 Bed Count would be helpful for CAT Clinicians while in the field 
 Most CAT Clinicians got excited when seeing bed availability for a resource.

 Saves them a phone call

 CAT clinicians could navigate to resources, and find a resource. 
 Some of the clinicians did not seem to know the card in search view was interactive. 

 List of resources seems helpful for CAT 
 Separate adult from child resources

 One noted that she has a hard time looking up, and has sometimes referred clients to call OC Links to help them find more resources.

 One noted it would be helpful to see last visited resource in this view

 Provide heuristic to indicate card is interactive, so that they can go to more details

 Lists or favoriting of resources would be helpful for clinicians, since they often refer to the same set, as well as make it easier to have on hand. 
 Distinguish adult from child resources

 Helpful to see others' lists, not just their own

 Bed Board integration would provide high value for the clinician.
 Explore what this could look like for a CAT Bed Searcher

title: OC Links Navigator Usability Testing
content:
1. Executive Summary

Overview
 Validate conceptually and from a usability perspective current mocks: 
 Can users successfully complete tasks that are essential to their role? 

 Understand pathways, validating side rail. Where would I go to complete a given task?

 Designs tested: Figma Link 

 Methodology 
 Discussion Guide Draft 
Usability study conducted April 16 ‚Äì 20, 2021
 N=6 OC Links Navigators 
 Note: The first participant, Maria, had received advanced training on CAT integration with OC Links. The rest of the participants had not. 

 User Stories for OCL Navigator 
 As a navigator, I want to find a given CAT case to make changes to it. 
As a navigator, I want to find a CAT given case for reference.
As a navigator, I want to track a CAT case to monitor its progress.
As a navigator, I want to dispatch a CAT case so that a CAT clinician can rapidly respond.
As a navigator, I want to communicate with the team to ensure the CAT case is being attended to and provide help to CAT as necessary.

*Note: The OC Links Navigators have not dispatched CAT yet, only pass off cases to their dispatcher. These tasks will be new to five of the participants (except the first participant, who has received advanced training.) 
 Key Findings 
 ‚úÖ What worked well: 
 Overall, tests showed that both iterative design changes to the current experience, as well as the new flow of assigning a CAT Clinician and referencing CAT cases were received positively. 

 Participants appreciated larger radio buttons and splitting some parts of the CAT Dispatch form into two columns, making it easier to read as well as complete the form. 

 Participants loved having CAT Cases accessible from the Dashboard view, as well as a separate side-navigation option to access the CAT Case overview. 

 ‚ö†Ô∏è What needs improvement: 
 Participants indicated that much of their time is spent completing forms , and there could be ways to make this process more efficient. 
 Provide address validation or address autocomplete with a map API. 
 Optional: Street View embed. 

 Provide current timestamp automatically in fields, with ability to edit in case time needs to be modified. 

 Formatting the MRN number field to split the eight digit entry with a hyphen, e.g. '####-####' 

 Many components of the CAT Dispatch form are left blank because information is unlikely able to be collected from callers (e.g. insurance information, SSN, DoB). 
 Optional: Adding a 'Not sure' option for some of the radio button questions can possibly reduce CAT Clinician - OC Nav communication. 

 Optional: Indicating 'Found' v. 'Not found' for a client's EHR could be beneficial. CAT Clinicians often want to know if the Navigator can provide them with an EHR. 

 Optional: Adding in cues for users to know which CAT form fields have yet to be completed, but not required to fill out. 

 New message awareness is still lacking , and participants mentioned often not seeing when someone in Live Chat has replied. Platform allowing, exploring ways to make messaging more dynamic and allowing for sound/flashing notification. 
 Additionally, the new message icon in CAT Cases could be made more prominent, perhaps with a color + size change. 

 The Resources tab in a case is problematic for users: 
 Search often does not return desired resource, even when some participants said they adjusted for case sensitivity. 

 'Enter' to confirm Search on the Resources tab in a case would be a time-saver. 

 Participants said they often use the same 10-20 resources, so providing a 'Favorite' list of these options to select directly in this view, rather than having to use 'Search' would be beneficial. 

 CAT should be automatically assigned as a resource if it is a CAT case. 

 Follow-ups require entering a lot of duplicative information. Participants want follow-ups to automatically pipe in relevant data from associated case, especially if it contains CAT information. 
 The description/narrative in particular should be piped over, but allow it and other fields to be modifiable so updates can be put in the follow-up. 

 Dashboard should provide a 'My Cases' filter as opposed to the Navigator having to select their own name. 'My Recent Cases' should be 'Recent Cases'. 

 Detailed task results 
 Miro board for detailed notes from each user interview. 
 Video recordings for each user interview. 

 Info importance:

 ‚ÄºÔ∏è = the most crucial for a user, described in detail

title: CAT Clinician Feature: Providing Case Updates
content:
User Stories 
 As a CAT Clinician, I need to provide case updates to dispatch so that they know when and how the crisis is being attended to.
 Open (before clinician contacted)

 Contacted | CTD 

 Dispatched | DIS 

 Arrival | ARR 

 Assessment Start | STR 

 Assessment End | END 

 Cleared | CLR 

 Provide an additional field for notes 
 As a CAT Clinician, I need to provide case outcome updates to dispatch so that they know how the crisis is being resolved.
 Voluntary hold

 Involuntary hold

 Diverted (not hospitalized)

 Call Cancelled

 No Contact

 Usability Study ‚Äì Action Items
 Provide the ability to both mark current time in time stamps, as well as edit.

 Provide ability to not just mark the time but the date as well.

 Explore ways to build trust in documenting time stamps. Perhaps include note about how these would be used and why.

 Provide a way for clinicians to provide updates if in an area with low network reception, or system goes offline.

 Keep track of what information can be automated

 Notes from Research
 Date + Time: Call Received
 Date + Time: Call Ended
 Date + Time: Dispatched 
 Date + Time: Arrival
 Date + Time: Wait time (for PD or ambulance)
 Date + Time: Assessment Start
 Date + Time: Assessment End
 Date + Time: Cleared
 P1: 
 Terms she uses: 
 1. Date and time dispatched
 2. Date and time of arrival 
 3. Wait time (waiting for a PD or RN) before assessment
 4. Assessment start
 5. Assessment end
 They update all of this at the end of the call.
 P5: 
 He uses "call received", "call ended," "time of arrival," "assessment time" (bc police wait time), assessment running time after 1st contact.
 Time stamps were kind of semantics. In EHR, time contacted = dispatched
 P6: 
 Time contacted = when clinician contacted.
 Dispatched = time clinician left.
 Arrival = time you got to scene
 Assessment = how long you spent w/ the client
 Clear = when done
 Her assessment has more details, such as:
 How long she speaks on the phone
 How long she speaks to client face-to-face
 How long it takes to drive to hospital or the scene
 How long she spends at hospital
 How long she waits for ambulance or PD
 Outcome Notes
 Adult
 Welfare and Institution Code (WIC) 5150: Danger to Self (DTS), Danger to Others (DTO), and/or Grave Disability (GD) 

 Voluntary Hospitalization (6000)

 Successful diversion (not hospitalized)

 Child
 Welfare and Institution Code (WIC) 5585: Danger to Self (DTS), Danger to Others (DTO), and/or Grave Disability (GD) 

 Voluntary Hospitalization

 Successful diversion (not hospitalized)

 Outcomes could be a combination of these options

title: Research Findings: Usability Testing for Bed Board for HCA CSU Employees
content:
Author 

 Research Goal 
 Validate conceptually and from a usability perspective current mocks that users can successfully complete tasks that are essential to their roles as clinicians / coordinators / admissions administrators at HCA CSU. 
 Methodology 
Designs tested: Figma Link 
User interviews conducted April 21st to 23rd.
 An initial focus group with HCA CSU leadership occurred on April 21st, followed by four 1:1 interviews with HCA CSU employees with varying roles and shifts (daytime v. night) to gather diverse opinions on functionality of the bed board. 

 Miro board : detailed notes from each user interview, as well as the discussion guide. 
 Key Findings 
 ‚ö†Ô∏è What needs improvement: 
 Users are worried about a lack of context for status updates, and responded very positively to the addition of a comment box where notes could be recorded. 
Some examples where notes could come in handy:
 Patients have certain medical issues, Unable to accommodate is due to medical but other CSUs can accommodate, age, medical or funding issues. these are three issues as to why unable to accommodate. 
 Product update: This will be included in v1 launch. 

 Timestamps should be in 'military' time. 
 Product update: We cannot modify how time is input in the UI, but we can make sure it is always displayed in military time. 

 'Pending Medical Transfer' should be a separate status . This would describe clients admitted to the CSU who are waiting to be transferred to a different medical facility, however due to lack of beds at that facility they are waiting in the CSU (sometimes for up to a week). 

 Product update: This is based on feedback from Nicole directly, however we are going to recommend we put this in the description since it is categorically more of a sub-status of 'Accepted/Accepted' 

 Hospitals should be called specifically in the 'Referral' section. 
 Product update: This will be included in the 'Referral Description' field. 

 Provide funding specificity for MediCare and MediMed. They need A/B /D, i.e .all combinations possible A/B/D. A client can have A/B but not D, or just D, etc. 
 Product update: v1 will include this in the Notes section of each case. 

 MediCal - County Codes: Each county has numbered code. Knowing the code allows determination if insurance can cover costs, provide care to them in other area after they leave OC. 30: Orange County, 19: LA County are most often seen. 
 Product update: v1 will include this in the Notes section of each case. 

 Dashboard View: Prioritize or highlight CAT / PD referrals as these are more time-sensitive and have priority. 
 Product update: We will accomplish this through color indicators, but not arrange them to appear above other cases in the pending queue.

title: NAMI Pilot Product Requirements Doc
content:
Fill in project details in the table below. Type /date to quickly add the target release date, /jira to link to Jira epics or issues, and @mention functional owners to keep everyone on the same page. 
 Target release
 June 30 2021

 Epic

 Document status
 DRAFT 

 Document owner

 Community engagement
 Bowen, Visith, Sara, Norma, Angelina

 Designer

 Tech lead

 User researchers

 Technical writers

 QA

 Objective
 Piloting the OC Navigator with NAMI Warmline takes a step towards preparing OC Navigator for a public launch in the fall. We'll have the opportunity to work on and test features such as lists, searching, and resource information organization. 
 Provide context on this project and explain how it fits into your organization's strategic goals 
 Success metrics
 TO DO
 Are their financial incentives or performance metrics built into NAMI's contract with the county? If no formal metric, is there an informal metric?

 Do they have data on iCarol? Speak to IT. 

 Do we have a BAA with NAMI to allow PHI?

 Goal
 Metric

 Warmline staff incorporates OC Navigator into their work
 If you had a choice to search for resources, what tool would you choose? Why?

 Mentors who experience low vision or are HOH can use the OC Navigator

 Mentors request less help from the resource specialist while using the OC Navigator. 
 ask eeman Reduced number of emails/requests for help 

 Reduce number of clicks to get to a resource
 via screen share or shadowing session

 Does the OC Navigator bring any additional value to your work compared to iCarol? 

 Encounter less issues than iCarol, such as page load, page freezing, bugs 
 ask evan cagle, it 

 Reduce call time for mentors 
 They can talk to more people. This might not be useful to measure since mentors might need to do double work. Might also be hard to measure. 

 Assumptions
 List any assumptions you have about your users, technical constraints, or business goals (e.g., Most users will access this feature from a tablet) 
 Enabling users to create curated lists will:
 a. improve the dissemination of information about resources between staff
 b. add additional information about what resources are relevant
 c. improve the speed of finding relevant resources for specific cases

 Enabling users to add notes/messages to resources will increase the amount of specific details and local knowledge about a resource

 Enabling viewing of recently active resources/lists/messages will improve the dissemination of new information to staff

 Milestones [draft]
 Use the roadmap planner (/roadmap) to help your team stay on track. To edit workstreams or dates, select the placeholder below and tap the pencil icon.
