m%20scope%20and%20success%20metrics%20internally%20and%20with%20Flor%22%2C%22duration%22%3A2.0792079207920793%2C%22pageLink%22%3A%7B%7D%7D%2C%7B%22rowIndex%22%3A3%2C%22startDate%22%3A%222021-06-07%2003%3A19%3A36%22%2C%22id%22%3A%2215e722f4-cccc-4c14-9bd5-3c70faaf193e%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Design%20%26%20UX%2FUI%20Iterations%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22%22%2C%22duration%22%3A1.9603960396039604%2C%22pageLink%22%3A%7B%7D%7D%2C%7B%22rowIndex%22%3A4%2C%22startDate%22%3A%222021-06-21%2004%3A59%3A24%22%2C%22id%22%3A%22f0f8bb80-ccc8-4a65-a067-e086f65ff1da%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Build%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22%22%2C%22duration%22%3A2.0495049504950495%2C%22pageLink%22%3A%7B%7D%7D%2C%7B%22rowIndex%22%3A5%2C%22startDate%22%3A%222021-06-28%2014%3A41%3A29%22%2C%22id%22%3A%22cfbdfdf4-f4b0-45dc-9b7c-4587e4542b4c%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Onboarding%20(tbd)%22%2C%22description%22%3A%22%22%2C%22duration%22%3A1%2C%22pageLink%22%3A%7B%7D%7D%5D%7D%5D%2C%22markers%22%3A%5B%7B%22title%22%3A%22Milestone%201%22%2C%22markerDate%22%3A%222018-07-31%2016%3A38%3A01%22%7D%2C%7B%22markerDate%22%3A%222018-10-08%2001%3A25%3A32%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Go%2FNo%20go%22%7D%2C%7B%22markerDate%22%3A%222018-12-31%2001%3A54%3A03%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Milestone%202%22%7D%5D%7D Roadmap%20Planner 74cf283cfd3756f070ec109bccd861f5 Type /trello to add a card or board to this page or /jira to include a Jira issue, chart, or project. 
 Requirements 
 Requirement
 Importance
 Problem/Questions

 1 Clearly displayed categories 
 Relevant categories, including COVID

 Include a COVID related category

 HIGH Red 
 Currently, there are 35 categories and would like to narrow down to 10. They also have individual listings of services that belong to one program. Ideally, resources would be organized by main agency. 
 Understand journey paths to finding a resource → UXR to uncover 

 2 Easy-to-use filters 
 Help find the best-fit resources for their callers

 Help find services that are available now 

 HIGH Red 
 Understand journey paths to finding a resource → UXR to uncover 

 3 Detailed resource information 
 Basics: hours, location, 

 Eligibility criteria
 Age, gender, geographic region

 Changelog of edits

 Stephanie brought up idea of a change-log to see how up-to-date a resource is 

 4 Updated resource information 
 HIGH Red 
 NAMI experiences issues with consistency and accuracy among their ~1010 resources

 How do we show revision history or 'last verified' for a resource? 

 Can we give the user reminders of when to update a resource? 

 5 Sharing of resources and lists 
 Do not share URL link

 Text or email 

 HIGH Red 
 Currently, resources are: 
 Copy/pasted from iCarol to the NAMI gmail account

 Shared verbally over phone

 Questions 
 What information about a resource do they share? 

 How does this vary? 

 Do they ever add notes when sharing? 

 Is there a way we can users customize the selection? → UXR to uncover 

 6 Search 
 How would searches be referenced? E.g., referenced from a single database or not? 

 Tags? 
 Would tags be free form or a set list of tags? 

 Note: reference "search hints" column in their excel

 7 Lists to help find resources faster
 A list page to help mentors find all lists belonging to NAMI. 

 List description and 'last edited by'

 HIGH Red 
 What's the flow for adding a resource to a new list? To an existing list? 

 Would sublists be helpful?

 Would they like personal private lists, vs. public to all staff?

 Would notes in the list be helpful? 

 Would they like active lists? How is that defined?

 Would they use lists like FAQs? 

 Do they need to attach files? 

 How could they search lists?

 8 Notes section for resources and lists
 Requires login to see, not public

 Would notes be helpful? 

 Do the notes need to be structured? Do they need to be chronological?

 Are comments helpful? How long does a comment stay on the front end? 

 Permissions/settings for writing notes → Ask Stephanie 

 How does NAMI currently use the iCarol notes feature? → UXR to uncover 

 9 Accounts for each user 
 HIGH Red 
 What permissions/settings does NAMI need? → Stephanie would prefer the levels like In iCarol, there's levels to permissions 
 Admin 
 Can determine roles

 Can edit a resource

 Shift Leads 
 Can edit a resource

 Viewer 
 Cannot edit

 User stories
 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to search for resources in a given zip code.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to search for resources by name.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to see what resources are in a category.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to see what resources have the tag I selected.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to write notes about a resource.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to share a resource's information via SMS or email.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to see what resources are in a shared list.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to create a list.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to share a list.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to save a resource to a list I've been given edit access to. 

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to save a resource to "My Favorites" list.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to see what lists I have created, edited, have shared with me, or saved.

 As a NAMI volunteer, I want to reference the resources that I referred to my clients.

 As a Shift Lead or Admin, I want to give editing permissions to a list I've created.

 As a Shift Lead or Admin, I want to edit a resource page. 

 As an Admin, I want to add, edit, or delete a team member. 

 An Admin or Shift Lead will be able to do the same things as a NAMI volunteer user.
 User interaction and design

 Reporting and dashboards

 Direct connection to a resource (requires resource's email address)

 Language options (EN, ES, etc.)

title: OC Links Feature: Directions + Locations
ancestors: OC Links Navigator ‚Äì Master Project Document
content:
User Story: Get Location
 As an author, I want to request the location of client of mobile app and save it. 
 note Can work as a function {_getlocation} where function calls request to browser and returns location if available. Can use like {my.last_location = _getlocations} for example.

 Can work as a function {_getlocation} where function calls request to browser and returns location if available. Can use like {my.last_location = _getlocations} for example.

 Considerations:
 Think through how to handle cases where location not available and/or access denied

 Do we inform the frontend that access was denied and then be able to handle that situation gracefully?

 Can integrate into the GUI in "Save Data" modal as a shortcut function. On the dropdown where you select what field to save in frontend to backend, we have ability to add these shortcuts and can display it as "Client's current location" (so that author doesn't need to use the expression above directly).

 User Story: Address Autocomplete
 As a client, I want to see auto-suggested addresses as i type. As an author, i want to save the address, along with lat/long coordinates. 
 note There are three ways to handle saving address data. First, we can save plain text in a "Text" type field in tables. Second, we can save as plain text but also include lat/long coordinates in json-style formatting and handle the display of that data gracefully if author wants to just show address for exmaple. Or three (prob best way), we can create a new field for tables if needed called "address" type. This would enable us to automatically call a function to get long/lat on save entry to this field. We could also then build in a function to split different things about the address as we do for other fields. For example, we could do things like
 {my.address} <returns regular address>

 {my.address.coordinates} <returns lat/long coordinates>

 There are three ways to handle saving address data. First, we can save plain text in a "Text" type field in tables. Second, we can save as plain text but also include lat/long coordinates in json-style formatting and handle the display of that data gracefully if author wants to just show address for exmaple. Or three (prob best way), we can create a new field for tables if needed called "address" type. This would enable us to automatically call a function to get long/lat on save entry to this field. We could also then build in a function to split different things about the address as we do for other fields. For example, we could do things like
 {my.address} <returns regular address>

 {my.address.coordinates} <returns lat/long coordinates>

 Considerations:
 Think through what service to use for autocomplete, google maps vs apple vs other

 Does autocomplete service use Chorus' company token or client's token. Or maybe clients token after certain number of requests?

 What are the cost implications for using this service from mapping provider?

 If address not found, need to make sure that custom address can be entered (also what about suite numbers etc do those mess this up?)

 User Story: Get Travel Times
 As an author, i want to display the travel time between two addresses. 
 note Could create a function like {_gettraveltime(address1, address2, options} whcih would call an API service like google maps to return the trvel time in minutes. Or also {_gettraveltime(_getlocation, address2). Depending on options in API, those can be exposed in options parameter for example things like travel mode, toll rods ok, etc. This function can be exposed through the GUI so the {} function is not needed to be called by an author depending on where it is used. Would just need an input for the two addresses and then settings for options if available.

 Could create a function like {_gettraveltime(address1, address2, options} whcih would call an API service like google maps to return the trvel time in minutes. Or also {_gettraveltime(_getlocation, address2). Depending on options in API, those can be exposed in options parameter for example things like travel mode, toll rods ok, etc. This function can be exposed through the GUI so the {} function is not needed to be called by an author depending on where it is used. Would just need an input for the two addresses and then settings for options if available.

 Considerations:
 Does this service use Chorus' company token or client's token. Or maybe clients token after certain number of requests?

 What are the cost implications for using this service from mapping provider?

 What are the pros/cons of allowing raw addresses vs requiring lat/long coordinates?

 User Story: Mapping Component
 As an author, I want to add a map to a mobile page and populate it with markers from a table 
 note We have basic version implemented in code now, simplest would be a GUI wrapper to this code so author doesn't need to know the code to type. Basic things include center point, zoom level and table containing the items to plot. Will have to think through options for marker image. Also, what about if user clicks on marker, does it go directly to a page (similar functionality as "List View" feature currently implemented) or does it show a tool tip style box with info on what the marker represents and a button there for the user to click to go to that detail page if needed. Generally, it can function the same as List View and Forms List to handle saving what item was clicked and exposing it on the next page for example. All that functionality already exists.

 We have basic version implemented in code now, simplest would be a GUI wrapper to this code so author doesn't need to know the code to type. Basic things include center point, zoom level and table containing the items to plot. Will have to think through options for marker image. Also, what about if user clicks on marker, does it go directly to a page (similar functionality as "List View" feature currently implemented) or does it show a tool tip style box with info on what the marker represents and a button there for the user to click to go to that detail page if needed. Generally, it can function the same as List View and Forms List to handle saving what item was clicked and exposing it on the next page for example. All that functionality already exists.

Considerations:
 Need to handle cases where lots of records returned to map - do we limit, do we group, do we display all, etc.

 What service provider do we use, pros/cons?

 Does this service use Chorus' company token or client's token. Or maybe clients token after certain number of requests?

 What are the cost implications for using this service from mapping provider?

 What are the pros/cons of allowing raw addresses vs requiring lat/long coordinates?

 References
 https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_khetTR4=/ 
 https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation

title: NAMI Warmline Research Plan, User Questions & Discussion Guide
content:
What is NAMI Warmline? 
The NAMI WarmLine is a free and confidential telephone service providing emotional support and resources to Orange County residents 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
 NAMI Website 

 Methodology 
 Phase 1: Foundational interviews 
Week of May 31st
 >4-5 participants 
 >Goal: Benchmark current satisfaction with finding resources in iCarol
 >Foundational questions regarding day-to-day tasks, such as finding resources 
 >Informational architecture testing via a card-sort activity
 Phase 2: Concept Interviews 
Week of June 7th 
 >6-7 participants 
 >Goal: Benchmark current satisfaction with finding resources in iCarol
 >Dashboard view - Establish 
 >Concept tests for updated features, including:
 >Resources organized by categories & subcategories with descriptive information and eligibility criteria
 >Lists
 >Sharing 
 >Filters
 >Search function

 Research Goals 
1. Understand who users are, and what their needs are when it comes to navigating to and sharing resources. 
 2. Discover how users approach resource organization. Identify areas where the OC Navigator can improve on current processes related to resource listings such as sharing resources internally and with Warmline clients. 
 3. Concept test other known features on the product roadmap (filters, resource cards, lists, sharing, and search) to determine usability. 
 Questions for Stakeholders
 Reference this page for initial questions with stakeholders , for meeting 
 # 
 Question 
 Details 

 1.
 Who will use this and how? 
 What is the organizational structure? 
 Four supervisors - who is the lead? 

 Volunteers - do they all same level of access?

 2.
 What are their top tasks? 
 How do they prioritize these tasks? 
 Both management-wise, and for their reports.

 3.
 How is success measured in these tasks? 

 4.
 How will success be measured for this project?

 Section D: iCarol Benchmarking 
 What would you change about iCarol's current system of client resources? What would you keep? 

 Section D: iCarol Benchmarking and OC Nav Satisfaction Measurement 

 Weekly Survey Questions [Archive] 
 Please rate finding resources on iCarol on a scale of 1 - 5, where 1 is 'very difficult' and 5 is 'very easy'. 

 Please rate sharing resources on iCarol on a scale of 1 - 5, where 1 is 'very difficult' and 5 is 'very easy'. 

 On a scale of 1 - 5, where in 1 is 'very unsatisfied' and 5 is 'very satisfied' how satisfied are you with iCarol's current system of resource listing and navigation? 

 Hard-metric: how many times did they reach out to Eeman for resource assistance? 

 How many cases occurred in a week? How many needed resource help? 

 Would you recommend OC Navigator to a friend or colleague? 

 Phase 2: Concept Testing, Lists, Resource Cards and Organization [WIP] Phase-2-Concept-Testing,-NAMI 

 Research Objectives (Priortize) 
 1. Understand the use cases for how and why they would use a list , as well as test usability for each concept , and see how different approaches to List-making perform with users.
 Learn what paper materials akin to a list they might have - ex: binder, sheet of paper, notes. 
 If they have this, can they show us?

 Validate terminology. 
 "Follow" v. "Save"

 "List" v. "Collection" 

 Types of list: process-focused (e.g. step 1, step 2) - geographic specific, program-centered, etc. What types of list (mental or on paper / digital) do they reference when making a referral?

 Attaching documents to resources? Is this useful? 

 2. Understand if users are comfortable with replacing: 
 FAQ Section with Lists 
 Subcategories with Lists
 Lists as parts of lists - what building blocks could surface at the list-level? At the search level? 
 3. Learn what kinds of content they would wish to discover . 
 How best can we help other staff members discover new resources + lists? 
 Use Cases: Disaster specific resources, pinned resources, etc. 

 How does this inform what sorts of list they'd wish to see? E.g., most popular, recently viewed, etc. 

 4. Note-taking: private notes: what are they currently doing at this level (digitally and analogue)? At the resource and list-level. 
 Potentially Out of Scope Goals: 
 4. Validate hypothesis that current design concepts of resource navigation can support mentors' tasks of finding a resource for clients.
 5. Landing Page - after login, where should they end up? Dashboard v. OC Resource Navigator Landpage. NAMI will always be gated by login. 
 NAMI specific : is there a need for a Landing Page? 

 6. Understand what content they'd want to see on the 'Dashboard' v. 'Resources' pages. 
 In the 'Dashboard', what is more helpful to see - a list of most commonly used resources, or resources that have been referred most recently by the logged in staff member? 
 Understanding how they'd ideally track referrals from prior calls, reporting, etc. 

 Concept Testing - Discussion Guide, Phase 2 
 Part 1: Foundational questions / List-making 
 What personal lists of resources do you refer to, if any? Where are they currently stored?
 Do you make any mental lists of resources? 
 Prompt if needed: E.g., when I know someone needs a certain type of service in a particular area, I know these resources exist and think through them before deciding on an appropriate service. 

 What uses might you have for creating a list?

 In a given day, how many resources do you typically navigate between / view / refer in iCarol or other sites? 

 Currently in your workflow, when do you login to iCarol? Do you find yourself logging in at the beginning of the day or when you need to find a resource? 

 Do you track referrals in a call-by-call basis or do you update this at the end of the day?

 Part 2: Concept Test - Dashboard 
 Now I will show you some designs, they aren't set in stone, etc etc. 
 Please go ahead and walk me through what you're seeing on this page. 

 What does Latest Updates mean to you - how do you envision this could be used by the NAMI team?

 Part 3: Concept Test A - Lists Page and List Creation 
 Walk me through what you're seeing here on this page. 
 How many resources would you expect to see in this 'List'? 

 What does 'Attachments' mean to you - is this relevant for your usage of a tool like thisWhat sort of forms do you usually work with? 

 How often do you refer to a map view, if at all when referring resources? How often do you work with resources where location is irrelevant (e.g. a digital only resource) 

 Are these tags below the map view useful for you? How would you imagine using them?

 What do those icons in the side of each card in this list indicate to you? Do you ever search by category when looking for resources currently? When might you do that v. search or other ways to find a resource? 

 Teleheatlth 

 What information would be helpful to see in each resource card of this list? 

 Please take me through what each of these boxes at the bottom of the screen indicate to you? When might you use each of these three text input boxes? 

 Do you ever take private notes, either on paper or digitally? When might you do that v. sharing a public comment on something?

 Do you ever suggest changes to current resource listings - have you ever wanted to do that? What changes might you want to make? 

 Concept Test B: Click here for alternate view. 
 Now I'm going to show you a similar page that also is how you might look at a 'List' of Resources. 
 What are your initial thoughts about this concept compared to the page you just saw? 

 Walk me through what each of these subheadings mean to you - how might you envision using each of these (e.g. Files, Notes, etc) 

 Prompt about map. 

 Wrap-up 
 I'll go through and click Concept Test A. 
 Show me how you would 'Save' a list. Why might you do that? 

 2. Now let's say you wanted to look at a Resources only page. How does this differ from the landing page with the Clouds? Do you prefer on over the other?

 Project Background
 The Chorus Engagement Team has conducted research with several groups that would comprise the user groups for the OC Navigator. For reference on who Chorus has spoken with, please see:

 Chorus has invited the team to visit Wellness Center of Orange County . This provides our team an opportunity to speak directly with our users.

 Chorus has already gathered a wealth of knowledge through speaking with the providers and healthcare groups. This opportunity provides UX/UI a better chance to learn more about the direct users/in-crisis archetype. 
 Methodology & Recruitment Criteria
 Phase 1: Foundational Interviews with n = 4 NAMI Staff

 Gain a better understanding of who the "In-crisis" archetypes users are, and the context of which they would be using our website.

 Notes/Questions
 Meeting
 For the group of "Those in crisis," Chorus already had 1 group. These users mentioned they don't need it, they didn't see the need for it. Went off topic a lot.

 Family & support system will help them use it often.

 Range of function, depending on state and time.

 Ideal = speaking with someone who has experience with a situation, either directly or indirectly. Not the actual 'in-crisis' person.

 Recommendations
 2-3 interviews, 3-4 hours max, prescheduled. Pilot very simple activities. 

 Figure out protocol for emergencies with Wellness Center

 Bowen offered to give Brendan + Courtney 2x 45m training

title: NAMI Warmline Pilot Master Project Doc
content:
Unmet needs 
 Why are we doing this? What does the user expect to accomplish that they can't? Why is it important that we fix it for them? 
 A more user-friendly resource portal

 Ability to locate appropriate resources faster

 Easy way to share resources via email or text 

 Objectives
 What do we want to accomplish with this project? 
 Build a resource portal to help users find, search for, and share resources to their callers and texters

 Refine features to prepare for the fall public launch

 User personas
 https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lQWnBDw=/ → Working NAMI proto-persona 
 Jobs we want to cover
 Easily and efficiently find and connect a relevant resource for a client.

 Help the client with their problems as they evolve by connecting to multiple resources as needed.

 Keep track of which resources were referred to, how often, and to whom.

 Keep resources up-to-date with latest information for fellow NAMI mentors.

 Some history
 NAMI Website 
 NAMI OC is a county-contracted agency that provides mental health related services to mental health service users and their family members. NAMI Warmline 24/7 is a warm-line staffed by volunteers going through recovery, called peers or mentors, who help connect callers or texters to local or national resources. 
 Chorus is partnering with NAMI in a two-part project:
 OC Navigator pilot, to understand and address their needs around resources 

 NAMI case management system similar to OC Links, to understand and address their needs around scheduling, message boards, and case management

 They receive 8,000 calls per month. Unclear how many of those calls refer to a resource.
 As of 2019, they had 22 staff + 125 volunteers
 Constraints 
 Working with features existing on Chorus platform June 2021.
 Explorations + Decisions

title: OC Navigator Competitive Analysis
content:
Dovetail Repo
 Find here all of the competitive benchmarking research done on OC Navigator
 Content Moderation | Key Takeaways
 Dovetail link 
 Findings
 The most flexible resource content moderation model surveilled was One Degree and Aunt Bertha, which operated by:
 Have an internal data QA team

 Have organizations update resources as needed

 Provide ability for users to suggest edits, but need to be reviewed before publishing

 Emerging theme around the big tech companies is that they are leaning towards more and more oversight. Section 230 reform is gaining clout, and looms on the horizon. This will likely impact many tech companies by creating more liability for them. What those liabilities will be, we will need to look out for.

 Recommendations
 Enable analytics on the website to learn about behavior patterns. This will help to inform decisions about edit permissions and how resources are referred to.

 Provide incentives for organizations to keep their information up-to-date. Competitor examples include:
 Increased traffic

 Data analytics

 Explore the content moderation model of One Degree and Aunt Bertha, to give the most increased changes of updates, while QA'ing for data integrity.

 Explore mobilizing a volunteer workforce to check and update resources

 Notify admin user of Navigator when a resource hasn't been updated in a given time period, ex. 6 months or 12 months since last update

 Lists + Favoriting | Key Takeaways
 Dovetail link 
 Recurring Themes
 Ready-made public lists appeared as a secondary or tertiary pathways to find content lists. 
 Search, recommendation engine, or categories/filters are more often featured as the primary starting point to finding list pages. 

 When a competitor had a ready-made public lists, they were community-generated. 
 E-Commerce competitors utilize a merchandised-display page if curating their own set of items to browse through.

 When searching for a list of things in a given location, competitors often display a list alongside a map , for desktop.
 On mobile, user can toggle between the two views, with list view being the default

 The permissions of the list, or deciding whether to be a publicly available list, truly depends on the user's context . With our direct competitors, almost all defaulted to a private sharing setting.

 Recommendations
 Conduct UXR to further understand the user journey of utilizing a resource website to identify the appropriate point to introduce a curated resource list. 

 Similar to how eCommerce merchandises content for the occasion, we can explore design ideas for a curated resource list that would provide the appropriate balm for the emotional experience* of the user.
 Use UXR to further dive into identified user groups to better understand the details and nuances of their journeys (e.g. finding resources for immigration help v. childcare), and identify stress cases. 

 Design Next Steps
 Decide on when to utilize community-generated lists v. curated lists

 Determine who and when can create a public-facing list

 Parse down a list preview UI to essential information only

title: Findings: NAMI Foundational Interviews - Phase 1
content:
Author 

 Research Goal, Phase 1: Foundational Interviews 
 Explore user needs surrounding the resource navigator tool, list-making, and other priorities features. 

 Identify possibilities and limitations in how our current tool can embed in the day-to-day of NAMI Warmline callers. 

 Inform pilot structuring for the live-site, including research format and what features to include

 Discover future needs that could be expanded on in latter phases 

 Research Methodology, Phase 1 
User interviews conducted Thursday, May 27th → Thursday, June 3rd. 
 An initial focus group with HCA CSU leadership occurred on Tuesday May 25th, followed by four 1:1 interviews with NAMI Warmline with varying roles and shifts (daytime v. night), tech-savviness, and tenure to gather diverse opinions on functionality of the bed board. 
 Additional research will be structured as such: 
 Phase 2: Week of June 7th: Concept testing via Figma/in-production site via Zoom 
 Additionally: IA testing will be nixed due to time constraints, categories will be worked on with the NAMI Resource Specialist in June 7th workshop. 
 Phase 3: The possibility of a site visit is being explored to observe NAMI callers in-office, pending end of COVID-19 stay-at-home orders for NAMI. 
 Key Findings 
 Miro board : detailed notes from each user interview, as well as the discussion guide. 
 Link to Zoom interview recordings (Note: Participant 3 could only conduct interview over phone, no Zoom recording available) 
 ‚ö†Ô∏è Potential Blockers 
 Adoption of a resource-only pilot tool will be limited. Because they need to search the resource in iCarol for gathering metrics and attaching to their call-log, we cannot reasonably expect adoption to be high. Implications for this should inform pilot structure, wherein we test with a small group of dedicated testers and limit them to 'having' to use OC Navigator for a resource for at least 3 calls a day. 
 üîé Search is important, and ideally Search pulls from keywords, resource name, and location. 
Search is still something Chorus doesn't do particularly well, and NAMI Warmline staff (specifically more tenured individuals) want to be able to search for specific resources when possible, as opposed to scanning a Favorites list or navigating through categories. 
 Search concepts should include the ability to search by zipcode and keyword/resource name, with the ability to assign a Category either at the search level or to filter results after search is conducted. 
 ‚úÖ Opportunities 
Current satisfaction with iCarol is low, specifically with regards to: 
 Ease of use of finding resources including: 
 Poor search capabilities

 Confusingly formatted categories / subcategories 

 A vertically-formatted list of 'favorite / most popular' resources that requires a lot of scrolling from the user. 

 Ease of use for sharing resources including: 
 No possible way to link a specific resource, either internally or to callers 

 No quick way to copy/paste information from that resource to email for sending to callers or other internal staff

 Out-of-scope for pilot but received very positively by NAMI staff: Twilio integration to send resource information via text to callers. 
Note: Currently, NAMI staff will read out resource information over the phone, which allows room for error when the caller is taking note of the information, as well as takes more time. 

 Chat - outside of scope for initial work with NAMI, but iCarol chat is broken and a buggy. Some users avoid it all together out of fear of losing messages. 

 Dashboard: Users reported general dissatisfaction with design elements and choices, saying that iCarol felt cluttered and ill-organized. A simplified dashboard view - without multiple vertical columns and extraneous information - including Categories, Search, and Favorites should be concept tested in Phase 2 of research. 

 Additionally, list-making was received positively, Warmline staff when prompted could envision: 
 Creating their own list of personal resource Favorites

 Viewing lists of known subject-matter specialists at the company. 
Sample: "Susan is an expert on our team in resources in Orange County for LGBTQ support, so she created a list to share with the team" 

 Creating lists based on a series of multiple steps a caller must go through to receive support for a specific need: e.g. 1) Go to Social Security Office 2) Go to DMV, etc.

title: Mienah Convo ‚Äì Helper Archetype
content:
Date

 Participants

 Mienah Sharif

 Notes
 Intro
 Mienah has both professional and personal experience of navigating and finding wellness resources, while considering the confines of SDoH. 

 She falls under the "Sister" persona.

 A huge barrier of connecting someone with severe mental health needs is its ties to the criminal justice system. Ex: calling a certain resource will automatically bring the police with them.
 This has caused people to turn away from seeking help, due to lack of trust

 When going on a website, generally:
 Testimonials are crucial. "Helpful to humanize the experience."

 Would rather see a real person than a cartoon.

 Concept A 
 Guides section ‚Äì "Experts" in title would turn people off.

 Likes the way categories are organized

 SDoH should go up higher. Very important as people might be unable to recognize they need help. We need to be able to reach that person.

 Dropdown copy options could be clearer (doesn't explain where you're going)

 Concept B 
 Prefers this to A
 A is more aesthetically pleasing, but likes that B is more explicit in actions

 Was unclear on what "search by name" meant ‚Äì suggested that the dropdown could go here

 Wellness Check-in: can be improved by adding "Brief"

 Concept C 
 Looks too advanced to her

 Subcategories are buried. She likes how in A and B there are a few examples of what is under a category.

 Need for simplicity and clarity:
 "I'm trying to think of when I was in crisis mode. People are tired, scared, frazzled. The worst thing is that you're going to be misled."

 Experience of finding resources
 She is very familiar with looking for help online, as she helped her family when she was abroad.

 She found a lot of websites were stale

 One particularly bad one was a long list of links that were expired, no way to filter

 When we asked about good websites v. bad: "I just remember the ones that were really bad. We looked them up last summer, and I was shocked that those websites still exist."
 ex: 211 is overwhelming

 Liked having settings/filters - refine by zipcode helpful, set a 15 mi radius.
 "Is this for a pregnant woman? The elderly? Youth? You start to lose hope as you scroll down the page, as you've wasted all this time ."

 "All you can do is rely on hope." A lot of the websites felt cold and detached, isolating. Defined a great need for refining, by zipcode or eligibility.
 " Some of these websites are vomiting up a bunch of links ."

 Overall notes
 Don't make people scroll on the page

title: Findings: Homepage Concept Tests
content:
Author 

 Prototypes Tested: https://www.figma.com/file/3g8d5sWZqHMeJafwd798Gu/OC-Navigator 
 For broader context surrounding these interviews and the OC Nav launch, see here: 
 Research Goal, Phase 2.1: Homepage Concept Test 
 Understand + prioritize what users want to see on home. 

 Gather sentiment surrounding various concepts approach to tone / color. 

 Gauge understanding of various CTAs, including SDoH, OC Links chat, and 'Get Help Now' 

 Gather ideas for future Guides, as well as understand needs from OC residents on commonly used resources 

 Discover future needs that could be expanded on in latter phases

 Research Methodology, Phase 1 
User interviews conducted Wednesday, June 31st - Friday, July 2nd 
 An initial focus group with a stakeholder workgroup leadership occurred on Friday, June 24th. This was followed by n = 5 interviews with 
 Participant Criteria 
 Must have used, or attempted to find on the web, CBOs / nonprofit / government resources. 

 Mix of people who attempted to locate services for themselves v. family/friends

 Mix of age 

 Household income < 60k

 Must live in Orange County 

 Key Findings 
 Notes: 
 Link to Zoom interview recordings (Pending) 
 ‚ö†Ô∏è Potential Blockers 
 Get Help v. OC Links is being misunderstood by some users. 
Both CTAs are to some users reading like 'I need IT help with this page' 

Consider 'Get Help Now' copy and ways to rephrase, 

 Wellness Check-In: not reading for some users, particularly with users with health concerns. Instead, they are interpreting it as a diagnostic tool for medical issues.

Consider copy that makes this more directional as a CTA 'Not sure where to start' rather than using term 'Wellness Check In' 

 Page Structure Results:

title: OC Navigator Taxonomy and Tagging
content:
Related Artifacts 
 Resource Spreadsheet 

 Guide / List Vetting 

 Data Architecture (Figma) 

 About 
 Our taxonomy will use a horizontal approach to tagging. Rather than implementing a rigid hierarchy, tags will be applied broadly to reduce the chance of miscategorization. 
 It is important to note that categories are also tags, but serve to group other tags into areas that target a specific audience or help with a specific subject matter. 
 Tags as Types 
 In order to facilitate better resource filtering, search, and cross-language site capabilities, tags types are required in the taxonomy. 
 Categorical Tags (displayed as icon in card)

 Service Tags
 e.g: warmline, counseling, prevention, housing 

 Languages 

 Population-specific 
 e.g: OC Residents, LGBT, HIV, Youth, Elderly 

 Cost (Fee Structure)
 e.g: Free | Sliding | Unknown | Medi-cal | MediMedi | 

 Presence
 e.g: In-person, remote

 Meta-tags (non-displayed to end-user) 
 e.g date source: OC Links, NAMI, other 

 Categorical Tags 
 This will appear on the homepage, as well as accompany resources with an icon specific to each categorical tag they belong to. Additionally, category-specific pages will contain resources with that primary categorical tag after the homepage click-thru. Our current categorical tags are: 
 Mental Wellness

 Housing

 Substance Use (tentative) 

 Medical

 Immigration 

 Money 

 Food

 Legal

 Getting Around 

 Family Violence 

 Tag Formatting 
 Tags are nouns and adjectives. Noun tags are singular. Tags can be applied in conjunction with multiple of the 'categorical tags', so there is no strict hierarchy. 
 Tags As Search 
 Tags will serve the dual-function of being keywords that surface relevant results based on user-search. However, due to the nature of natural language, non-visible tags should be added (or some other workaround) to match the way people may search for resources, e.g. pluralized terms, verbs, etc. 
 Implementation Checklist 
 From 7/9 Checklist

 1 
 complete 
 Create Tag Types 

 4 
 incomplete 
 Organize current data into tag types 

 2 
 incomplete 
 Assign Resources to Multiple Categories 

 3 
 incomplete 

 References 
 OC Workshop Day 1: Category Tags 
 1degree Social Service Data Standards 
 Tags

 Properties

title: OC Navigator: Copy Tests via Maze
Analytics to track for MVP Soft Launch
content:
2 flat pipe Overview
 For MVP launch, if we can utilize analytics, here is a running list of things we'd like to keep track of.
 We will be using Google Analytics , and potentially Chorus' own analytics system.
 How will analytics help us?
 User Experience Goals 

 Unmet needs 
 Users want to understand their needs.

 Users want to understand the needs of a friend/family member.

 Users want to understand how to best support their friends/family member in need.

 Users want to find and access local resources with up-to-date information.

 Users want to feel more connected to their providers.

 Objectives 
 Decrease gaps in service

 Increase continuity of care

 Normalize seeking mental health services

 Raise awareness of local services

 Analytics Goals 

 Discover Opportunities 
 Find problems and maximize return on UX effort

 User & Path Analysis 
 Understand user types, usage contexts, and behavior sequences

 Outcome Measurement 
 Systematically evaluate design results

 Experimentation 
 Past MVP-launch, we can compare design alternatives for iterative improvements

 note Analytic Type Definitions
 Places: How many times was a page or screen visited?

 Actions: What UI elements did users interact with?

 People: Who are the users? How do they behave over time?

 Paths: How are different pages, actions, and behaviors related to the user journey?

 Analytic Type Definitions
 Places: How many times was a page or screen visited?

 Actions: What UI elements did users interact with?

 Synthesis of UXR 
 Ways to synthesize our learnings User journey map to show the experience of finding resources , to go past the existing user journey map , and get more in depth about what they're currently doing online and elsewhere.

 Map out a new journey map to show the experience of someone helping someone else. 

 Identify the stress cases as user scenarios of what users could be going through. 

 After these learnings, we could assemble as a group to conduct a "context and outputs" workshop . Could be great to do with stakeholders or in a work group.

 Analytics 
 Ideas of what to track in OC Navigator: Analytics to track for MVP Soft Launch

 Google Analytics 
 Armen mentioned we can use this. Unclear on what state this is in.

 Chorus Data 
 Identify what we can learn, and how to best pull the data.

 Participatory Design Idea 
 Could host a "design jam" where members in the community do a Co-creation workshop. This activity could be a fun way to engage the community.

 Timeline: probably at least 2 weeks to prep, and 1 week after event to synthesize findings.

content:

 OC Links

 Technical writers

 QA

 Objectives
 OC Links needs to use their Chorus platform to dispatch Outreach and Engagement (O&E) cases.
 The O&E department assist people in the Orange County community experiencing homelessness by linking them to services. These services can encompass mental health, substance use, housing, transportation, and more. O&E case workers have specialties of expertise, as well as cities they serve, languages spoken, and more; there is even a registered nurse who works as an O&E worker. Their cases can take several weeks or even months to close.

 Explorations + Decisions

 Impact
 This project will help OCHCA by more easily dispatching O&E cases, and tracking them. 

 Other documents
 https://www.ochealthinfo.com/bhs/about/nit/oclinks/ 

 Tim Interview 3/12, he lightly speaks to O&E: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1H8yLyWkoJI1ToV3DjB3CiVYKp13FNwvuRPMPe7JYP4E/edit 
 O&E 
 goes out there for the individual, on their own incentive. They do it without police. They may or may not work with CAT, but unsure of frequency. 

 O&E is in OC Links' division. 

 "Not there to poke the bear." 

 https://www.ochealthinfo.com/page/outreach-and-engagement-services 

 Assumptions
 List any assumptions you have about your users, technical constraints, or business goals (e.g., Most users will access this feature from a tablet) 
 The O&E workers work in a very similar way to CAT clinicians, and are similar personas. 
 Difference between CAT and OE
 Cat clinicians are rotated

 OE: really need someone who knows how each person being served and the appropriate person for them. Needs more of a decision to know who to dispatch.
 OE: may not have an outcome for 3 months. Status could be progressing for awhile. 

 Want to be able to close a case, but also reopen if that person shows up again. 

 OE is judged by referral and linkage data. Referral and linkage data is not going to be in Chorus. It'll stay in Access. So they just need the dispatch portion. 

 Jennifer would like to see some closure of the loop. When case is closed in spreadsheet, Jennifer wants to input a note in case should they call again. 

 So the OC Navigator can see the outcome and who the OE staff person is.

 O&E works will have county-issued iPhones and laptops. 
 Confirmed yes.

 Open Questions
 Question 
 Answer 
 Date Answered 

 To confirm, who will be using this new expansion? OC Links Navigator + O&E worker? Their manager?
 OC Links Navigators will dispatch, and send to O&E OD. O&E Managers would also like to view reports. 
 As for O&E workers themselves, we will learn more the week of when we speak with them.

 What are the top tasks of O&E worker? As they currently do their work. 
 How are they currently dispatched? 

 Who are they helping exactly?

 Goal: link them to services and ID barriers involved to linking them to services (could include housing, transportation)
 Overall goal: link them to behavioral health services. 

 Can serve anyone in OC at any age experiencing homelessness

 OC links takes call. Then sends a dispatch form to O&E OD*. If determined to be an O&E case, then the case gets assigned to a clinician. 
 After assigned, the clinician has 3 business days to contact the individual and trying to engage them. Clinicians do progressive O&E until we can open a case for unenrolled services, or unable to locate or flat out refuse after several tries. 
 O&E cases might not have an outcome for months.
 Refer to chart Tim created. 
 *OD: Officer of the Day/ triage clinician - person assigned to answering calls for the day

 What are the top tasks of O&E's manager(s)?
 Reporting on number of cases, number primarily. Also looking at area, and rate of successful linkage to resources. 

 If closes out, managers update their spreadsheet (track who case is assigned to and what the outcome is). They will try to find out if the person was linked to a program.

 How will this project help contribute to the goals of OCHCA?
 Hopefully reduce number of cases.

 Is there any existing data on O&E we can reference? 
 Currently there are about 6-9 cases/day. They predict it'll go down to 5 cases.
 At beginning of pandemic, they got around 400-500 calls a month. Now it's gone down to about 300 calls a month.

 What devices are O&E using? Are they also iPhones from the county? Do they also need to do desk work, on a desktop/laptop?
 O&E workers have laptops, and county-issued iPhones.

 Are any additional screener questions required in OC Links? Current question:

 Out of Scope
 List the features discussed which are out of scope or might be revisited in a later release. 
 Additional portal for OE staff in the field similar to CAT clinicians. Their use-case does not seem to necessitate real-time updates since cases can remain open for 3 months.

title: Redirect to static website for ocnavigator.org
content:
The below instructions describe how Chorus hosts (in this case) a static, Webflow-generated website that Chorus hosts on AWS. 
 Overview: Create new elastic load balancer rules to redirect traffic from ocnavigator.org and www.ocnavigator.org on port 443 and 80.
 AWS Account : https://187505007626.signin.aws.amazon.com/console 
 AWS Region : us-west-2
 Static Website domain: https://angels.ocnavigator.org/ 
 Elastic Load Balancer Id: arn:aws:elasticloadbalancing:us-west-2:187505007626:loadbalancer/app/production-chorus/237ef56d95ea43db
 REDIRECT STEPS 
 Open the https://187505007626.signin.aws.amazon.com/console 

 On the navigation pane, choose Load Balancers under Load Balancing .

 Select your load balancer and search for - production-chorus-1092444474.us-west-2.elb.amazonaws.com , and then choose Listeners .

 Choose View/edit rules for the load balancer listener that you want to use.

 Choose - Port 80 perform
 Choose the Add rule icon (the plus sign).

 Choose Insert Rule .

 Choose Add condition .

 In the conditions section ( IF ), choose Add condition .
Choose Host header , and then enter your hostname (for ocnavigator.org and www.ocnavigator.org).
To save, choose the checkmark icon.

 In the actions section ( THEN ), choose Add action .
Choose Redirect to .
Specify the port - 443
Change Original host, path, query to Custom host, path, query .
For Host , enter angels.ocnavigator.org 
For Path and Query , keep the default values (unless your use case requires you to change them).
Set the Response to HTTP 301 "Permanently moved" or HTTP 302 "Found" .
To save, choose the checkmark icon.
The THEN section now appears:
 Redirect to https://angels.ocnavigator.org/ : 443/#{path}?#{query} 

 Status code: HTTP_301 

 Choose Save .

 Go back to listeners and Choose - Port 443 perform
 Choose the edit rule icon (the pen sign).

 Edit the rule number 1 which has Host header , and then enter your hostname (for ocnavigator.org and www.ocnavigator.org ).

 In the actions section ( THEN ), choose Add action .
Choose Redirect to .Change Original host, path, query to Custom host, path, query .
For Host , enter angels.ocnavigator.org . 

 For Path and Query replace to these values Path = /#{path} and Query = #{query}

 Set the Response to HTTP 301 "Permanently moved" or HTTP 302 "Found" .
To save, choose the checkmark icon.
The THEN section now appears:
 Redirect to https://angels.ocnavigator.org/ : 443/#{path}?#{query} 

 Click on Update on top.

 About CARS and Student Mental Health Resources
 The Orange County Health Care Agency (HCA) has partnered with the Center for Applied Research Solutions (CARS) to help educators, school staff, school administrators, coaches, families, and youth find tools and providers to support mental health and wellness for K-12 students. 
 The Student Mental Health Resources directory raises awareness, educates, and empowers educators, school staff, families, youth, and personnel who interact with OC students at every level.
 Business goals
 Add digital resources to the OC Navigator.

title: OC Navigator: Wellness Center West Research November 15th, 2022
content:
JIRA : DES-58 a9d3eb4c-c63a-3c77-864c-b5dd8664a020 System JIRA 

 Background 
The team will be visiting the Orange County Wellness Center in November to better understand from the member & provider their perspective on how OC Navigator can be useful to them. Chorus will lead training on the OC Navigator with users, many of whom are members f the Wellness Center. 

 Guiding Questions 
Are users finding what they need on OC Navigator, and if not, why? 
Is OC Navigator useful for both members and providers in its current form? 

 Research Goals: Members 
 Validate current design approach from a brand and UI perspective. 
 UI: Task completion.
 Search and find a specific resource.

 If you were in a crisis: is it obvious where to find more immediate help?

 Brand sentiment - Do they feel like the site is made for them as an OC Resident? Is it representative of their ethnicity/socioeconomic group/community/gender etc.? 

 First time impression - what do users think when they first land on the site. Does it match with their goals of accessing the site? What is the purpose of the site based on your first impression

 The SDoH tool: What does an effective UX look like for in-app screeners ? Do people find them useful? How does adoption vary between demographics, if at all?

 Capturing the 'uhh' moments: where are users stopping, either confused or otherwise etc etc. Getting the 'why' to inform future design. 

 Research Goals: Providers 
 Validate current design approach from a brand and UI perspective. 
 UI: Task completion.
 Search and find a specific resources on behalf of a consumer 

 The SDoH tool: Is this an effective tool for providers? Do they ever fill it out with members to help them understand where they might help? If not, why?

 Content: is content on the site match up with user needs? Are there happy paths to get to that content? 

 Current User Context: What devices are they using when they interact with OC Navigator? 
 Where/what are they doing while they're using OC Navigator? 

 Methodology 
Prefer to have a combination of the following, time allowing: 
 1:1 user interviews with members

 focus groups with providers 

 shadowing providers as they use OC Navigator in context 

 Discussion Guide: User Interviews, Members 
 Introduction, explanation of test, etc. 
 (~Around 5 min duration) 
 General need-finding 
 (~10 min duration) 
1. Get to know participant, name background, etc.
2. Dig deeper on their screener response 
 Usability Test 
 (~Around 30 min duration) 
 Have them give initial impressions for app.

 complete tasks (search, browse, etc)

 Discussion Guide: Provider Focus Group 
 Introductions, explanation of Chorus and people at OC 
 (~Around 5 min duration) 
 Shadowing Guide: Providers 
 Introduction, explanation of shadowing, etc 
 (~Around 5 min duration)

title: OC Navigator Roadmap Priorities
content:
Who helps determine what we should work on? 
 County stakeholders
 Community co-chairs 
 Community partners
 Feedback from other sources
 How do we determine what to work on?
 #E6FCFF Usability (i.e. user experience; ease of use) - Is this going to enable someone to visit and use the site? Will they find what they're searching for?
 Social impact - Is this going to improve how users are going to find and connect to resources? 
 User engagement - Is this going to increase how many people use the site? 
 Effort - How much effort is this going to take?
 Complexity - How complex is it to implement?
 Who are our top competitors?
 Find Help

 Unite Us 
 One Degree 
 Kaiser 
 WellSky (previously Healthify) 
 AARP 
 Aunt Bertha 
 Roadmap overview

 to look into it, but we're doing the same as Yelp

 About us

 Find resources

 Share feedback

 Languages

 Is the data set ready? Close. Let's make sure we include embed links for videos. Action: to share with Calvin

 We could have a field for Type > App where if it has an "Apple app" or "Android app" there is an input field to add to build tickets

 Add "Type" field to digital resources/resource entry portal Action: to add to tickets

 Mobile designs
 Will work on fly-out menu

 Filters - We can set it to work the same as the hamburger menu (Christy) 

 Can we lock it "Housing Results" + filters? Action: Christy can work on 2 stickies

 Need a search button for mobile. to add 

 Filter results "More filters" 
 Let's ask Brendan to gather some options so it's more intuitive/descriptive. Action: to create ticket

 2/6/23 Design Review 
 Notes
 Category landing page 
 Subcategories 

 Focus populations 

 Let's list subcategories in alpha , but won't be able to do it and mix subcategories with focus populations - Decision - Just using subcategories 

 Digital versus online - Which ones do we want? 

 Create tickets for mobile and desktop - SAs will build desktop first 

 Languages/labels will stay the same as we use now - e.g. languages offered, etc.

 Filter pops up - We can do like what we do for the languages

 Search & Filter - Let's test this out

 Technical questions:
 Are we updating top navigation to lighter version? -Yes, we can update this now. 

 Hover states - do we have this?

 Is map supposed to be edge-to-edge? Yes

 Navigation changes can be in phases - styling, then labels/page titles 

 How may subcategories do we get? 12 in the medical category

 What about for when we don't have any results in each tab? Kris will comp this out. 

 Category descriptions - How can Xuan's team support? 

 Let's revisit subcategories/subtopics - Need or an area which might be a little different.

 Schedule follow up call 

 Send Kris list of subcategories

 15

 complete

 incomplete 
 Kris to work on a tab system ‚Äì double height

 complete

 Can the graphics be randomized on refresh?

 Can we anchor a link? Jump to link + have it autoscroll to results

 Chorus would have to execute a page refresh. 

 Can we keep "Housing Results"? Yes.

 Let's display the categories for each guide. 

 Would folks know how to translate the resources when searching? 

 Christy - Let's mush less into the filter, worried about searching by categories. 

 Xuan 
 Category keywords are already structured. 

 Parent keywords are not subcategories. 

 Resources are going to be tagged w/subcategories; we will add this into the data structure. 

 How do we set this up in a way that makes sense for the filters on the page? 

 UX testing results:
 People liked "services"

 People didn't like "group"

 People did not like "collections" 

 If you had a guide with 300+ digital resources, how would we search it? 
 Four or five filters across topics

 Spread by population 

 Keywords + search bar 

 CARS might need to be its own template 

 We would need to rethink how guides work 

 Questions for SAs: 
 What needs to happen for us to add new subcategories? 

 What needs to happen for us to break out "services," "digital," and "guides" in new filters.
 CARS data will be covered by digital. Anything else we need to think about here?

 What needs to happen to make the new filters Kris added in the image to go to the various sections in "I'm looking for help with"? 

 Can we upload PDFs as a digital resource? Yes. 

 1/27/23 Preliminary User Testing Results
 What worked? 

 People liked version 2 more - the one where things are laid out with them more

 Most people just want to search by category.

 What can improve? 
 They run a search, update the city, none of these are helpful - proximity search will help with this
 New design will discourage people to filter by city 

 Collections - this makes people think of collections coming after them 

 More filters were coming up better - people didn't know that keyword was a filter (layer a magnifying glass) 

 Let's test changing the languages a little bit more - Log in a ticket for UX 
 Languages icon - Do we want to test also having inside the menu? 

 Globe icon is too abstract

 What is the most commonly used icon to denote language change? 

 Data stuff - What needs to go in the backlog from here? 
 Housing - I just want to call a place.

 Medical - a quick filter that makes it super clear. 

 Wellness Check-in - Everyone skipped it (already has a ticket) 
 Take our wellness check -in -Herson style video, explaining what it is. We can redesign. Journey, process, results -

 More humanistic approach? 

 What are you actually looking for

 Collections versus resource guides
 They're lists; maybe down the road we have a how-to; they're all resources, for a demographic

 How do we allow the user to select the type of resources they want? 
 In person versus digital 

 We don't just want to mix up different looking cards 

 Demo
 Could we randomize images in the banner by demographic? - Maybe

 Feedback
 Let's reconsider "my group" 

 We should circle back with the Riley Group on:
 Verbiage

 Subcategoreis 

 Proximity search
 Zip code; Issue for smaller cities, they only have a few; Showing at the zip level 

 Where is this on the Eng roadmap? - Let's add it once it's ready to go. 

 Submit buttons for the header?
 Confusing to have left items and right, but just needs submit CTA 

 Confusing to have two filters (top on banner and left at the bottom) 

 Card sort - Nearest to me would be helpful for community members 

 "My group"
 What about groups that are not specific populations? 

 This could be a sensitive issue 

 Let's gather data/requirements from county 

 We could just surface tags to handle demographics - we just wouldn't label 

 Or add a "for everyone" 

 Mad Libs
 People love this!

 Feedback from the community - People don't like "keyword" 

 People love Online and In-Person, let's comb through the list of "digital" - what are we calling online? Like OC Links 

 Could we add subcategories for the digital resources? (website, apps, etc.) So when people land here, this new filter surfaces. 

 Action items and questions
 Kris to turn this into mobile 

 Steps: Kris to create one more traditional and one mobile > Feasibility review > User testing

 the needs or the topics were different from the categories → some of these were more clinical

 Fill in the details for content - What are the kind of questions do we want to ask? Example: I am looking to reset my password for my new computer. (spans across different topics)

 Guide topics 

 When you're searching at the top, you click a guide

 complete

 Keyword portal 
 Adding/editing a resource

title: OC Navigator Competitors
content:
Questions to consider 
 Do I like this resource?

 Is it user friendly?
 How quickly can I find crisis support? 

 How quickly is it to find self-guided support? 

 What are some helpful features? 

 Do I want to keep using this resource?

 Find Help 
 211 
 Unite Us 
 One Degree 
 Kaiser 

 Description 
 Customers use findhelp (formerly Aunt Bertha) to integrate social care into their systems and make a positive difference in their communities. Its social care network features more than 550,000 program locations verified by findhelp's data operations team.
 2-1-1 Orange County (211OC) links Orange County's most vulnerable with the health and human service resources they need.
 The equity-centered choice
for social care
 One Degree provides services to community-based organizations, healthcare, and government agencies.
 Our partners and clients use One Degree technology to power their social care systems: making informed referrals, enrolling people into resources and benefits, and measuring outcomes.

 Experience summary 
 Some interesting features (collapsable resource details, etc.), and simple to use. Feels like a digital yellow book and boring. 
 Overwhelming and busy. It's hard to focus on one items with so much happening all at once. 
 Colors are user friendly and some of the features are nice (e.g. subcategories that automatically display under the categories). 

 Pros/cons 
 Simple initial page to just search for resources. 
 Additional filters on search results are useful (e.g. Program Filters). 
 Collapsable resource cards. 
 Helpful CTAs (e.g. Next Steps)
 10 primary menu items (categories)
 Not much context initially to know/learn about what it is. 
 Navigating across primary nav items is a bit jolty/jittery. 
 Link farms for some of the primary categories (e.g. Money).
 Category pages don't have have landing pages. 
 No people anywhere; not much imagery beyond the icons. 
 Resource map is on the left; not a common practice. Usually on the right. 
 On category landing page, "Personal Filters" is confusing. 
 More languages
 Data dashboards 
 10 primary menu items
 Very busy/overwhelming homepage with a lot of things to click on 
 Hard to tell what's an image versus a CTA (e.g. 211 chat bubble at the top) 
 Not as easy to find a simple list of resources/categories

title: p1 Incident 4/27/23 OC Links
content:
Postmortem summary
 Postmortem owner 
 Jamie

 Incident 
 OC Links Data Saves issues

 Priority 
 p0 Red / p1 Purple / p2+ 

 Affected services 
 OC Links CM

 note Executive summary
 Around 1:25 PM on 4/27 Support was alerted to the following by OC Links:
 Pages not loading
 CAT dispatches are not being triggered
 CAT dispatch not displaying correct
 Issue found: Saves not happening on Create Case>Details Tab

 Executive summary
 Around 1:25 PM on 4/27 Support was alerted to the following by OC Links:
 Pages not loading
 CAT dispatches are not being triggered
 CAT dispatch not displaying correct
 Issue found: Saves not happening on Create Case>Details Tab

 Postmortem report
 Instructions 
 Report 

 Leadup

 Around 1:25 PM on 4/27 Support was alerted to the following by OC Links:
 Pages not loading
 CAT dispatches are not being triggered
 CAT dispatch not displaying correct

 Fault

Describe how the change that was implemented didn't work as expected. If available, include relevant data visualizations.
 Jamie called in Ashok to look at OC links because Engineering had just pushed a release and we were still in the middle of testing post-release and weren't seeing the same issues as OC Links reports. He recommended hard browser resets and to check back in.
 OC still reported issues. Called in more people to help take a look at OC Links

 Impact

 OC Links staff were unable to use the system. Had to go to paper and pencil because of data save issues. Data on details tab missing
 Support was flooded with emails
 Addie and Xuan had calls from Tim at OC Links

 Detection

 Around 1:25 PM Xuan received a message that the system wasn't working and gave a brief summary
 At the same time, Support emails were coming in
 We spent about 5-10 mins trying to reproduce and were not successful. Jamie asked for assistance from the Entire OC team and starting a meeting 

 Response

 Xuan, Addie, Jamie and Ashok first responded. 
 Jamie and Ashok got on a call to take a look. Ashok was brought in because this was happening at the same time as post-release testing. It was unclear if this was an eng issue or SA issue. We could not reproduce. Ashok gave some ideas. Jamie took 5 mins to test, still receiving reports. Brought in more team members to help reproduce the issues. 

 Recovery

Report how the user impact was mitigated and when the incident was deemed resolved. Describe how the team could've improved time to mitigation.
 We worked as a team to find the source of the issue. We spent about two hours working on source of the issue to resolution.
 We could have improved this process by knowing what changes may have been done to an interaction. At this time, we have to go by peoples word. In an ideal world, we would have a change log to look at or some sort of activity log for interaction changes.

 Timeline

Detail the incident timeline using UTC to standardize for timezones. Include lead-up events, post-impact event, and any decisions or changes made.
 1:25 Users report issues with OC Links
 1:30 testing on our end and we can't see the same issues
 1:35 Jamie and Ashok meet
 1:40 OC Links try's a browser reset- No luck
 1:50 Jamie asks team to jump on a call
 2:01 We decide to roll back Engineering release because we still can't find root cause
 2:25 We find cause and start to work towards a resolution plan
 3:00 Addie alerts OC can start to use system again
 3:15 We are able to put a fix in place and work towards recovering data for OC Links

 Root cause

 We dug deeper on our side and uncovered that we had removed a hidden field around the same time as release (12:40 PM) which was then "unmapped" in the response sets. This "unmapping" caused the response set save to fail. This is the first time we've seen a deleted field and subsequent "unmapping" cause a response set failure

 Backlog check

Review the engineering backlog to find out if there was unplanned work that could've prevented the incident or reduced its impact.
 Is there an eng ticket?
 ttps://chorusapp.atlassian.net/browse/CHORUS-4369 

 Lessons learned

Describe what you learned, what went well, and how you can improve.
 Changes made to prod should never be done without a ticket, testing and notice 
 Should have questioned unmapped response set more thoroughly when it was first noticed.
 Don't work on other things while release is happening. We had no stated guidelines around this previously. This is an area where more process/overhead would be beneficial for us, no matter how minor a change is. 
 Lots of context switching was involved in and around release time. Team will work on protecting SA's time to avoid context switching and keeping focus.
 Solutions team access to Eng release calendar (and vice versa) so that teams can have increased visibility in terms of what changes are being made and when.
 Roll back: We rolled back the engineering release. We should have taken a more time to look at the platform sites app.join and chorusplat.io to see if their release had any effect on those sites first.

 Follow-up tasks

List the Jira issues created to prevent this class of incident in the future. Note who is responsible, when they have to complete the work, and where that work is being tracked.
 h ttps://chorusapp.atlassian.net/browse/CHORUS-4369
