title: O&E Shadowing (Dispatch Team & Field Clinicians)
content:
1 2 false list false Overview 

 Chorus Staff Attending: 
 Time: 8:00am-12:00pm
 Location: 500 City Parkway West, 4th Floor, Orange, CA 92868
 Objectives 
 Shadow administrators and clinicians while they are using Chorus and other systems to understand how data is being entered across tools

 Learn how O&E clinicians receive and send referrals

 What is the attitude around adopting an app to record their work?

 Understand their workflows, focusing on:
 How they are using our tool?
Areas of opportunity (e.g., workarounds, going between pages, taking notes on the side)?
 What do you dislike?

 Areas that are helpful?
 What do you like?

 What should we prioritize improving?

 Important note: this research will only ever be used internally to guide product design only with this product team, we will never share data and will always keep data private
 Agenda 
 Shadow a variety of employees (ideally both Administrators and Clinicians) from 10am-2pm on June 2nd

 Where it is appropriate and not disruptive, ask questions to staff about their workflow and experience using Chorus

 Helpful Tips While Shadowing from Mike Squibb
 Meet with a supervisor or manager, etc as a team first when you arrive
 Introduce yourselves

 Reiterate expectations (how long you'll be there, what you're looking for, etc)

 Get tips on how to participate w/o getting in the way

 Divide and conquer so we can get more data back. I'd have each of you shadow individually, and try to shadow as many as you can. An ideal data set would be 5+ people. If we can shadow 5+ people and observe 10-20 use cases, that would be amazing (not sure how long a 'case' will last, but you get the idea: more is better).

 Ask the person you're shadowing to think out loud (when appropriate) to talk through what they're feeling, what they need, what they dislike, what they like. (as long as it doesn't interfere or diminish the experience/task they're working on). If it's not appropriate to verbalize thinking while with a client, quickly chat for a few mins between client interactions to capture what they were thinking

 Questions 
 Can I see how you typically use Chorus?
 What do you like?

 What do you dislike?

 Should outreach workers have access to case details on mobile if they have not yet accepted the case? This is currently the case in CAT.

 How is UAF survey currently being utilized? How many times is it filled out?

 Is it helpful to see an alarm indication or flag on Dispatch Dashboard after a certain number of attempts?

 Do you think it would be useful to see number of cards on each status?

 How do dispatchers currently determine which Outreach Worker is closest to the participant?

 What Tabs are you using most frequently and least frequently?

 How do you send referrals?
 What information do you send?

 Do you receive confirmation that a referral has been accepted? Linked?

 How do you receive referrals?
 What information do you receive?

 Do you send confirmation that a referral has been accepted? Linked?

 What other systems are you currently entering client data into?
 Where is the information you're entering duplicative?

 Would it be helpful to see client history?

 Any feedback on the statuses or reasons?

 Any additional information that you would like to record in Chorus?
 Any information that you would like to not have to record in Chorus?

 Notes from Mike Squibb: 
 If possible, get together right after the research ends and discuss high level findings while it's all fresh in your mind.

 Synthesize findings asap after (the next day, for example) so you can create a user journey (or journeys) and plot out where there's friction, needs, pain points, wins, etc.

 Findings
 User Journey Map 
 Triage/Dispatch Clinician 
 Outreach/Field Clinician 

 Systems Used 

 Teams Message 
 Coordinating communication among O&E office staff (Supervisors/ Officer of the Day) 

 Incoming requests from OC Links 

 Email 

 HMIS/Clarity 
 Shelter and Housing History 

 Care team allocation 

 IRIS 
 Mental Health history & SUD History 
 clinician will note either or both when making a case for dispatch to alert field staff if they may need to be mindful of safety or other client needs 

 Clinic location if they've previously received mental health services 

 If a client has an existing appointment or missed an appointment 

 Chorus 
 Client management and dispatch 

 May review if there a CAT notes
 could indicate the need for safety measures for outreach clinicians 

 Phone 
 O&E potential clients 

 Google Maps 
 To help a client identify their location and ideal meeting place for the client and their clinician 

 CALSAWS 
 To review a client's benefits (MediCal, EBT, CashAid, Social Security Benefits) 

 Chorus 
 UAF Survey

 Clarity/HMIS 
 Shelter and Housing History 

 Care team allocation 

 Paper and Pen 
 Client case notes 

 Email 

 Phone 

 Pain Points 

 Triage staff shadowed: Monica & Caroline 
 Extremely slow loading page and filtering pages 
 Navigating between O&E tab and Client tab took 15-30 seconds each time 
 Both triage clinicians used paper to supplement the Chorus app to account for slow wait time 
 Would write things onto paper and then transfer it to Chorus app after the call 

 The workflow of the triage worker on the phone less efficient

 Triage worker was losing trust with the system and was losing the trust of the client they were on the phone with because the person on the phone had to wait while the page was loading

 Filtering a page for client or staff details took 60 seconds

 If an existing O&E client case has a clinician assigned to it, the triage clinician is not able to see the staff who was assigned to the case. 
 To find out who was assigned to the case, the triage clinicians must spend additional time sending teams messages to staff and/supervisors asking if anyone knows or remembers what clinician was assigned to a client case

 Because triage staff do not have the ability to see clinicians assigned to client cases they experience the following two problems: 
 Often times O&E clients call from various phone numbers because they do not have consistent phone access. When a client calls in to check on the status of their case, if a triage worker is not able to quickly identify 

 Triage/dispatch clinicians get really busy with phone calls and documenting. Because of this, sometimes and so they chose to enter their call data into Chorus after the call has happened 
 slow loading pages is one of the main reason why staff will enter their call data after the call 

 Triage/Dispatch clinicians don't find the dashboard of Recent Callers list useful for their needs 
 The client page and the O&E tab are their most frequently used paged

 Triage clinicians review how many times a client with an existing Chorus case may have received CAT services, but it is difficult for them to see a quick overview of how many times a client has received CAT services 
 Triage clinicians currently have to scroll through a client's entire case history in the detail tab to look for frequency of service use 

 Sometimes triage clinicians type out an entire client case, then accidentally click away from the screen without clicking safe. Because there is not an autosave feature, they lose all their work 
 This leads them to writing things down on paper and then transferring to Chorus later 

 Triage workers have to log all calls even if the caller is not eligible for O&E services or does not provide a name. Because Chorus requires a name, the triage clinician logs the call by using XXXX XXXXX for first and last name 
 They would like the ability to document that the caller wasn't eligible for services and/or did not provide a name 

 Outreach Staff Shadowed: Ronnie, Tamara
 Geolocation 
 when outreach clinicians refresh a location it doesn't work, and the pin will be the last place the clinician was located

 Even when Geolocation pins a clinician's location, they still have to type out street names which takes additional time and is redundant for their workflow 

 Friction and inefficiencies navigating between Chorus and UAF survey apps 

 Outreach workers do not have a digital space to document client case notes within Chorus 
 Outreach clinicians use a paper referral form in the field to take notes or take notes for the client in an email 

 They have to retype their notes later and share with their supervisor 

 UAF Survey is often flow and freezes 

 Potential Bug: time stamp displayed same time for all the surveys even when they weren't all updated at the same time

 Workflow Overview 

 Workflow Overview 
 Triage clinicians receive clients from one of two sources: 
 800 Number

 OC Links 

 Triage Clinicians manage calls and program communication via the following: 
 OC Links will send a teams message to an O&E Triage clinician asking about client details and if they're able to take a client call 

 Program only serve currently homeless individuals in orange county
 If the call is form a homeless family, the triage clinicians will refer the client to Family Collaborative Solutions or 211
 "Family" is defined as a caretaker with a youth under 18 with them 

 If a call is for someone at risk of homelessness they would refers them to another resource

 Sometime triage clinicians receive calls from clients who have an existing case 
 client are calling to receive a status of their case 

 a clinician will look up a client in HMIS to see if a client has connected with a clinician in the field (allows clinician to see their care team for shelter or housing engagement)

 Sometimes outreach workers run into other clinicians clients while they're in the field and are able to connect with them to get updates, provide resources, and check in

 UAF survey used frequently in the field 
 data collection method

 completed on clinician's iPad

 submitted per client interaction 

 Must be submitted at the location the survey was taken for Geolocation to save their location

 Client engagement documented:
 In UAF survey

 In Clarity if engaging with housing resources 

 notes on paper 

 Common variables documented during clinician and client engagement: 
 shelter, treatment, language, transportation 

 Outreach clinicians link their clients to medical appointments and help them with their paperwork needed for the appointments 

 Outreach clinicians help their clients with connecting with bed resources by putting them on the list for availability 

 Frequent resources Outreach clinicians support clients with: 
 Outreach clinicians provide client's buss passes frequently 
 documented in UAF survey 

 Social services

 Food stamps/EBT

 Mental Health Resources 

 Sobering Station 

 Taxi service for transportation to resources 

 Outreach clinicians have to fill out the name of their co-staff 

 Outreach clinicians complete all client info while they are going through the UAF survey 

 Outreach clinicians close a client case in any of the following: 
 after 3 failed attempts 

 after the contact has been made

 if a client refuses help 

 Housing eligibility 
 eligible for housing if they were homeless for one year

 A letter is required to write a letter to get housing support 

 Som

 Potential Requirements From Shadowing 

 Triage/Dispatch clinician needs the ability to see the following for an existing client record:
 The supervisor who assigned the clinician to the case

 The clinician(s) who have worked with the client

 Triage/Dispatch clinicians need the ability to to backdate a client record (when updating or making a new client case)

 Triage clinicians need the ability to see a quick summary of frequently utilized programs in a client record case history
 e.g. Instead of scrolling through client case history to see how many times a client utilized CAT, they would have a list at the top of the name of programs used and a simple count of how many times the client has used the service 

 Ability to quickly save the client information they enter into Chorus 
 (autosave, or a save button that follows along with them on the screen) 

 The ability to make an appointment with a client's mental health provider with Chorus
 IRIS integration 

 The ability to indicate that a caller did not provide their name
 triage clinicians must log all calls in Chorus even if the caller wasn't eligible for services or didn't provide their name

 The ability or outreach clinicians to search, find, and edit client records for clients they're not directly assigned to 

 The ability for outreach clinicians to quickly and easily make a new client record when they are approached by new clients while they are in the field

 The ability for outreach clinicians to document in Chorus UAF survey " Client was not there" or "Zero Contacts" 
 staff manually entering zeros currently 

 The ability for UAF survey to default zeros; staff can quickly populate only what is relevant for their client 

 The ability for Outreach clinicians to access UAF in O&E mobile app 

 The ability for outreach clinicians to see the status of a client's referrals, the status of the referral, and if the client was linked 

 The ability for outreach clinicians to auto-populate the name of their co-staff 

 The ability for cross stress of an outreach clinician to auto-populate when they are completing the UAF survey 

 The ability to upload a photo or icon to a client's record
 There are existing client photos in HMIS/Clarity 

 The ability for outreach clinicians to view previous O&E clinicians a client has worked with to allow outreach clinicians to connect clients with previous staff and for outreach staff to contact previous clinicians for consultation on the client 

 Questions 

 What are the distinguishing roles/responsibilities if any from the following roles:
 Officer of the Day

 Supervisor

 Admin
 If they're different roles which screens do features within chorus do they use?

 What are their unique workflows within triage and outreach dispatch

Objectives
 Shadow OC Links Navigators while they take calls and serve clients to better understand their workflow and pain points

 Important note: this research will only ever be used internally to guide product design only with this product team, we will never share data and will always keep data private

 Helpful Tips While Shadowing
 Meet with a supervisor or manager, etc as a team first when you arrive
 Introduce yourselves

 Reiterate expectations (how long you'll be there, what you're looking for, etc)

 Get tips on how to participate without getting in the way

 Divide and conquer so we can get more data back. I'd have each of you shadow individually, and try to shadow as many as you can. An ideal data set would be 5+ people. If we can shadow 5+ people and observe 10-20 use cases, that would be amazing (not sure how long a 'case' will last, but you get the idea: more is better).

 Ask the person you're shadowing to think out loud (when appropriate) to talk through what they're feeling, what they need, what they dislike, what they like. (as long as it doesn't interfere or diminish the experience/task they're working on). If it's not appropriate to verbalize thinking while with a client, quickly chat for a few mins between client interactions to capture what they were thinking

 Before shadowing occurs ‚Äì participants are interviewed or involved in group discussions to learn more about their needs.

 During shadowing ‚Äì the shadow works with a commentator who explains what is being observed throughout the study. This is most often used when the shadow is facing a complex situation where a full explanation (or training) has not been available before shadowing commences.

 Chorus Team Members
 Shane Bai - Product Manager

 Todd Lynch - Sr. Product Designer

 Ellie Cho - Sr. Product Designer

 Elena Seward - Customer Support Specialist

 JJ Jessup - Product Manager

 üìù OC Links
 Staff members 
 Tim Sigafoos - Service Chief

 Sandra Duarte - Service Chief

 Maite Sbabo - Service Chief

 Shadowing Questions
 Ask the Navigator what their specialties are. How long have you been working as a Navigator? What is your background?

 Who do you go to when you have questions or need help? 
 Goal is to understand if Navs feel supported in using the OC Links app. 

 Observe their workflow 
 What are your pain points? What are the hopes you have? What are the things that are critical to you that you don't want to lose? 

 What is Navigators' intake process? How does intake differ from case to case, need to need? When we compare notes after shadowing, how might they differ from clinician to clinician? 

 Do you have any specific questions that you would like to add notes to? 

 Observe the workarounds they use to overcome current issues in the app

 What are you trying to accomplish as you utilize each module/tab/page in the app?
 Goal is to understand their larger goals, which can help us develop better solutions 

 Better understand how Navigators are using the OC Links app from call to call; in between calls and among call types.
 What are the types of calls you may get throughout the day?

 What are they clicking exactly? What are they thinking about as they use the app? What emotions surface as they use the app to complete their jobs?
 Observe body language, thumb twiddles, refreshes

 What are Navigators' experience of referring to O&E?

 Better understand how CAT is scheduling appointments for clients

title: OC Categories and Initial Unified Database Planning
content:
‚úÖ Actions

 1 
 incomplete 
 ROM time to re-cat resources + bulk upload and re-link (~4 sprints min?). Sequence out (LOE estimate) 

 üìö Glossary
 Term 
 Definition 

 Categories (Primary and Secondary)
 The set groups of resources and programs defined by OC HCA. 
 OC Navigator currently has two category fields: Primary (a pick-one) and Secondary (a pick-many). Primary Categories are the primary association with the resource, and determine the icon that is shown in the resource in OC Nav. The intent for Secondary Category was to allow for users to see resources that provide many services, despite being primarily associated with one category.

 Service vs Online
 Not extremely important to this conversation, but for reference, OC Navigator distinguishes "Service" and "Online" resources in the following way:
 Service: Resources that involve interaction with the organization, including hospitals, offices, telehealth and even hotlines.

 Online: Resources that are more self-directed, including toolkits, resource directories and articles.

 These are currently mutually exclusive.

 Organization
 Describes the group that provides the resource, ex. School Readiness Tutoring - YMCA .
 The previous process of showing this on OC Navigator was through the title, but we are beginning to start using an "By Organization" field to serve double duty for Services and Online.

 Type (CYBH, AOABH, etc.)
 Currently exists in the OC Links data structure. Describes the funding type (?)

 üîÑ Comparing Data Structure between OC Links/Warmline and OC Navigator

 Volunteer Opportunities

 üå± Progress So Far 
 Resources
 Around late January, I did an audit comparing the OC Links database and the OC Nav resources marked with the OC Links source here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1oxkTsqhIz7vLj1Wa8slXvNFIG71ZD2gvbvxH4gfw-8k/edit#gid=1939607885 
 This document https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fVbSPFk00qRzPWYP6CvM5QdlSIWSTIZKrs4yyTCBxZY/edit was also created in late March with a summary of what I knew at the time.
 Categories
 The lists below are mapping OC Navigator categories to the closest equivalent in the current OC Links list. These may not be final?
 Categories that can just be added (no overlap)
 (nothing) → Law Enforcement

 Categories that can map:
 Family Safety → Domestic Violence 

 Money → Financial Support

 Housing → Housing

 Substance Use → Substance Use Treatment

 Transportation (Getting Around) → Transportation

 Categories that might be able to map, depending on the situation:
 Learning → Education

 Mental Wellness → Mental Health (q: how do Hospitals fit in here?)

 Categories that will require manual review:
 Medical → Hospitals + Medical

 Legal Help → Immigration + Legal

 Multi-Category → ? (big q: what is the definition of this and how often is it used?)

 Basic Needs → ? (q: how does OC Links currently handle this?)

 Kids and Families → ?

 Subcategories
 County is in the process of confirming the list of Mental Wellness and Substance Use subcategories. We haven't revisited the other categories at this point yet.
 Types
 Types currently aren't logged in OC Navigator (apart from in the titles of the resource, ex. Adult and Older Adult Behavioral Health (AOABH) Regional Outpatient Clinic Access Point - Aliso Viejo) so these should be easy to just append onto the dataset.
 Miscellaneous Notes
 Number of active resources in OC Navigator: ~1200

 Number of total resources in OC Links: ~450

 Estimated overlap: ~350?
 Things on Links that wouldn't show up on Nav: closed referral programs, help lines from other CA counties, police departments, etc.

 Chorus variables currently have a limit of 75 columns (+1 for the ID)
 This means that there may be the need for the Unified Database to live in two linked variables (similar to how TFW currently works)

 ü´±üèª‍ü´≤üèΩ Dependencies

title: OC SSO PRD
ancestors: OC SSO App Access Management for Groups, Zones, and Users
content:
Disclaimer: This doc is an abbreviated version of Client SSO Access to Chorus PRD , tailored to the point of view of Orange County. 
 üëÄ Summary
 Why are we doing this? 
 Orange County likely has a dozen+ apps for each of their employees. As a result, managing users, permissions, and access across their toolset is cumbersome, expensive, and error prone.

 What do we expect to accomplish? 
 We will introduce mechanisms for folks to log into Chorus via SSO.

 We will introduce tools for authors to manage how those mechanisms will work on their apps.

 Will will provide for tools to manage updates between Orange County's management systems and Chorus.

 Why is it important? 
 Orange County needs to be able to easily manage who can access what at scale.

 Chorus team 
 Responsible: 

 Accountable: 
 Katy Jeter, Product Manager

 Consulted: 
 Addie Nakatani

 Sarah Burdette

 Mike Valdez

 Informed: 

 Jira epics 

 Figma file 

 Client impacts 

 Chorus impacts 

 Client deadline 

 Objectives
 Approved Orange County staff members will have full control over the ability to provision and remove staff members for their Chorus app. Users will be able to log into the Chorus app via their Orange County-issued SSO credentials. The Orange County SSO tool (Azure AD), along with Multi-factor Authentication enforcement, will be managed by the Orange County HCA IT team. 
 Allow users to safely and securely log into Chorus using Orange County's SSO tool, Azure AD .

 Allow authors to customize login rules to ensure that user management and authentication is compliant with their policies.

 Keep OC SSO users and Chorus users in sync.

 Target Delivery : September 30, 2023 
 Access to specific zones within an Orange County app will be governed manually and separately. 
 Terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 SSO
 Single Sign-On. Orange County's tool is Azure AD . 

 MFA
 Multi-Factor Authentication

 OC HCA IT
 Orange County Health Care Agency Information Technology

 County-Contracted Organizations
 Warmline (NAMI)

 CSU Bed Board (Exodus Recovery & College Hospital)

 IdP
 Identity Provider

 Client Contacts
 Phong Vo: Works with Joe and Jay

 Joe Tran: Team lead for system administration team working with Chorus SSO; Network Services Technical Lead

 Shaun: SSO Admin connecting with program interaction

 David Castellanos: Information Security Officer

 Charles Snook: OC IT; Cloud Engineer?

 Jay Alberto: OC IT; Cloud Engineer

 Key User Stories
 OC HCA IT Staff Members
 Priority 
 User Story Title 
 User Story 
 Jira Backlog Item (contains acceptance criteria) 

 1
 Create New User
 As an OC HCA IT staff member, when I create a new user in Azure AD, that user can use this to authenticate into the Chorus app.
 [Insert Jira link here] 

 2
 Delete/Remove User
 As an OC HCA IT member, I want users in the Chorus app to automatically deactivate if they are removed from our directory so the app remains compliant.
 [Insert Jira link here] 

 3
 SSO Using Existing Credentials
 As an OC staff member, I want to log into Chorus using an account I already have so that I don't have to manage more user names and passwords.
 [Insert Jira link here] 

 OC Users
 When users sign into the Chorus app, I can use the OC SSO tool to gain access. 

 When signing in via Chorus credentials, MFA is required (which is enforced by Azure AD). 

 When my access is revoked from Azure AD or Chorus, I cannot use SSO or any other form of access to log into the Chorus app. 

 Chorus Authors
 As an author, I want my users to be able to login with OC's SSO tool so I don't have to manage more users or their permissions.

 Critical User Journey(s)
 OC HCA IT creates a new user in Azure AD. That user gets just-in-time provisioning in the target Chorus app based on the assigned Azure Group/Client Group .

 Authors can set zone access to only allow users from a linked Active Directory authenticating via SSO. 

 Success metrics
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Allow Orange County to self-manage their user access
 There will be a reduced number or more accurate list of users

 Expedite the user provisioning process
 Reduced amount of time spent provisioning accounts

 Constraints
 At a high level, Chorus needs to decide what will be our next SSO implementation .

 We need to confirm with Orange County if external emails (i.e. emails not managed by Orange County) will also need to be supported by SSO. This will change the SSO option we recommend.

 We need to confirm with Orange County if SSO implementation will need to be rolled out per mobile zone/app, OR, if SSO will be rolled out across all zones/apps at the same time.
 This will also determine whether or not we will have just-in-time provisioning available or if we will need to continue pre-provisioning (which is a known security vulnerability).

 If zone by zone, we will start with OC Links, then CAT Mobile, etc.

 If all zones/apps at the same time, this will be timed with the launch of the Referrals & Linkages project .

 We must comply with security, privacy, and compliance rules, standards, and best practices.

 Requirements 
 The Chorus platform allows SSO authentications from the Azure AD SSO tool . 

 Users will be provisioned as just-in-time, instead of pre-provisioned to reduce our security risk. 

 OC IT will need to provision all users requiring access to a given app in Azure AD prior to the agreed upon go-live date for a given app.

 Prior to go-live , Chorus will prepare the following:
 Product Manager responsibilities:
 Updated workflow for collecting user information needed for the existing Team portal. 

 Announcement messages in the respective apps notifying users of the changes and dates for when these will go live.

 Customer Success Team responsibilities:
 Training materials for adopting the new account management procedure.

 Author Configuration
 Authors must be able to pass in the necessary parameters to connect their user directory to the Chorus app.

 Authors should be able to access the app without having to authenticate through OC's SSO. 

 If an author needs to test a login-gated page as a normal client user, they will need to be added to OC's Azure AD.

 Client Login
 If enabled, existing Chorus users may access a login-gated mobile zone using SSO.

 User Creation & Conflict Management
 To determine whether an individual exists in both systems, we will match on email address.

 If a "matched account" has a different first name, last name, or phone number, Chorus will update the associated values in its system

 Conflicts
 name

 email

 phone

 Security, Privacy, and Compliance
 All information is safely stored in a way that complies with all rules that apply to Chorus.

 If a user is deactivated in OC's SSO system, they are promptly deactivated in Chorus.

 Milestones
 Milestone 1
Orange County Staff
 Milestone 2
Orange County Contracted Entities 
 (ideally) B2B Tenancy/Invite external users 
 Milestone 3
Multiple Azure ADs for 
Orange County Contracted Entities
 (If a contractor uses Azure, OC could create multiple connections this way.) 

 Release Blockers: 
 OC-employed users can sign in with Azure SSO

 Release Blockers: 
 OC-contracted users can sign in with Azure SSO via the Azure AD B2B tenancy.

 For OC-contracted users without the ability to use SSO authentication, Chorus login credentials have MFA enforced.

 OC to decide if non-organization emails will be allowed for user accounts so Chorus can support accordingly.

 Release Blockers: 
 Chorus environments can support multiple IdP connections to multiple OC apps.

 Should have: 
 Should have: 
 Should have: 

 Nice to have: 
 Nice to have: 
 Nice to have: 

 Out of scope
 Ideas
 Files
 Next steps

 1 
 incomplete 

 Problems to solve
 Open Questions
 Question 
 Answer 
 Answerer 
 Answered on 

 OC HCA IT QUESTIONS 

 Are we rolling out SSO per app or all at once?
 Plan to roll out app by app for easier testing, starting with existing apps followed by apps launching in Q3 2023.
 David Castellanos
 8/1/23

 Will all apps require SSO or only some?

 Do we need to support SSO access for non-county-operated entities?
 There are 26 non-county contractors with approximately 59 users needing access to various OC apps within Chorus (and growing).
 Instead of connecting to multiple IdPs, the goal is to instead invite guests to the OC Azure AD account via B2B tenancy ‚Äì waiting to confirm this is a viable option as of 8/1/23.
 OC IT
 8/1/23

 Is MFA a requirement?
 MFA is a requirement for logins via Chorus user credentials only when SSO is not available.
 (Goal is to instead invite guests to Azure AD via B2B tenancy ‚Äì waiting to confirm this is a viable option as of 8/1/23.)
 OC IT
 8/1/23

 Confirm that they can set MFA on their azure and that that would cover the MFA requirement (that's the common pattern).

 Our assumption is that the same Azure AD account will be used across all entities at OC for SSO access. Is this accurate?
 Yes
 OC IT
 8/1/23

 We are assuming that if a user needs to authenticate, they should always be forced to do so via the SSO tool, and should not have the ability to login using Chorus credentials. Is this accurate?

 What security and/or data retention policies do we need to follow of in terms of how/when we remove users and user data from Chorus that have been removed from Azure AD?

 When can their team test Azure AD B2B tenancy guest invites by? We will need this to test if the Chorus platform can authenticate with these users in the same way as normal OC county staff.

 See https://chorusapp.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CE/pages/1931542540/Client+SSO+Access+to+Chorus+PRD#%3Aquestion_mark%3A-Open-Questions , Orange County section for additional questions.

 CHORUS INTERNAL QUESTIONS 

 See Client SSO Access to Chorus PRD for more information.

title: OC Improve Dispatch Response & Safety (Geotab) PRD
content:
Chorus team 
 R esponsible 
 Designer:

 Engineer / SA(s):

 A ccountable 
 Product Manager: Shane Bai

 Platform Product Manager: Katy Jeter

 C onsulted

 I nformed
 Product Manager: Julie Jessup

 Platform Product Manager: Carter Moar

 Project Manager: Sarah Burdette

 Jira epics 

 Figma file 

 Client impacts 
 OC Links, CAT - Mobile

 Chorus impacts 

 Client deadline 
 CCMU Funding Deadline: 12/31/23
Geotab launch: Spring 2024 (~May 2024)

 Terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 CCMU
 Crisis Care Mobile Units Program Grant .
 OC's CCMU funds are only available until the end of 2023. 

 Geotab
 Geotab is a fleet management tool. https://www.geotab.com/ 

 MHSA
 Mental Health Services Act . It is designed to expand and transform California's behavioral health system to better serve individuals with, and at risk of, serious mental health issues, and their families. MHSA addresses a broad continuum of prevention, early intervention, and service needs and the necessary infrastructure, technology, and training elements that effectively support the public behavioral health system.
 Recently, a reform rule was implemented where field teams have 60 minutes from the time a call operator (e.g. an OC Navigator) answers a call to determine if there's a need for dispatch and then send a dispatch team.

 OC Links

 OC Navigator
 A dispatcher who answers calls received by OC Links.

 CAT Mobile
 CAT Mobile is the Crisis Assessment Team. They are a team of clinicians that gets dispatched after an OC Navigator (via OC Links) receives a call and they determine a resource needs to be sent to a person in need.

 O&E Mobile
 Response and dispatch system for the Outreach & Engagement team

 Geotab SDK
 Geotab Software Development Kit .

 OC Contacts 
 Sharon Ishikawa
 Amy Couch
 Erika Punchard
 Ryan Yowell
 Matthew Kee
 Vanessa Thomas
 Linda Molina
 Omar Leyva

 Geotab Contacts
 Drake Zwahlen, Business Development Manager, Public Sector
 Brianne Biczo, Public Sector Account advisor; handles west coast public sector accounts

 Objective
 When a call comes in to a given OC program (CAT, O&E, etc.), a dispatcher may need to send a clinician to the caller's location based on the clinician's proximity ETA to the caller, their skillset, and which vehicle they have available to make the dispatch. The solution Chorus provides for OC needs to:
 Improve the efficiency of the dispatch.

 Make sure the dispatch is accomplished within the timeframe outlined by the CCMU Program Grant .

 Provides better insights into and helps manage the OC workforce capacity.

 The goal is to shorten dispatches by minutes. 
 Target launch : Spring 2024 
 Broader Context
 Due to a recent MHSA reform, the CAT Mobile team essentially has 60 minutes from call to dispatch arrival.
 A target goal is to have 75% of dispatches arrive within 30 minutes or less .

 Orange County plans to have 21 vehicles outfitted with Geotab's hardware by Spring 2024.

 Generally, 2 clinicians are assigned to a given fleet vehicle.
 At times, clinicians may need to use their own personal vehicle to respond to a dispatch .

 It is possible a pair of clinicians would need to change out during a shift.

 There are 2 ADA vans. It is possible that a clinician may need to change out their assigned fleet vehicle for one of these ADA vans during a dispatch.

 OC needs to know how long dispatched field workers are spending with each client so they can :
 Understand how long client service sessions are taking.

 Use this information to support staff training.

 Use this information as data to support additional hiring requests as needed.

 Use this information to ensure the safety of staff.

 Use this information for their contractual state reporting needs.

 Due to union rules, we are allowed to track the geolocation of the vehicles but not the clinicians. 

 Personas
 If a FigJam exists with user personas, link to it here: https://www.figma.com/file/0gkKqxKmQwj208l1TUEqox/PADs---Project-Creative-Brief?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=fWUDxaTrngntgQGl-1 
 User Class 
 Description 
 Key Goal 
 Control 
 Persona 

 Peer 
 Individual who has a mental health condition. They need a PAD to clarify how best to help them when they are in crisis. 
 Complete their own PAD in advance of an emergency / crisis state 

 Get notarized 

 Full control 

 Only their project 

 Richard 
 Age: 52 

 Occupation: not employed, receiving disability benefits 

 Education level: Some college 

 Tech savvy: 3/10 

 Peer Support Specialist 
 A peer's buddy (likely with their own PAD), who helps them complete their PAD. Will likely help many peers with their PADS. 
 Guide / assist a peer to complete their own PAD 

 Often completed in multiple sessions 

 Read only & notes 

 View all data 

 Multiple PADS 

 Maria 
 Age: 35 

 Occupation: Peer Support Specialist 

 Education level: High school 

 Tech savvy: 8/10 

 Key User Stories
 What does the user need to be able to do and why (using the "As a..., I want to...so that" format)? This should focus on the most critical stories, where the more exhaustive list can live in Jira. 
 User: Peer 
 As a Peer, I want to sign up so that I can use the service. 

 User: Peer Support Specialist 
 As a Peer Support Specialist, I want to add notes so that I can communicate with the Peer. 

 Critical User Journey(s)
 Dispatcher
 Dispatcher answers a call.

 Dispatcher determines the call will require a dispatch and starts an MFSA timer .

 Dispatcher gets the destination for the dispatch .

 Dispatcher reviews a real-time map with the geolocation of all fleet vehicles relative to the caller's geolocation. 
 [Envisioning Chorus sending an API call asking for the geolocation of the 21 fleet vehicles.]

 [Envisioning Chorus generates an ETA based on live traffic updates .]

 Dispatcher determines which clinician is likely to be utilizing the closest vehicle and checks if the clinician has the appropriate skillset for the caller's need.
 If there's a match, dispatcher confirms the clinician currently has that fleet vehicle checked out and sends a dispatch to the clinician. [TBD]

 If there isn't a match, the dispatcher looks for the next closest fleet vehicle and repeats the process.

 Dispatcher can monitor how long a clinician has:
 Been in transit.

 Been meeting with the dispatch recipient. 

 Clinician
 Clinician checks out a fleet vehicle for the day. [TBD]
 [Need a workflow for when a personal vehicle is in use.] 

 Clinician accepts a dispatch.
 [Envisioning Chorus sending an API call asking for the geolocation of that specific fleet vehicle to record in Chorus at this moment in time.]

 Clinician arrives at the dispatch recipient's location.

 Clinician meets with the caller and stops the MFSA timer . [TBD]
 [Envisioning Chorus sending an API call asking for the geolocation of that specific fleet vehicle to record in Chorus at this moment in time.]

 [Consider making the case unable to open/proceed until the timer is stopped for accurate recording information?]

 [Consider starting a new timer for how long clinician has been meeting with caller as a staff safety feature.]

 Clinician completes the dispatch.
 [Chorus records time of completion which stops the clinician timer safety feature.]

 Clinician or Vehicle Changes
 [TBD]

 Success metrics
 Goal Type 
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Business
 Time between identified dispatch need and clinician arrival is reduced
 75% of response times are < 30 minutes

 Business
 Clinician staff are safer when dispatched
 Duration of dispatches are recorded

 Constraints
 What compliance guidelines, budgetary/timeline restrictions, or other factors need to be kept in mind? 

 Requirements
 We need a mechanism for the moment a dispatcher (triage clinician) determines a dispatch is required, Chorus records this determination time and starts an MHSA timer.

 To make the best informed decision, the dispatcher will need to know real-time information on the following during this process: 
 The geolocation of all vehicles in the fleet. 

 The geolocation of a field clinician with an appropriate skillset by fleet vehicle. 

 The destination for the dispatch. 

 Time the field clinician accepts the dispatch. 

 Time the clinician begins transit to the caller's destination. 

 Duration of the dispatch of time clinician meets with the caller and resolution. 

 Nice to Haves
 Estimated time of arrival from clinician to caller. 

 Milestones
 Milestone 1: MVP
 Milestone 2: 
 Milestone 3: 

 Release blockers:
 Manual location reporting and vehicle checkout

 Release blockers: 
 Geotab reporting of location reporting and/or vehicle dispatch

 Release blockers: 
 Automatic reporting of location reporting and/or vehicle dispatch

 Should have:

 Should have:
 Should have:

 Nice to have:

 Nice to have:
 Nice to have:

 Out of Scope
 Creating an API listener for events from Geotab.

 Files
 Description 
 Author 
 Link 

 MyGeotab Map iframe
 https://geotab.github.io/sdk/software/guides/map-add-ins-docs/ 

 Geotab product guide
 See section on "Types of Tracking" that states: 
 "With Active Tracking, asset locations are refreshed every second for up to 20 moving assets displayed on the map, providing continuous animated movement…. 

 ‚ú± NOTE : Active Tracking is only available on the ProPlus plan." 
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/14GNbMq_ZKSUpkmSdJ8ws-DyO4P_HmTYOIu3k52f7KKY/edit#heading=h.gr7gs5ntzq3r 

 Adding custom content to a Geotab map
 https://support.geotab.com/en-GB/mygeotab/doc/custom-maps 

 Critical Questions
 Question 
 Blocker (y/n)? 
 Answer 
 Answerer 
 Answered on 

 GENERAL 

 Are we allowed by the clinician's union to track a clinician's geolocation in real time? 
 We need to understand if tracking is a nice-to-have, a requirement to improve safety, or a convenience so clinicians do not need to manually report this information. 

 What is the specific definition of the 60-minute timer? 

 How are we going to track a clinician's location if they are using a personal vehicle?

 When does dispatch tracking start and stop?

 GEOTAB 

 What are our options for associating an individual with a vehicle?
 Geotab Drive App 

 Key fob ($65 each; ~$2,730+) 
 The clinician would swipe their key fob for the vehicle.

 OC's CCMU funds for key fob purchases are only available until the end of 2023. 

 Manual recording within the Chorus app (i.e. a dropdown of available vehicles).

 Geotab
 6/28/23

 What is the pricing model for utilizing API calls?
 Chorus will not need an extra license and there's no extra fee to access the data.
 Geotab
 6/28/23

 What API endpoints are recommended for Chorus to grab needed data?
 Y

 Can Geotab send information to Chorus in real time? 
 Yes, it can do by the second or instant call outs. 

 Chorus will need OC permission to access MyGeotab online portal and data repository.

 So long as the vehicle is moving, real-time data is available.

 Geotab
 6/28/23

 Does Geotab have the ability to overlay vehicles on a map?
 Chorus would need to use its own map and then use the MyGeotab SDK to populate it.
 Geotab
 6/28/23

 ORANGE COUNTY 

 How do they plan to access Geotab data?

 Who at OC can grant permission for Chorus to access MyGeotab online portal and data repository information? We would need access to the parent account for Human Services.
 Y

 Are fleet vehicles checked out at all times, regardless if a clinician is currently on a shift? Or can the assumption be made that any vehicle within proximity to a caller is eligible to be dispatched at that time?

 Follow up question to vehicle check-out state, do we need to provide visibility into whether or not that clinician is currently working and/or tie into the Scheduling work that's being done now?

 Roadmap

 General updates 
 Currently aiming for a late October launch, but may change due to RingCentral and HCA demographic field updates.

 We have been having the The Warmline team complete UAT in a phased approach. There has been some great feedback and we plan to discuss all their feedback thus far in more detail on Thursday. Some examples of their feedback include:
 Having the case info be on one long page or being able to freely move between tabs.

title: OC SSO App Access Management for Groups, Zones, and Users
content:
Master Spreadsheet for Managing OC's SSO Configurations
 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1P2vrC-xYArFO13b9QyzeEeJSAQnDgIIu3iXnqL5jSPM/edit#gid=1277622550 

 Core Concepts & Responsibilities
 Groups : There is a 1:1 relationship between Chorus Client Groups and Azure Groups.
 Chorus product is responsible for identifying and creating needed Client Groups for the app.

 OC IT is responsible for creating equivalent Azure Groups and providing those Group IDs to Chorus.

 Chorus engineering is responsible for mapping the Azure Groups to the Client Groups in the platform code.

 OCHCA IT is responsible for assigning users to Azure Groups.

 Zones : There is a 1:1 relationship between Chorus Zones and Azure Apps.
 Chorus product is responsible for identifying and creating needed Zones for the app (and how Client Groups will be assigned).

 OC IT is responsible for providing Chorus the Azure App ID, Tenant ID, and Client Secret for each Azure app/Chorus Zone pair.

 A Chorus platform admin is responsible for adding this new IdP info.

 A Chorus author is responsible for configuring the zone to use the new IdP info.

 Users 
 "Internal users" refers to OC staff members with an @ochca.com email address.

 "External users" refers to OC contractors. 
 All contractors must use an enterprise email address.

 All contractors must provide additional information to OC's compliance teams for approval.

 OC IT is responsible for sending Microsoft Azure invites to contractors.

 OC programs are responsible for submitting users via an OC NAR request for their IT teams to process accordingly. Programs should plan on this taking a few business days to complete.

 When there are changes to Groups or Zones, this requires manual coordination between Chorus engineering and the OC/OCHCA IT teams to generate and apply the necessary coding changes. 

 Implementing SSO for New Apps
 Quick & Dirty
 When OC wants to give users access to a new Chorus app:
 Chorus sends the app zone URL to OC IT.

 OC IT creates an Azure App for it.

 OC IT securely sends Chorus the following Azure App details (see 1Pass for API key entries):
 Application (Client) ID

 Tenant ID

 Client Secret

 A Chorus Admin enters these details in the Admin Panel > Integrations > Active Directory.
 (This is what populates the "Login type" dropdown in the Mobilize zone configuration.)

 OC IT creates the (internal and external) Azure Groups that can access that Azure App.
 Internal = OC staff

 External = OC contractor (usually same name as internal with "_Cloud" appended)

 OC IT sends the (internal and external) Azure Group IDs to Chorus.

 Chorus Eng hardcodes the mapping of the 2 Azure Group IDs (internal and external) to the 1 Chorus Client Group. (See Eng's Client Group Mappings .)
 As of Sept 2024 there is no UI for this, but it is being explored as a future add.

 See SSO ‚Äì Azure App Setup Process for more information.

 Profit.

 Process from Inception to Completion
 Prepare the Chorus app 
 The Chorus SA(s) finalizes the Client Groups and Zones for the new app.

 The SA(s) updates the Zone and Group tabs in https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1P2vrC-xYArFO13b9QyzeEeJSAQnDgIIu3iXnqL5jSPM/edit?pli=1#gid=1277622550 
 As of 1/10/24 users are now managed exclusively by OC. 

 Timeline : Complete at least 2 weeks prior to launch.

 Create a Launch Plan 
 A Chorus project/program manager works with the program lead to review the "7. Launch" options below and make a decision.

 Timeline : Complete at least 2 weeks prior to launch.

 Prepare the Users List 
 A Chorus project/program manager works with the program lead to identify users for the new app and their group assignments.
 Important : For contractors, additional information will need to be collected including (employee ID, direct phone/mobile phone, etc.).

 A Chorus project manager helps the OC program lead put together training and notification materials to inform users of the SSO login process for accessing Chorus apps.

 Timeline : Complete at least 4 days prior to launch.

 OC NAR Submissions (Technical Implementation) 
 A Chorus project/program manager submits the list of Chorus Client Groups and Zones to the OC Primary Critical System Owner for that Chorus app.

 The Primary Critical System Owner submits an OC NAR request to OC/OCHCA IT to complete the following:
 Create an Azure Group for each Chorus Client Group.

 Create an Azure App for each Chorus Zone. 

 Provide which Azure Groups have access to each Azure App.

 ***Important*** : Provide the timing of when Azure Apps will be assigned to Azure Groups ( this determines the launch timing! ). Refer to "2. Create a Launch Plan" above.

 Match all configurations made in Azure to existing Chorus Azure Apps.

 Note the target launch date for the new Chorus app.

 Timeline : OC/OCHCA IT will need 1 - 2 business days to process.

 OC/OCHCA IT will need to process the NAR and securely send back to Chorus the generated Azure Group IDs and Azure App IDs, Tenant IDs, and Client Secrets.
 The Group IDs do not need to be encrypted ‚Äì only the Azure App creds. 

 Timeline : Chorus will need 1 - 2 business days to process.

 Credentials should be sent by the client to a Chorus IT [EMAIL ADDRESS PENDING] . 

 Chorus Jira Tickets (Technical Implementation) 
 The Chorus project/program manager will submit an https://chorusapp.atlassian.net/servicedesk/customer/portal/1 request to add those credentials to 1Password and share with the Chorus platform admins. 

 The Chorus product/technical project manager submits a ticket to Engineering to process mapping the Azure Group IDs to the Chorus Client Group IDs.

 The Chorus product/technical project manager submits a ticket to Client Innovations to have a platform admin add the Azure App credentials as new IdP options to the Admin Panel.

 The Chorus product/technical project manager submits a ticket to Client Innovations for the SA to update the Zone configurations to use the new IdP. 
 SAs to make any other necessary adjustments to the app.

 Timeline : Chorus will need 1 - 2 business days to process.
 This will be treated as an interrupt ticket to the existing sprint. 

 Submit the Users List 
 The Primary Critical System Owner submits an OC NAR request for adding users to the appropriate Azure Group(s).

 OC/OCHCA IT to process the NAR.

 Timeline : OC/OCHCA IT will need 1 - 2 business days to process the user list.

 Launch ‚Äì Choose 1 
 Option 1: Chorus App Goes Live Before Users are Added 
 OC/OCHCA IT assigns Azure Apps to Azure Groups at the same time Groups are created.

 When a user is created and/or added to an Azure Group, the Azure App will show up in the user's dashboard right away and direct links will work immediately.

 Timeline : OC/OCHCA IT will need 1 - 2 business days to process the NAR plus up to 24 hours for new users to show up in the Azure system.
 New OC staff members will require up to 24 hours to process (though usually 2 - 4 hours) due to required MIM syncing (part of OC's HR system).

 OC contractors will likely process within 1 - 2 hours since they are not part of the MIM syncing.

 Option 2: Chorus App Goes Live After Users are Added 
 When a user is created and/or added to an Azure Group, the Azure App will NOT yet show up in the user's https://myapps.microsoft.com account and direct links will not work.

 OC/OCHCA IT assigns Azure Apps to Groups as a separate step at a designated time. Azure Apps are assigned to Azure Groups after users have been added to those Groups. Once Apps are assigned to Groups, users will see these apps show up in https://myapps.microsoft.com and direct links will work.
 Timeline : 1 - 2 hours to take effect on launch day. (Assumption is that the users have already been processed, which takes up to 3 business days to complete.) 
 Recommend hosting an open-ended workshop launch meeting and inviting the following parties to ensure a smooth launch and expedient troubleshooting. There is no set agenda, just a passing of the baton between parties as technical steps are taken to launch SSO and confirm everything is working as intended. The majority of attendees will be on standby and are not expected to participate unless called upon. 
 Chorus project manager

 Chorus product manager

 Chorus director of engineering (can review access logs)

 Chorus customer success representative

 OC project/program representative

 OC IT representative

 OCHCA IT representative

 Designated OC users to test: group access, device type, internal/external user access, network access, etc.

 Implementing SSO for Existing Apps
 [Needs to be fleshed out]
 Project/product managers should work with clients to consider if an "SSO is coming" banner in the existing app would be appropriate.

 Project/product managers should determine when old users should be removed from the app.

 Project/product managers should determine when passwords for all existing users should be deleted.

 Managing Groups
 Membership in a Group determines what Zone(s) a user has access to.
 New Groups for Existing Chorus Apps
 Trigger : Chorus or Orange County creates a new Client Group or Azure Group 
 Chorus and OC program staff collaborate to define the new Group and which Zone(s) it has access to.

 Chorus and/or the authorized OC contact submits a NAR to OC IT to create the Group and assign it to existing Azure Apps.

 OC IT creates the Azure Group and sends the new Azure Group ID to Chorus.

 A Chorus engineer maps the new Azure Group ID to the Chorus Client Group.

 A Chorus author adds the Client Group to the correct Zone(s).

 OC program staff then submit a NAR request to OCHCA IT for assignment of users to this new Group. This may take up to 24 hours for their system to process the change. 

 Managing Zones
 Zone URLs will be available to OC users as direct links or via myapps.microsoft.com based on their Group membership.
 New Zones for Existing Chorus Apps
 Trigger : Chorus creates a new login-gated Zone
 Chorus and OC program staff collaborate to define which Client Group(s) should have access to the Zone.

 Chorus and/or the authorized OC contact submits a NAR for the new Azure App (Chorus Zone) to OC IT.
 The ticket needs to include what existing Azure Groups need access to this new Azure App. (Once processed by OC IT, this app will show up in myapps.microsoft.com.)

 OC IT securely sends the new Azure App ID, Tenant ID, and Client Secret to Chorus.

 A Chorus platform admin adds the Azure creds to Admin Panel > Integrations > Active Directory for the given app.

 A Chorus author configures the new Zone to use the new Azure App IdP and assigns Client Groups accordingly.

 Managing Users
 Managing users is exclusively the responsibility of OC. Chorus should/will/does NOT have any involvement in the adding or removing of users from Chorus apps ‚Äì this is entirely managed by the OC program staff, OCHCA IT, and OC IT teams. 
 Adding Users
 An OC program staff member submits an OC NAR request with the following minimum information:
 Name

 Email

 App Name(s)

 App Group(s)

 OC/OCHCA IT processes the ticket. This may take a few business days to complete.

 Once processed, users should be able to access their apps automatically via direct link or through myapps.microsoft.com .

 Removing Users
 An OC program staff member submits an OC NAR request to remove a user from a given Chorus app.

 OC/OCHCA IT processes the ticket. 

 When that user next attempts to access the Chorus app, they are automatically unable to log in. (This will go into effect within 15 minutes of removal by OC/OCHCA IT.)

title: PRD - OC Links - MultiUser Workflow Enhancements (User Presence)
content:
Please note: not all projects require a PRD; this template should be used to gather requirements for any track of work that will take more than one sprint to complete. 
 Chorus team 
 R esponsible 
 Designer: TBD

 Engineer / SA(s): TBD

 A ccountable
 Product Manager: 

 C onsulted: Requester 
 I nformed: Leadership, OC Links service chiefs, platform team, SA team, design

 Jira epics 
 CP-4411 a9d3eb4c-c63a-3c77-864c-b5dd8664a020 System JIRA 

 Figma file 
 https://www.figma.com/file/JWoBZzV6MvJRNhgY9EdvwR/CAT-Dispatch-Workflows-June-2023?type=whiteboard&node-id=433%3A1769&t=13Dsybuzk6AXkzZs-1 

 Client impacts 
 OC Links, CAT Mobile to start

 Chorus impacts 
 The end goal is to have a solution to solve for data crossing due to multiple users accessing the same information on a platform level through user presence implementation. This initiative will cover workflow and implementation enhancements until we reach this point.

 Client deadline 

 Terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 User Presence
 Industry term for the technology that lets applications track 'who is online' on a website -- for example the Slack server that tracks if we're online/offline is their presence server

 Objective
 Our objective is to identify user collision points and implement a solution to mitigate problematic outcomes due to multiple users in the same case, specifically data overriding. Success will mean the ability to identify workflow and implementation enhancements to each collision point in the user experience until we reach a platform level user presence solution that will unlock new potential solutions.
 Broader Context
 On all Chorus applications, more specifically OC Links, there is no concept of capturing user presence so the end user has no way of knowing if other users are viewing the same case. This has led to data overrides if multiple users are performing concurrent actions on the same pages or interactions. As we scale and more users utilize our Chorus applications, multiple users will be accessing the same pages, interactions, and submitting simultaneous actions as part of their workflow. We're already starting to see interest in a solution for BHH products.
 Problem Statement
 In OC Links, multiple users (of the same and different user personas) are concurrently accessing the same pages, interactions, and actions leading to data overrides and a misleading result for users. We currently have no way to identify which and when users are accessing certain pages, interactions, or actions limiting our solutioning.
 Personas
 If a FigJam exists with user personas, link to it here: 
 https://www.figma.com/file/JWoBZzV6MvJRNhgY9EdvwR/CAT-Dispatch-Workflows-June-2023?type=whiteboard&node-id=162%3A2119&t=vOhkEYGkT6dqrax4-1 

 User Class 
 Description 
 Key Goal 

 OC Navigator
 Individual who fields and assesses incoming calls providing resources or determining if the call requires a crisis dispatch (i.e. CAT Youth, CAT Adult, or PERT).
 Fields and assesses incoming calls

 Provides resources and determines if the call requires a crisis dispatch (i.e. CAT Youth, CAT Adult, or PERT)

 Updates cases as necessary for accuracy as information is gathered

 CAT Clinician
 Licensed, field-level individual who is physically dispatched to a crisis call to provide an official assessment of a client and provide additional resources or referrals as needed.
 Is physically dispatched to a crisis call

 Provides an official assessment of a client and additional resources or referrals as needed

 Updates case or calls in to OC to provide details to a Navigator who can update on their behalf

 CAT Dispatcher
 Individual who physically dispatches appropriate and available clinician to a crisis call from OC Links
 Dispatches appropriate and available clinicians to a crisis call from OC Links

 Reviews case and updates for accuracy

 Officer of the Day
 CAT Youth specific dispatcher who dispatches appropriate and available clinicians to a crisis call from OC Links
 Dispatches appropriate and available clinicians to a crisis call from OC Links

 Reviews case and updates for accuracy

 OC Supervisor
 Service chief level user who oversees specific departments or teams related to OC Links and CAT. These individuals are in and out of cases due to a variety of reasons and it is difficult to pin point exact use cases because it varies by case.
 Reviews cases for updates and accuracy 

 Performs actions in cases on behalf of team

 Critical User Journey(s)
 Please refer to the user journey outlined here: https://www.figma.com/file/JWoBZzV6MvJRNhgY9EdvwR/CAT-Dispatch-Workflows-June-2023?type=whiteboard&node-id=162%3A2119&t=vOhkEYGkT6dqrax4-1 
 Success metrics
 List project goals and the metrics you'll use to judge its success. 
 Goal Type 
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Data
 Minimal to no data crossing issues reported by OC Links or CAT Mobile teams
 Support tickets created related to data overrides due to multiple users

 Constraints
 Due to other required, time-sensitive releases for OCHCA, we are strapped in design and build capacity, but also know this is a large pain point for the OC Links team. Our initial solution must address this pain point and allow us to measure success of our initial solution in order to prioritize a larger effort approach.
 Requirements
 For MVP, we will be releasing a Banner Notification that notifies users if another user is currently in the same case. This solution is less disruptive to current user workflow, creates visibility of users that will likely reduce user collisions and allow for collaboration across program staff in data entry. Although it does not directly mitigate the data overrides from a systemic level, it is an expected feature that was proposed by OC and agreed upon during internal brainstorm sessions as a standard feature along with longer term solutions if required.
 Banner design that can be used on multiple pages that is clear, functional, and easily legible by users

 Users must retain the ability to concurrently view a case (eliminates effectivity of a soft lock solution)

 Must be accessible across all tabs within an Edit Case screen

 Banner notification must update in a reasonable time after a user leaves a case

 Nice to have: 
 Ability to identify who the other users are within a case are in order to adjust my workflow (i.e. if a Supervisor sees an OC Links Navigator in the case or vice versa, the user can connect with that person in order to coordinate current status, wait until edits are made before entering, etc.)

 Out of scope
 Although it is needed for a cohesive user experience in the future and is a potential longer term solution for our multiuser problem, we will not be redesigning key workflows in OC Links or CAT to support a read-only version of a case for MVP. 
 Ideas
 Initial Brainstorm Kickoff Notes 
 Brainstorm Session #2 
 Outcome: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tv8WTDkPHeTEZx6JqSjFC7Ozun6OlyLFcmSb5aUqhBI/edit#heading=h.mx70i7g37a5z 
 Next steps
 Type your action, @someone, and check when complete. 

 1 
 incomplete 
 Design to create MVP designs on key pages in OC Links 

 118 
 incomplete 
 Edit Case → Details Tab 

 119 
 incomplete 
 Edit Case → CAT Tab 

 2 
 incomplete 
 Perform a design review internally and demo with client for approval 

 3 
 incomplete 
 Consult SA leads to assess LOE and prioritize into future sprints for build 

 Critical Questions
 Question 
 Blocker (y/n)? 
 Answer 
 Answerer 
 Answered on 

 Is there a way to mitigate multiuser problems between mobile and desktop experiences that have the ability to edit the same data?
 N
 We will implement a banner solution and monitor effectivity through support tickets and user feedback.

title: Unified OC Resource Directory
content:
Please note: not all projects require a PRD; this template should be used to gather requirements for any track of work that will take more than one sprint to complete. 
 Chorus team 
 SA(s): Christy Lee, Gio, Eric

 Project Manager: Calvin 

 Product Manager: Mayra

 Jira epic 
 CP-4470 a9d3eb4c-c63a-3c77-864c-b5dd8664a020 System JIRA 

 Client impacts 
 OC Navigator, OC Links, OC Warmline, OC R&L

 Objective 
 Provide one unified resource dataset to power OC programs/apps including OC Navigator, OC Links, R&L, NAMI OC Warmline, etc. By establishing one dataset, we can: 
 Enable referrals and recommendations across OC programs; 

 Improve quality of resource entries and reduce duplicate data entry;

 Provide a holistic perspective of how resources are being viewed, referred, and recommended;

 Ultimately enable self-referrals from OC Navigator.

 Pave the way to establish workflows for programs to add and edit resources. 
 Note: Resource data governance is an ongoing conversation with the County.

 Problem Statement 
 OC HCA resource information is currently organized separately in (e.g. OC Navigator, OC Links ) which means that resources are being updated in multiple locations without one source of truth. This causes inconsistency, inaccuracy, redundancy, inefficiency, which ultimately leads to delayed support for OC residents. 
 Constraints 
 The following are known timelines, workload, and final approval considerations that will impact the ability to deliver the unified dataset: 
 The UAT release of CRP (Crisis Residential Program) on 11/22, with the need for the database by 10/20/23 - Done 

 As of 11/09/2023, Chorus variables can only support 75 columns (+1 for IDs). The unified database is at this limit, but currently has the following unused columns that may be repurposed for new fields:
 order

 featured

 featured_order

 card_format (would require updating the entry portal to remove this question)

 resc_type (unconfirmed, possible duplicate of digital_type)

 last_verified_by_ref (unconfirmed, possibly duplicate of last_verified_by)

 Dependencies
 The following are items that must be resolved to ensure timely completion of the project. Additional items are called out in the project plan . 
 OC Links is referring to its own de-coupled database and will need to be re-hooked to the new unified database. 
 Status: 

 OC Warmline should pull from the new unified database prior to launch at the beginning of December. This will help prevent technical debt by avoiding adding resources via bulk upload, and creating a new siloed database. 
 Status: In progress 

 All OC Links cases are currently associated with OC Links resources, they will need to be associated with the corresponding OC Navigator resources.

Her sense is that ~20% of these resources are their "own" and not part of the OC Links dataset. 

 R&L module 
 Yes, but only to their own programs. Providers shouldn't be updating another provider's info. 
 Product discussion: How will we accomplish this?

 email to Calvin on Tim and Maite on 9/19/23

 üôã‍‚ôÄÔ∏è Open questions 
 Question 
 Answer 

 Adding OC Links Resources: All OC Navigator resources will be copied into the MCI with no alternations. What is the best approach for OC Links resources?
 Eng maps existing OC Links resource fields to OC Navigator, copies over all OC Links resources and retains their original IDs.

 Contractors review both databases and note overlap. Resources on OC Links but not OC Nav are entered to the new database. Overlapping, duplicate and inactive resources are not.

 Christy Forte
 Option 2. Engineering will update the existing OC Links case records to point to the new referral resource database IDs (many will be ported over from Navigator). These will have been mapped by the independent contractors.

 MCI Sequencing: When will the OC Navigator resource database be copied over to the MCI? 
 If this happens before the CRP/Warmline UAT, how will contractors add and edit resources in the Unified Database? Will they need a resource portal?
 If this happens after the CRP/Warmline UAT, do we foresee any issues when changing the table reference from OCN to the Unified Database?
 Christy Forte
 The database can be copied over when asked by the product team. The OC Navigator resource entry portal can continue to be used, as it will be set up to update the unified database. 
 This should likely be done before 10/20.

 Data Structure for Program-Specific Information: How do we make it such that programs can add information like Internal Notes and Main Contact Details? 
 Do we need a separate table, or many more variable fields? If it's a separate table, would it live in the app or on the MCI?
 When will this be ready?
 Christy Forte
 Program specific information will likely live in its own table on the MCI. Columns can be added for each program that needs its own information for Internal Notes or Main Contact Info.

 OC Navigator Translations: OC Navigator uses a separate "app_language_captions" table to store translated resource details. This table is updated every time a resource is added or edited to the existing OC Navigator database.
 Will this workflow still work if the resource database lives on the MCI?
 , Christy Forte 
 "app_language_captions" and "resource_announcements" will be moved into the MCI.

 Resource Data Governance: Who should be allowed to add new resources and edit existing? 
 Should this happen in the respective apps (e.g. Warmline staff edits a resource and OC Links resource gets updated). Or should this only be a handful of people who have access to the Resource Entry Portal? 
 What about externally operated resources?
 See updates in Requirements Section E.

 Program Specific Resources: Is there a way for individual programs to add resources specific to their products without updating the unified database? Is this something that is urgently needed? Does this undermine the initiative, or risk a bunch of redundancies?
 For right now, we are not considering this. 

 Visible to HCA vs Public: How segmented should visibility of resources be across different apps?
 Example: Is there an HCA resource that will be visible on OC Links, but shouldn't be visible to a CSU user?
 Renaming these options to Public User and R&L User, using multi-select. To reduce complexity, we are keeping this as two options for now.

 Payment selection options.
 Is this needed on Internal Tools? Needed for OCN, possibly Warmline, unknown R&L.
 Not needed for R&L as part of requirements. Initial options have been suggested, but may be expanded upon later. We are adding the column for now, but will update as what this field is used for becomes clearer.

 Hospitals and Law Enforcement to categories 
 Add them as keywords ( to confirm)

 Denoting County Contracted/Operated: What field should be used to filter for whether a resource is County Contracted/Operated? 
 Examples: Show OC Links Card, Initial Resource Source, Also Appears On, something else?

title: DEPRECATED: OC User Management for Chorus via Azure AD
ancestors: OC SSO App Access Management for Groups, Zones, and Users
content:
Adding Users to a Chorus App
 An approved staff member is notified a user needs to be added to a Chorus app.
 This process needs to be defined by OC program staff. 

 Sample instructions: 
 Someone submits an email request to a program staff member requesting access, whether it's for an existing employee or a contractor. 

 Program staff reviews a set of criteria determined by the stakeholders for whether or not to grant access. 
 For contractors , they will additionally be required to sign a [NAME OF AGREEMENT] stating that they understand they are responsible for notifying Orange County program staff via [METHOD OF NOTIFICATION] within 24 hours of changes needed to user permissions. 

 If approved, an appropriate program staff member will submit a request to OCHCA IT. 

 The program staff member submits a support ticket to OCHCA IT via a NAR request with the following information: 
 Name

 Email

 Azure AD Group(s) 
 This is a pre-determined list defined by OCHCA IT and Chorus. Eligible groups will be listed in the NAR request form. 

 OCHCA IT, can you add any other relevant information here or better yet, links and screenshots? 

 OCHCA IT completes the request and notifies the user and/or requesting staff member that the user now has access to the Chorus app.

 The new user accesses their Azure AD Launchpad and clicks on the "Chorus" app(s) listed.

 Because the user is accessing the site from Azure AD, they will automatically be directed to the appropriate app module in Chorus. (If for some reason they weren't already logged into Azure AD, they will be directed to do so before being allowed into Chorus.)

 That's it!

 Editing Existing Users
 An approved staff member is notified that an edit is needed to a user in a Chorus app.
 This process is to be defined by the client with their internal team and stakeholders. 

 The program staff member submits a support ticket to OCHCA IT via a NAR request asking for changes to any of the following: 
 Name

 Email 

 Azure AD Group(s)
 This is a pre-determined list defined by OCHCA IT and Chorus. Check with OCHCA IT for a current list.

 OCHCA IT, can you add any other relevant information here or better yet, links and screenshots? 

 OCHCA IT completes the request and notifies the user and/or requesting staff member of the change(s).

 The user accesses their Azure AD Launchpad and clicks on the "Chorus" app listed.

 The user automatically has access to the correct module(s) within 15 minutes.

 That's it!

 Removing Users from a Chorus App
 An approved staff member is notified that a user needs to be removed from a Chorus app.
 This process needs to be defined by OC program staff. 

 Sample instructions: 
 Someone submits an email request to a program staff member requesting user access removal, whether it's for an existing employee or a contractor. 

 Contractors are responsible for notifying Orange County program staff via [METHOD OF NOTIFICATION] within 24 hours of need for user removal. 

 The program staff member submits a support ticket to OCHCA IT via a NAR request asking that the user be removed from the Chorus Azure AD Group(s).

 OCHCA IT completes the request.

 Within 15 minutes of removal, the user will automatically no longer be able to log into Chorus.

 That's it!

 Need help? 
 If users are having issues accessing a Chorus app they will first contact program staff for assistance.

 If necessary, program staff may then escalate this issue to OCHCA IT by submitting a support ticket to [SYSTEM] and include the following information for that user: 
 Name

 Email

 Azure AD Group(s)
 This is a pre-determined list defined by OCHCA IT and Chorus. Check with OCHCA IT for a current list.

 If OCHCA IT is unable to resolve the issue, they may escalate the ticket to Chorus by submitting a support ticket to Chorus Support Center via this link . Chorus will expect the following to have been checked and confirmed is working correctly before submitting to Chorus:
 The user is active in Azure AD.

 The user has been assigned to the correct Group(s) in Azure AD.
