title: OC HCA IT User Provisioning & De-Provisioning
ancestors: OC SSO App Access Management for Groups, Zones, and Users
content:
There are many parties involved in any project. For Chorus in particular, here is the list of involved parties and their involvements from the OCHCA perspective.
 OCHCA IT, OC IT, and OC Compliance Teams & Contacts 
 Orange County User Provisioning Policy
 Provided by David Castellanos to Chorus on September 5, 2023:
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/197yOIm8A1qxAnNeSVMTr6a82yFwhGgPo/edit?usp=drive_link&ouid=115896567208507325556&rtpof=true&sd=true 
 NAR Request Workflow
 The whole process starts and ends with a program submitting a NAR (Network Access Request). 
 A few notes:
 OCHCA IT does not have its own Azure tenancy. They have a sub-tenancy with OCIT's (County) Azure tenancy. So when we are talking about Azure AD, we are referring to the County Azure AD.

 All contractor accounts are created in MIM (Microsoft Identity Management) and synced up to Azure AD .

 The County HR team is not involved in the OCHCA IT's contractor provisioning and de-provisioning process.

 Provisioning County Employed Users (HCA Users)
 The Program will submit a NAR to request a new user (or contractor) through an ISM (IT Service Management) ticketing system managed by the OCHCA IT service desk.

 The ticket will be processed by the OCHCA IT provisioning team based on the predefined roles from The Program (On-Premise Azure AD Groups which eventually sync up to Azure AD Group).

 The County HR provisioning team will pre-create the user account in MIM with the appropriate roles. At the same time, the County HR " HART " system (the employees management system) will also create the new employee account. 

 Once MIM and HART sync up through the MIM sync process, the account will be created in both OCHCA IT Azure AD and the County Azure AD.

 De-provisioning County Employed Users (HCA Users)
 The Program will submit a NAR to request de-provisioning of a user (or contractor) through an ISM ticketing system managed by the OCHCA IT service desk.

 The OCHCA IT provisioning team will process the termination of the user's account in MIM .
 (The user will not be able to gain any access from OCHCA IT resources. The account will be disabled, but not deleted, in OCHCA IT Azure AD.)

 County HR will remove the user from the HART system.

 After HART and MIM sync up, the user's account will permanently be removed from both OCHCA IT AD and County Azure AD.

 Contractor Provisioning Options
 B2B ‚Äì Current Method in Use and Confirmed by Orange County on 9/14/23
 The OCHCA IT sysadmin team (Phong's team) will work with OCIT to create a script to invite a contractor's email (including personal emails) to join the County Azure AD. 

 The contractor will go though an authentication process to create their own identity, including the setup of MFA. 

 Once registered, OCHCA IT will assign the contractor with a specific role(s) to a pre-defined Azure AD Group. The available Azure AD Groups are defined by the OC program staff and the Chorus team and implemented by the OCHCA IT team.

 FIM (Federate Identity Management) ‚Äì Method Currently Unavailable 
 This requires all contractors/providers to belong to a trusted federation like Okta, AWS, Amazon, Google, Facebook, AOL, Yahoo, etc. Chorus would need to build the support for each of these trusted sources or integrate with a product like Auth0 . Both of these options at this time are unavailable. 
 Manually Create in a User in MIM
 Our OCHCA IT provisioning team will have to manually create these accounts for contractors and use the MIM sync process to sync it up to the County Azure AD.
 OCIT Involvement
 OCIT is the Azure AD integration provider. We only need them to create Azure AD Enterprise Applications and provide OIDC authentication (instead of SAML) as this is modern best practice. We will also need to work with them for the onboarding process for contractors either B2B. (They are not involved in the OCHCA IT user provisioning process.)

title: SFTP Access for Orange County to Chorus Data Exports
ancestors: EDW Integration ‚Äì¬†Delivery of Chorus App Data to OC Databricks
content:
Chorus Innovations has set up an AWS Family Transfer bucket where periodic data exports are made available to authorized users at Orange County. Below are the policies and instructions for gaining access to this system.
 Important Caveats 
 For initial setup: 
 An authorized OC program staff member will submit a NAR ticket to OCHCA providing an approved list of users needing access to the data exports.

 For each OC employee user approved, OCHCA IT will need to:
 Provide an SSH key for that user

 Set up that user's device with an approved SFTP client

 OCHCA IT will then approve and submit this list to Chorus via Zendesk support@chorus-ochcahelpcenter.zendesk.com .

 These data export files will be accessible from a designated folder via SFTP using an SSH connection. All users with access to this designated folder will have access to all files available in this folder.

 A download log may be provided upon request to monitor which users are downloading which files. 

 The list of users should be kept at an absolute minimum for best security practices.

 The client-approved users will be granted per-user access that is not to be shared. These users must provide an SSH key from the device they plan to use for accessing the data exports.

 New User Requests
 Prerequisite Requirements : OC employees will need to work with OCHCA IT to: 
 Generate an SSH key

 Identify and/or install an approved SFTP client.

 Once these are available, they may proceed with their request. 
 OC program staff submits a NAR to OCHCA IT with the following information:
 Requester's name

 Requester's email

 Requester's title

 Date of request

 New user's name

 New users's title

 New user's SSH key
 OCHCA IT will need to assist the approved user with generating this SSH key.

 OCHCA IT will need to identify and/or install an approved SFTP client on this user's device.

 List of data export files the new user plans to access

 OCHCA IT approves the request and sends a Zendesk support@chorus-ochcahelpcenter.zendesk.com ticket with the same information to Chorus. 

 Chorus processes the request.

 A Chorus representative will then schedule a screenshare session with the new user to confirm their SFTP connection is successful using the SFTP client recommended by OCHCA IT.

 Chorus notifies OCHCA IT the Zendesk ticket is resolved.

 OCHCA IT notifies program staff the NAR ticket is resolved.

 User Removal Requests
 OC program staff submits a NAR to OCHCA IT requesting a user be removed.

 OCHCA IT approves the request and sends a Zendesk support@chorus-ochcahelpcenter.zendesk.com ticket with the same information to Chorus. 

 Chorus processes the request and notifies OCHCA IT the Zendesk ticket is resolved.

 OCHCA IT notifies program staff the NAR ticket is resolved.

content:
Please note: not all projects require a PRD; this template should be used to gather requirements for any track of work that will take more than one sprint to complete. 
 Chorus team

 Designer: Kris, possibly Envoy

 SA(s): Christy Lee, Gio, Eric

 OC Navigator

 Will this be a productized feature, or a "one-off"? 

 Client deadline 
 TBD

 Objective
 Consolidate three Orange County Resource Directories: 
 Mental Health and Recovery Services (MHRS); Drug Medi-Cal Organized Delivery System (DMC-ODS); Network of Care (NOC)

 Provider Directory (PD) and 274

 Reduce inefficiencies in quality management by keeping resource information updated, consolidated, and consistent in one place;

 Improve accuracy of resource information, especially for county-operated or contracted programs to meet state requirements for quality management;

 Broader Context
 Problem Statement 
 The state requires accurate, comprehensive documentation of county-operated or contracted programs that is updated on a monthly basis, which currently exists on websites not built on Chorus. This frustrates and confuses users since the most up-to-date information lives on directories that are less visible and have less useful search/filter functionality.
 Constraints
 OC HCA shall determine fields with QMS.

 Dependencies
 üìå Stakeholders

 Requirements
 Milestones
 What features will be included in MVP vs subsequent releases? 
 Milestone 1: MVP
 Milestone 2:

 Nice to have:
 Nice to have:

 Out of scope
 List any related features that won't be addressed, or will possibly be part of another track of work. 
 Files
 Description 
 Author 
 Link 

 üôã‍‚ôÄÔ∏è Questions
 Question 
 Blocker (y/n)? 
 Answer 
 Answerer 
 Answered on 

 When the new information is added, how and by whom will those resources be continually updated? Is OC Navigator replacing those directories, or just displaying the same information?

 The MHRS Directory includes individual providers as well as the larger organizations/programs. Do we need to list all of these people, and if so, how do we need to approach this?
 Ex: https://www.ochealthcareagency.com/mhp/38652-bryson-carrie-sudrc-laguna-hills 

 Terminology
 Helpful resource → OC Amendment 3 Common Terms and Definitions 
 Term 
 Definition 

 Resource 
 A resource is a form of support available for OC residents to find and connect with assistance in different areas of their lives, including health, wellbeing and other supportive services. In the OC Navigator, there are two types of resources and this organization impacts how the information is organized and presented to site visitors: 
 Services: Involve interacting with an organization, service provider, or another human being. These may require a referral or a recommendation. 
 Examples: Hospitals, food banks, telehealth providers, and hotlines. 

 Online (digital): Can be accessed online, anytime, and do not require a referral or recommendation. 
 Examples: PDF toolkits, articles, and websites that focus on educating. 

 County-operated or County-contracted Programs 
 These are OC HCA-provided resources that include mental wellness, substance use, housing, supportive employment programs. The accuracy of this information is under higher scrutiny because they receive state funding and are required to list additional details like NPI number, ADA compliance and license numbers. 
 Examples: Program for Assertive Community Treatment (PACT), and Collaborative Courts. 

 Resources not overseen by OC HCA include other government programs like OCTA or private organizations like the AARP or the Salvation Army.

 Referral Only Program 
 Resources where community members must be referred by a program or provider to receive supportive services. These programs may not be visible to the general public.

 Self-Referral 
 Resources where community members are able to call and refer themselves for supportive services, without assistance from another program or provider.

 Referral 
 When a client is given a recommendation in writing to a specific service provider for care and treatment.

 Recommendation 
 The process of providing a participant with one or more suggested resources, without plans and/or an ability to follow up on linkage status.

 Linkage 
 Client is admitted to or participates at least once in the treatment to which they were referred. 

 Closed Loop Referral 
 Referring and receiving providers are able to track the status of a referral and confirm client status between both providers.

 Referrals and Linkages Module 
 A system of features within Chorus products that allows apps to receive, track, manage and send referrals to other apps.
 The current list of OC products set to use this module (as of 8/22/2023) is: CRP, O&E Expansion, CSU, CAT, IHCS and OC Links

 üíø Dataset Fields 
 Field 
 Definition and example 

 Category 
 An organizational field that splits up resources by the type of support provided. OC Navigator has 11 categories that allow for multi-select. OC Links has 13 options that are single select.
 Example: Mental wellness 

 Subcategory 
 A proposed additional organizational field within a category.
 Example: Under the money category, housing fees. 

 Resource Type 
 Currently, this field describes where a resource is classes in the existing, outdated Behavioral Health Systems (BHS) structure in OC Links, Warmline, others? OC HCA has expressed an interest in revamping the options for this field. It is currently unclear if they would like to keep record of this outdated BHS structure in the database.
 Example: 

 Search Hint 
 OC Navigator metadata assigned to resources that gets referenced by search to populate results. Created based on the resource name, description, eligibility, language, categories, hours, and keywords. 
 Example: 

 Keyword 
 Pre-defined groupings of search hints created with subject matter experts (SMEs). These are assigned by staff who add and edit resources through the Resource Entry Portal and OC Navigator site visitors can view them on the resource detail page, under "Eligibility."
 Example: A resource tagged with "autism" will be assigned the search hints "autism, autism spectrum, aspergers, is my child autistic, testing for autism".

title: Chorus Apps & Roles for Orange County
content:
Purpose/Use of All Chorus Apps for Orange County
 OC Links
 The OC Links app facilitates core work functions for staff to manage, triage incoming calls and chats, and connect OC residents to appropriate behavioral health and social services.
 Crisis Assessment Team (CAT) Dispatch
 The CAT app facilitates core work functions for supervisors to dispatch and coordinate clinicians in the field and for clinicians to update their dispatch status and call outcomes.
 Crisis Stabilization Unit (CSU) Bed Board
 The CSU app facilitates core work functions for CSU staff to see referrals and update the referral statuses to coordinate care across the four CSUs and show bed availability to clinicians and law enforcement, increasing timely access to care.
 Outreach & Engagement (O&E)
 The O&E app has two components: O&E Admin includes modules that enable supervisors to assign referrals from OC Links to outreach workers in the field. O&E Mobile serves the needs of the field staff so that they can receive notifications of assignments, track their progress on a case, and document case outcomes.
 Outreach & Engagement Universal Activity Form (UAF) Survey
 The O&E UAF is a form that the O&E outreach staff uses to take a census of homeless encampments in the county.
 OC Navigator
 The OC Navigator is a resource navigation website that helps community members and providers find mental health and social services that can address their needs. Various features support users' journey to care: a social needs questionnaire identifies what a user may need and recommends resources; community-curated resource guides provide actionable steps and resources for specific topics; and users can connect to programs with contact information that is regularly updated.
 Explanation of Chorus Roles
 Each Chorus role gives a user access to a certain app, and allows for certain permissions within that app. See table below for details.
 Explanation of the Permissions Each Role Provides

title: RingCentral Technical Supporting Documentation
content:
Background
 Prior to engaging with Chorus, Warmline set up a "CRM" system with iCarol. As of Fall 2023, Chorus intends to replace iCarol as that "CRM" system for housing all participant information instead. The provided proposal below outlines iCarol's proposed integration strategy with Nice, a partner of RingCentral for the product Warmline is using for their call system.
 Information Shared with Warmline from iCarol
 I have been assigned to help you setup up Telephony Integration in your system. While we can certainly meet to help clarify any questions you may have after you have reviewed this ticket, Telephony Integration is actually very straight forward. Please read the contents of this ticket carefully and reply to the action items outlined below.
 Before we go too much further into the setup details, I'd like to start by telling you how telephony integration works.
 Telephony Integration works by your Telephony Provider sending a specific URL (that I will provide below) populated with certain values gathered from the incoming phone call. Your Telephony Provider will then send that URL to the desk of the agent routed an incoming call, where your agent will then be presented with a new iCarol Contact Report Form open on their screen and that form is populated with those values gathered from the incoming call. At that point your agent would work the call as normal and then would submit the iCarol Contact Report Form.
 In order for a value to populate onto the iCarol Contact Report Form, that information that has to be gathered from the actual incoming call by your Telephony system before being routed to the agent. Most commonly these values are things like Phone Number from Caller ID, Incoming Phone Line that was called, and any keypress options setup by your Telephony System, such as "for English Press 1" or "Please key in your 5 digit zip code". 
 Each of these are VALUES that can then populate onto the iCarol Contact Report Form. How they get into the form is through the URL string.
 Please carefully review each of the following Action Items and reply to this ticket with your updated information and any questions you may have. 
 Action Items:
 Consider what other pieces of information you gather through your telephone system about a call that you would like to populate onto the Contact Report Form. For instance, if you want "Incoming Line" that was rang to populate onto the form, where on your Contact Report Form would that information go? Most commonly you will have (or will need to add) a drop down list on your form that is for "Incoming Line" - so that when a new form opens up, the "Incoming Line" question is already selected. 

 Review the linked Telephony Integration Knowledge Base Article and attached Telephony Document to further understand what other "Standard Fields" can populate onto an iCarol Contact Report Form through this process. 

 For now you will see in the URL string below that I have included "ani=VALUE" When VALUE is replaced with a phone number from caller ID. That Phone Number will be entered onto the Contact Report Form. Again consider what other VALUES from a call that could be populated into the Contact Report Form and reply to this ticket with other items you would like included . I will add that to your URL string and send that back to you for you to forward onto your provider.

 Please reply to this ticket with the name of your Telephony Provider 

 If you use caller Profiles, do you want to automatically populate a caller profile onto a new form when the caller ID matches the phone number of Profile in your iCarol system?

 Template URL to give to your Telephony Provider- once we set up the feature
 Below is the template URL that you need to provide to your Telephony Provider, where they replace VALUE with the phone number from the caller ID.
 https://services.icarol.com/telephony.asmx/GetCallReport?reportVer=#####&ani=VALUE 
 iCarol Telephony Integration
 October 13, 2021

title: PRD - OC Links and CAT R&L PRD
content:
1 6 false list false Chorus team 
 PM: Addie for requirements

 PM: Shane for design and delivery

 Project Manager: Sarah

 Design: Dan 

 SAs: TBD 

 QA: TBD

 Timeline 
 See Project Plan 

 Figma file 

 Client impacts 
 R&L will ultimately affect all OC Products

 Client deadline 

 Before we begin: a note on terminology (from CRP & R&L PRD)
 Term 
 Definition 

 Referral 
 When a client is given a recommendation in writing to a specific service provider for care and treatment

 Linkage 
 Client participates at least once in the treatment to which they were referred. Since CRPs are residential stays, "Linkage" has been defined as when the client is admitted to the service

 Closed Loop Referral 
 Referring and receiving providers are able to track the status of a referral and confirm client status between both providers

 Problem statement
 The focus of this initiative is aimed at OC Links Navigators, CAT Clinicians, and associated management users, targeting the following challenges:
 The current referral process between OC Programs is inefficient and relies on fax, phone calls and emails. This results in communication gaps and delays in placing individuals in suitable programs

 There is a lack of visibility into how many referrals are successfully accepted and linked across the county

 Objective
 Create a system that allows OC Links and CAT Clinicians to receive, manage, and send referrals to other OC programs (both county contracted and county operated). This includes the ability to: 
 Receive and manage incoming referrals

 Send and track outgoing referrals

 Broader Context
 OC Links and CAT will be the 2nd and 3rd programs to include the Referrals & Linkages (R&L) module (a module designed to send and receive referrals digitally across the county). CRP is the first program
 As additional programs are onboarded onto the R&L module, OC Links and CAT will be able to digitally send and receive more referrals through Chorus 

 In the short term, they will only be able to digitally send and receive referrals to CRPs and will have to manually send referrals in other ways

 Sharon would like the initial focus of R&L to be on the crisis system of care which includes: 
 CRPs (new system) - 1st R&L program 

 CAT - 2nd R&L program (already built, but need to add R&L module)

 OC Links - 3rd R&L program (already built, but need to add R&L module)

 CSUs - 4th R&L program (already built, but will need to be updated to be consistent with the CRP experience including adding the R&L module)

 IHCS (new system) 

 O&E (new mobile dispatch system) - Led in a separate initiative by JJ that will include the R&L module to reduce any retrofits down the road

 Personas
 OC Links Service Chief (Tim) 
 Goals: Tim wants his Navigators to be able to help their clients and be able to document all necessary information frictionlessly in Chorus

 Motivations: Tim cares about understanding at a high-level how many referrals that his Navigators make are being accepted and linked

 Frustrations: Tim is frustrated that Chorus can be slow both to update and in performance. He also gets frustrated when things don't work the way he expects them to

 OC Links Navigator (Asita) 
 Goals: Asita wants to be able to care for her client

 Motivations: Asita really wants to help clients find ongoing care after their call to OC Links

 Frustrations: Asita is frustrated when she has to spend a lot of time on administrative tasks and can't quickly find information that could help her client

 CAT Clinician (Joe) 
 Goals: Joe wants to very quickly get to the client in the field that is experiencing a crisis and help them get the care they need

 Motivations: Joe wants to be able to help clients find ongoing care to help deal with their crisis and mental health

 Frustrations: Joe is frustrated with all the documentation that he has to do

 Client at OC Links that is referred to CAT - note: clients will not have access to the R&L Module in the short term (Richard) 
 Goals: Richard wants to get help with his mental health crisis so he calls into OC Links

 Motivations: Richard wants to get help with his immediate crisis and be able to have a plan of action after his interaction with CAT

 Frustrations: Richard is frustrated by having to retell his story to different programs in the county. He's also frustrated that the process takes such a long time

 Functional Workflow - Future state
 For most up to date and complete functional workflows please see figma: https://www.figma.com/file/ZehsPRBCvUMmu5b1hqFtXS/Crisis-R%26L-Audit?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=aAV7LKX2EHur58dq-1 
 Critical User Journeys & Requirements
 See Q4 Product Plan for high-level requirements
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_gXk4ybpvtzTAQ8TLvD9MuQJhgkOXULGm_-SKvkQyF8/edit 
 Dependencies
 Data Type 
 Action 
 Status 

 Client 
 Client History - Determine the minimum viable history that all programs will be able to view
 Blocker : IT & Compliance sign off required before turning on automated referrals among OC apps
 Required Milestone Meetings: 
 Requirements meeting with Sharon & Tim ( Sarah to coordinate scheduling) 

 OC IT, Compliance, and Sharon for MHP & DMC client data sharing requirements is being rescheduled. 

 Client data - Updated client demographic field information to be more consistent with PIF
 Starting build

 Chorus Master Client Index Development and Implementation - 
 Chorus Master Client Index (MCI) will be configured within its own Chorus app, allowing program apps the ability to read and write client data and history to a single source of truth

 New apps (CRP) will have the option to be built and connected to the MCI during development. Live apps will need to be refactored to connect them to the MCI (CAT, OC Links, O&E)

 (in progress, completion forecast )

 Connect OCL & CAT to Chorus MCI 

 Referral 
 Outgoing referrals - Referral groups 
 For outgoing referrals, we will want programs to be able to send referrals to a referral group or an individual program within a referral group 
 Individual program: refer to an individual CRP (e.g., previously worked with a CRP, hospital reached out to a CRP directly, etc.)

 Referral group: refer to the Youth CRP Group and the Adult CRP Group, so that multiple programs have the chance to claim a referral

 Action: Therefore, there needs to be two resources added to outgoing referrals:

 Referral / Case History 
 For outgoing and incoming referrals from and to OC Links and CAT, we'll need to consolidate historical (current) Case History data in OC Links with the new Referrals table in the MCI
 Note: This solution for MVP will have to work around the inability to filter across tables (ENG).

 Current Proposal: 
 The objective would be to create a cohesive Referral History experience between OC programs and apps.
 To do so, we'll map the equivalent data from this form for each Case (OC Links) and translate them into new Referral records.
 Destination would be OC Links / CAT / O&E / Any outgoing referrals from OC Links / Any outgoing referrals from CAT.

 Source would be the application that made the referral or N/A when this does not apply.

 Date of Referral and Time of Referral in OC Links for a Resource = Date of Referral and Time of Referral in the Referral database.

 Meeting on 10/18 to create cross- functional alignment between teams (SA, OC Links / CAT, O&E, and others) on this proposal

 Resource Database

 R&L Data Architecture

title: Orange County Cerner Cloud EHR integration to Chorus via Redox PRD
content:
Disclaimer: This doc is an abbreviated version of Redox to Chorus Platform Integration for Connecting to EHRs PRD , tailored to the point of view of Orange County. 
 üëÄ Summary
 Why are we doing this? 
 Orange County uses the Cerner Cloud EHR. Chorus is one platform among many that OC needs to sync data with. 

 What do we expect to accomplish? 
 We aim to create a mechanism whereby Chorus can connect to Orange County's Cerner Cloud EHR (to start), with the capacity to add more of their inherited EHRs over time using the Redox engine.

 Why is it important? 
 Orange County has patient records across a multitude of providers. Providing an integration with Chorus and Cerner Cloud EHR is another step in overall record consolidation and improved record management.

 Chorus team 
 R esponsible 
 Designer: 

 Engineer / SA(s): TBD

 A ccountable
 Product Manager: 

 C onsulted: 
 I nformed: 

 Jira epics 
 CHORUS-5252 a9d3eb4c-c63a-3c77-864c-b5dd8664a020 System JIRA 

 Figma file 
 https://www.figma.com/file/Q3eLUviuK47uiT7pmMqrGM/%5BWIP%5D-Redox-workflows?type=design&node-id=684%3A896&mode=design&t=FbsDL0n16aB8gNo7-1 
 https://www.figma.com/file/rVjSBy7KEWLQb13yTpAg8w/Redox-Workflows?type=design&node-id=127%3A54&mode=design&t=OeUqcmKlzz4OdkF2-1 

 Client impacts 
 OC Master Client Index (MCI)

 OC Links

 OC PEI

 OC Warmline

 OC CRP

 Chorus impacts 

 Client deadline 
 Q1 2024

 Terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 EHR
 Electronic health record ‚Äì a systematized collection of data. Think about it like a database of patients and things that concern them (schedules, medications, procedures, providers, etc.).

 IRIS
 The on-premises version of the OC Cerner EHR. As of Q1 2024 this will be replaced by the Cerner Cloud EHR (technically remote hosted). 

 Cerner Cloud
 The Orange County EHR what will be available in Q1 of 2024.

 Redox
 A tool that helps us make federated EHR connections. Chorus connects to Redox and then Redox can make all the EHR connections we need. https://www.redoxengine.com/ 

 MRN
 Medical Record Number. A medical record number (MRN) is a unique identifier assigned to a patient in an electronic health record (EHR), practice management, or healthcare IT system. The MRN is used to keep track of medical history, diagnoses, treatments, and other important information related to patient care.

 FHIR
 Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources. The FHIR standard defines how healthcare information can be exchanged between different computer systems regardless of how it is stored in those systems. FHIR is the federal law.

 Module
 Orange County's term for referring to a Chorus app.

 Contacts
 Name 
 Title 
 Company 
 Email 
 Role 

 John Vo
 Orange County HCA IT
 Main steward of Cerner IRIS and the transition to Cerner Cloud

 Sharon Ishikawa
 Orange County HCA

 Zara Siddiqui
 Data Analyst
 Orange County HCA
 Works closely with Sharon

 Objective
 Create a connection between Chorus and the Cerner Cloud EHR using the Redox engine to sync applicable data between the two systems.

 OC has other service providers with their own EHRs that they'd eventually want to unify as well.

 Excerpt from the Contract
 HCA DATA INTEGRATION

 Objectives 
 The objective of data integration between Contractor and the HCA EHRs is to facilitate streamlined data entry and workflows for County program staff, reduce duplicated administrative efforts among county providers utilizing various client management systems (IRIS, Microsoft Excel, Microsoft Access, Contractor digital solutions, etc.), improve data integrity among integrated systems, and improve continuity of care for County residents utilizing County services.
 The objective of other data integration efforts, including integration with various third-party tools and enterprise data warehouses (EDWs), is to ensure efficiency in digital solution execution by leveraging third-party functionality, ensure alignment with MHRS service delivery goals, and ensure accuracy among County data through connection with pertinent data sources.
 Modules/Workflows 
 Facilitate a bidirectional feed of information between Contractor solutions and the HCA EDW . This will require the ability to both read and write between the HCA EDW and Contractor digital solutions.

 Explore integration with OC systems for client data that are not entered into a HCA EHR (e.g., resource referrals)

 [See also https://docs.google.com/document/d/1U_5rfmkJA68PHgFU3TNPlxaq2PwimetcPFiP7TEle1Q/edit page 17 .]
 Broader Context
 See Redox to Chorus Platform Integration for Connecting to EHRs PRD for more information.
 Key User Stories
 As an (authorized) author, I want to map applicable Chorus data to applicable Cerner Cloud EHR data.

 As a client or author, if I update patient data in Chorus, I want that data also updated in my Cerner Cloud record.

 As an author, if patient data is updated in the EHR, I want that data also updated in Chorus.

 As a data owner, I want to see what Chorus apps have access to certain fields in the EHR. 

 Success metrics
 Goal Type 
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Business
 Chorus can integrate with the Cerner Cloud EHR.
 Patient information more accurate, easier to maintain, and synced across different systems.

 Constraints
 Currently, the Orange County Cerner Cloud system is actively being built and existing records from the IRIS Cerner (an onprem server) are being migrated. The target completion date by Orange County is Q1 2024.

 Chorus will only be mapping data that exists at the time Cerner Cloud becomes available.

 As soon as it's available, Orange County will provide Chorus with Cerner Cloud Integrations or Cerner Cloud UAT EHR access to begin connection efforts.

 Chorus must pass Cerner certifications for integration.

 Our solution must adhere to Security, Privacy, and Compliance rules, standards, and best practices.

 Chorus will only sync data to Cerner Cloud that is supported by the 5 predetermined Data Models from Redox, or for which a FHIR Extension exists: 
 https://developer.redoxengine.com/data-models/PatientAdmin.html 

 https://developer.redoxengine.com/data-models/PatientSearch.html 

 https://developer.redoxengine.com/data-models/Referral.html 

 https://developer.redoxengine.com/data-models/Notes.html 

 https://developer.redoxengine.com/data-models/Scheduling.html 

 Orange County and Chorus will need to identify a system for Patient Matching.
 In scope (but needs discovery) : Leverage the existing OC patient matching solution. 
 MRNs will backfill as patient records are updated in the EHR.

 Will involve a level of data migration effort.

 Out of scope : Use a tool like Verato to handle patient matching. (We would like to pitch this investment once we have more research.) 

 Requirements
 Orange County will collaborate with the Chorus team to provide an accurate data mapping of fields in Chorus with fields in the Cerner Cloud EHR. This mapping will outline the fields that should:
 Sync between the two systems.

 Be read, write, or both.

 Data will sync in real time. 

 Milestones
 Milestone 1: MVP
 Milestone 2: 
 Milestone 3: 

 Release Blockers
 Must have feature 1 

 Must have feature 2 

 Release Blockers:
 Ability to send data to custom fields in Cerner?

 Release Blockers: 
 Ability to send/receive Scheduling-related data.

 Should have
 Desired feature 1 

 Desired feature 2 

 Should have:
 Should have:

 Nice to have
 Bonus feature 1 

 Bonus feature 2 

 Nice to have:
 Nice to have:

 Out of scope
 Scheduling . Chorus will not provide any data syncing for Scheduling needs until a Chorus app (i.e. OC module) exists with this functionality with clearly defined scope. (We anticipate such a project will not be available until after Q1 2024.) The only scope known to date: 
 Ability to schedule appointments from Chorus apps into providers.

 They will need the ability to read in the EHR schedule. A potential workaround for writing back could be for the user to call to officially schedule. We would need to confirm this viability of this approach.

 Orange County shared they would like for users to schedule an appointment in clinics using the IRIS EHR. This would be part of the outgoing referral workflow for the Referrals & Linkages app .

 Advanced Patient Matching . At this time, Verato, an advanced patient matching tool and partner company to Redox, is excluded from this scope of work. Chorus will present research demonstrating the pros and cons to Orange County to make an educated decision whether or not this should be included in the initial scope of work. Until this, this is expressly excluded.

 Files
 Description 
 Author 
 Link 

 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1fe2ZV8k4i0mVFu6UnENabaJgKarfcvyl6baOjo7J2rA/edit#gid=1758898685 

 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/17t9wEZwEGe8io4uFtEyjuiyyfly-14ih3HQXg8gDFco/edit#gid=0 

 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/178TQAbo-Nu9xqz-N0lzSLtn4Ij9rNI9SQRCn1rGiZJU/edit#gid=429647645 

 OC Navigator Variables (coming soon)

 OC CRP (coming soon)

 MCI (coming soon)

 Critical Questions
 Question 
 Blocker (y/n)? 
 Answer 
 Answerer 
 Answered on 

 How does Orange County want to address patient matching between Chorus and Cerner Cloud? 
 In scope: Create an MRN field in Chorus and create a rudimentary process to match those records 1:1.

 Out of scope: Use an advanced tool like Verato for Patient Matching. Pricing pending.

 Y

 How does Orange County want Chorus to sync their data?

 Requires further investigation

title: CARE Court PRD
content:
1 6 false list false Chorus team 
 PM: Thai, Maddie

 Project Manager: Mike V.

 Clin Sol: Michelle Young Sambajon

 TPM: Jason Lunde

 Design: TBD

 SAs: TBD

 QA: TBD

 Timeline 
 Q1 MVP 

 Figma file 
 https://www.figma.com/design/0ANXJLg1HDznVQEdkwQagn/CARE-Court?node-id=3-665&node-type=canvas&t=yBa7ud0OwESalm3b-0 

 Client impacts 
 MHRS Care Court Staff

 Client deadline 
 A working app by March 30, 2024

 Before we begin: a note on terminology 
 Term 
 Definition 

 CARE Act 
 Community Assistance, Recovery, and Empowerment (CARE) Act is a new civil process that authorizes specified adults to petition a civil court to create a court-ordered CARE plan for persons with untreated schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders.

 Petitioner 
 The person who files the petition on behalf of the respondent. This person can also be the respondent themselves.

 Respondent 
 The person who needs more intensive care. There are basic eligibility criteria this person must meet. 

 Hearing 
 A court hearing where the petitioner and respondent answers questions from the CARE Court team, including OC judges, so they can determine eligibility and progress in the CARE Court system 

 Problem statement
 The focus of this initiative is to support a brand new process undertaken by OC HCA CARE Court staff, including MHRS representatives in the hearings and MHRS case management staff that includes:
 a new way to intake CARE Act clients 

 a way track outreach conducted by MHRS staff to engage the respondent/client

 Currently, staff are using a spreadsheet to track this data. 
 Objective
 Create a system that allows CARE Court staff to intake new clients with PEI PIF fields and track staff outreach efforts. This includes the ability to: 
 Intake new clients with PEI PIF fields and additional fields related to the Court petition

 Track outreach and engagement efforts such as time stamps and notes related to each outreach

 In future iterations, this system would be connected to the larger Referral and Linkages system to refer clients to services in MHRS.
 Broader Context
 CARE Act was implemented October 2, 2023. CARE Act is a new process in California to help persons with untreated schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorders to provide them with behavioral health and other essential resources and services. OC is one of the first counties to implement the CARE Act.

 When a Petitioner submits a petition (via drop-in, mail, or online), an OC Courts Judge will review the petition and determine if the Respondent's needs meet the basic requirements of the CARE Act. 
 A petition is a packet of documents that includes the petition, a Mental Health Declaration, and possibly other needed documents. 

 If the Respondent meets the criteria, the Judge will assign HCA to complete a report and will appoint a Public Defender to represent the Respondent. 

 Once HCA has completed the report, the Judge reviews the report and determines whether to move forward to develop a care plan. 

 The care plan for a Respondent must be approved and ordered by the Court. The plan is subject to Court modification before approval.

 See figures below for the OC process. This flowchart was created by CARE Court staff. Source deck here: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/19wwq9tu49StagZSOtIWYSIfbhC22MDPb/edit#slide=id.p1 
 Visit the official website for more information: https://www.courts.ca.gov/48654.htm 
 Personas
 MHRS CARE Court Staff 
 Goals: Intake and track client throughout CARE Court process

 Motivations: I want an organized and easy way to intake clients, find their file and update their status for the year they are participating in CARE court

 Frustrations: I'm using a spreadsheet and it's too easy for clients to fall through the cracks or for me to forget to follow up

 Functional Workflow - Future state
 Critical User Journeys & Requirements
 Design 
 Align with new OC branding (O&E, CRP etc)

 Product 
 Client Dashboard
 Create New Petition (redirect to client intake)

 Client Search
 Case number, first name, last name

 Client Intake
 CARE Court-specific fields

 PIF

 Monthly CARE Status Survey
 CARE Court-specific fields

 Data 
 Clients will be stored in MCI

 CARE Court data will be kept in separate table (similar to the way O&E is structured)

 Out of Scope

 Files
 https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1gqkvDoB8NALNhk3J2oKdWNgj_S9sTbeW 
 Open Questions 
 Question 
 Answer 
 Team to ask

title: EDW Integration ‚Äì¬†Delivery of Chorus App Data to OC Databricks
content:
Orange County uses Databricks as their Enterprise Data Warehouse (EDW). They primarily use it as a tool for generating data analytics, reports, etc. 
 As of November 2023, Chorus delivers app data exports for various OC programs (i.e. OC Links, CAT Dispatch, O&E, etc.) directly to Databricks via SFTP. (See Databricks (an EDW and lakehouse) ‚Äì Chorus + Databricks SFTP Connections for technical details on how this delivery method works.)
 Requesting Variables for Export to Databricks
 See Data Exports ‚Äì New Requests .

 At this time, the expectation is that Chorus provides the full date range of requested variables for export (instead of the last 14 days of data for example) as Databricks is able to easily surface changed data between exports.

title: SUD - R&L Background and Overview
content:
Chorus team 
 PM: Thai

 Project Manager: Mike

 Design: Dan

 Research: Angelina

 SAs: Katy

 QA: TBD

 Timeline 
 UAT by end of Q1

 Roadmap 
 TBD

 Jira epics 
 TBD

 Figma file 
 TBD

 Problem
 Complex SUD referral pathways require multiple processes and steps for clients . This causes clients to get lost in the system without receiving care.

 Referrals require providers to send each other multiple back and forth communications , taking time away from client care.

 Delayed treatment per client results also results in higher costs related to poor clinical outcomes and readmissions 

 Personas
 Client (Richard) 
 Goals: Richard wants to work on his mental health by staying at Phoenix House

 Clinicians (Leon) 
 Goals: Leon wants to be able to care for his client and help clients find ongoing care after their stay at Phoenix House

 Intake Coordinators (Cindy) 
 Goals: Cindy wants to ensures that incoming referrals for SUD services are easily manageable

 Authorization team (ART) service chief (Glenn) 
 Goals: Glenn wants to ensure that all requests to authorize referrals are done quickly but also accurately.

 Before we begin: a note on terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 Drug Medi-Cal Organized Delivery System (DMC-ODS) 
 The Drug Medi-Cal Organized Delivery System (DMC-ODS) provides a continuum of care modeled after the American Society of Addiction Medicine (ASAM) Criteria for substance use disorder (SUD) treatment services, enables more local control and accountability, provides greater administrative oversight, creates utilization controls to improve care and efficient use of resources, implements evidenced based practices in SUD treatment, and coordinates with other systems of care.
 Source: https://www.dhcs.ca.gov/provgovpart/Pages/Drug-Medi-Cal-Organized-Delivery-System.aspx 

 American Society of Addiction Medicine (ASAM) 
 Established in 1954, ASAM is a distinguished medical society that encompasses more than 7,500 physicians, clinicians, and related professionals who specialize in addiction medicine. DMC-ODS is modeled after ASAM Criteria for SUD services
 The ASAM Criteria Assessment Interview Guide from DHCS 

 Bed Board (aka Bed Availability Board) 
 Shows availability at different programs, so that referrers (e.g., Police, CAT Team, etc.) know if they can refer a client to a program

 Referral 
 When a client is given a recommendation in writing to a specific service provider for care and treatment

 Linkage 
 Client participates at least once in the treatment to which they were referred. Since CRPs are residential stays, "Linkage" has been defined as when the client is admitted to the service

 Closed Loop Referral 
 Referring and receiving providers are able to track the status of a referral and confirm client status between both providers

 Authorization for Residential Treatment (ART) 
 BHS staff responsible for authorizing residential treatment. ART team staff are healthcare professionals with appropriate clinical expertise in treating the beneficiary's/client's condition or disease

 Authorization 
 The approval process for DMC-ODS services prior to the submission of a DMC-ODS claim

 Withdrawal Management 
 Services are offered in residential, non-institutional, non-medical withdrawal management programs that utilize a social model detox system, for a maximum of seven (7) days to help beneficiaries during the non-acute detoxification process. Acute withdrawal management services are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Steps down to SUD residential where they stay for 30 days, from residential treatment go to outpatient services for as long as they need

 Residential Treatment 
 Residential treatment substance use and/or co-occurring mental health treatment program for up to 90 days. Program addresses behaviors and emotions behind addiction. Treatment includes individual therapy, group therapy, and education about addiction. It is a non-institutional, 24-hour non-medical, short-term residential program that provides rehabilitation services when determined as medically necessary. Residential services require prior authorization by the County Plan. Each authorization for residential services can be for a maximum of 90 days for adults and 30 days for youth. Only two authorizations for residential services are allowed in a one-year-period.

 Recovery Residence 
 The Outpatient Recovery program is designed for adults ages 18 and older who are living with a serious mental illness and possible co-occurring substance use disorder. The program is operated at multiple locations throughout the county, with County-contracted locations referred to as Recovery Centers and County-operated locations referred to as Recovery Clinics. Individuals are referred to the program by Plan Coordinators in the Adult and Older Adult Behavioral Health (AOABH) Outpatient Clinics after all emergent mental health issues have resolved. This typically occurs within the first 3 to 6 months of being opened in an AOABH clinic. Individuals are referred to the contracted Recovery Centers after they have been in the AOABH outpatient system of care for one year and have remained out of the hospital or jail, are stable on their medication regimen and have consistently attended their appointments.

 42 CFR Part 2
 Federal regulation 42 CFR Part 2 requires providers to obtain patient consent before sharing information about treatment for substance use disorders with other providers.

 Goals
 Ensure timely access to care for SUD services to clients

 Reduce the administrative burden related to phone calls and data entry to support referrals

 note EQRO metrics to define timely access to services
 SUD Residential/Outpatient: 10 days

 SUD Withdrawal Management: 48 hours

 EQRO metrics to define timely access to services
 SUD Residential/Outpatient: 10 days

 SUD Withdrawal Management: 48 hours

 Success metrics
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Ensure timely access to care for SUD services to clients
 Time from referral request to appointment offered 

 Time from referral request to appointment accepted

 Time from referral request to linkage

 No show rate

 Vacancy rate

 Reduce the administrative burden related to phone calls and data entry to support referrals
 Reduce # of emails sent between SUD programs

 Removal of excel bedboard tracking sheets

 Staff satisfaction 

 User Research Synthesis
 UXR efforts
 1 - In person shadowing session with the ART team

 1 - Referrals and Linkages Workshop with SUD and Housing (OC kickoff)

 2 - Deep Dive interview sessions with the ART team on residential treatment and residential recovery workflows

 3 - Deep Dive Interview Sessions with RT and RR providers (upcoming) 

 Notable Quotes
 "Each provider emails an excel sheet every morning showing their bed availability. If somebody's out, it could be forgotten. The further out from the date of receipt, it becomes less and less accurate" 

 "We currently has very little access to client information, despite the fact that they come "internally" from other HCA programs" 

 "Real-time bed board and bed availability would be huge" 

 Functional Workflow - Future state
 https://www.figma.com/board/oGTAphU2e8dfx7It6nBfjh/SUD-R%26L-Chorus-User-Flow?node-id=124-4986&node-type=canvas&t=zztKmIzd6cqIvn1M-0 
 High Level Workflows that need to be supported:
 Referral source → ART Team referral approval → Residential Treatment Admission and Bed Assignment→ Residential Treatment Discharge

 Referral source → HCA Gatekeeper approval → Recovery Residence Admission and Bed Assignment → Recovery Residence Discharge

 Priority Population → Residential Treatment Admission and Bed Assignment→ Residential Treatment Discharge

 Early Prototype created by Ellie to support OC kickoff meeting

 https://www.figma.com/design/n6po0F6uCQ9hajmgpajFgH/SUD-R%26L-prototype?node-id=0-1&t=712Djd9TlpK72W1L-0 
 High Level Product Features 
 Allow programs involved in the current SUD care pathway (ART, Withdrawal management, residential treatment centers, and recovery residences) the ability to digitally send each other referrals. Functionalities that are needed would be
 Send a referral to an SUD-related program

 Receive/record a referral incoming into an SUD related program

 Forwarding a referral to the appropriate destination based on review

 Viewing bed availability and assigning bed availability

 Utilizing attached client assessment forms for guidance on referrals

 Updating the status of a referral

 Permissions
 42 CFR Part 2 requires providers to obtain patient consent before sharing information about treatment for substance use disorders with other providers. For each referral into SUD services, an ATD must be filled out which specifies which organizations will receive, disclose, and exchange information. 

 The ART ATD specifies a list of providers that will be able to receive information, but it's possible that the client might remove a few from the list.

 Feature Priorities
 Must Have Features 
 Feature 
 Justification 

 Referral Dashboards
 Users need a view to see incoming referrals to determine which they need to address

 Creating and forwarding new referrals
 ART team and Providers need the ability to create new referrals when requested from referral sources and send to different groups 

 Attaching documents to referrals
 Attachments are needed to support first iteration of ATD's and ASAM's

 Live bedboard availability and bed assignment
 Main cause of administrative task overload is constant communication of excel sheets. A live bed availability bedboard significantly reduces administrative work.

 Compliance to ATD permissions (non-digitized)
 Referrals need to be only viewable by programs listed in the signed ATD. 

 Placement lists
 ART team needs a method to track which clients are approved for treatment and simply need a bed assigned.

 Live Status Tracking
 Users need to see the history of the referral, including changes to status, notes from other providers, and linkage information.

 Should Have Features 
 Feature 
 Justification 

 Email and SMS Notifications
 Allows programs to quickly respond to incoming referrals sent to their dashboard. Referrals can be supported without notifications but this requires users to view dashboard multiple times within a day.

 Edit Client/Referral 
 Allows users to keep and client and referral data up-to-date if there are any changes

 Nice to Have Features 
 Feature 
 Justification 

 Activity Log
 Detailed list of changes made to referrals and referral fields in a historical view. LOE is high and status tracking should ensure all mandatory activities are captured.

 Print
 Allows users to have referrals documented outside of Chorus. Not crucial to current workflows found in UXR.

 Live/Digitized TAR review updates
 Pending UXR research 

 Future Roadmap (currently out of scope for initial launch)
 Feature 
 Justification 

 Integrated referrals and bedboards viewable directly on OC links, O&E, CAT, CRP/CSU
 Certain live OC apps (CRP's specifically) commonly send referrals to SUD. However, this workflow can be supported via manual referral creations from the SUD programs for the time being. High risk associated with sensitive information being sent from and to SUD clinics due to 42 CFR regulations. 

 Future bedboard projections/availability 
 UXR revealed that current referral and bed management workflows do not account for future bedboard projections. Not needed for current launch, but would be great addition after initial launch to offer appointments/intake dates earlier.

 Administrative/supervisor views
 Reports on referral tracking analytics as well as overview screens for multiple programs. Risk associated with sensitive information due to 42 CFR regulations. Feature is not needed to support initial workflow digitization.

 Guest portal
 Multiple referral sources into SUD programs are not slated to use Chorus. Provision of a guest portal allows the ART team to reduce the amount of referrals to generate on Chorus. Risk associated here with sensitive 42 CFR regulations as well as ambiguity regarding adoption of a guest portal. 

 Completely digitized ATD 
 UXR revealed that OC does not deal with client requests for custom ATD permissions (IE: asking that only certain clinics receive information). Current practice is to sign off ATD which allows all programs to have access regardless of destination. High LOE from dev team as well.

 Next Steps
 Utilize UXR sessions to start collaborative design process with stakeholders utilizing design prototypes

 Create detailed plans for usability tests (can we fit design prototypes, alpha testing, beta testing, AND UAT before release)

 Continue continuous UXR process throughout stakeholder interviews

 Files
 Relevant Documents:
 SUD Linkage Form https://drive.google.com/file/d/1RjXKx8POEnxPBrCE9ELF3IcpknKC9J8j/view?usp=sharing 

 Brief SUD LOC form: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1CaUP3ZRKjvo9jO2TGzMKKzRb1jMLsHEg/view?usp=sharing 

 ART ATD form https://drive.google.com/file/d/1kXkOgWjOSjVvhV7XtiWkaPdLfICtU8Ch/view?usp=sharing 

 Drive with all other documents: 

 Critical User Journeys & Requirements
 https://www.figma.com/board/z7sujV1UzeUaXk05KjHbL6/SUD-Residential-Treatment-and-Recovery-Residence-Documentation?node-id=38-155&t=JDQEVlnb0WW8A5ei-4 

 Dependencies & Questions
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1SNg_tK3YtBdoVkLO7TJhd9NSVOo9i8E3KV72PPoMlDE/edit#heading=h.8orveys5vviv 

 Client List & Permissions 
 Can we have one client list across all SUD programs?

 Can we have one client list across all MHRS Programs & SUD Programs?
 Which programs (both county operated and county contracted) from MHRS are allowed to see SUD clients? Which programs from MHRS are allowed to see SUD history?

 How much information should SUD programs be able to see from other SUD Programs and from MHRS programs?

 What is a program receives a referral for a client that they do not have access do, should they create a new client?

 Are there any special requirements for Youth permissions?

 R&L Data Architecture
 Please click here to view data architecture needs: R&L Data Architecture . This includes: 
 Client and referral data
 OC Links, CAT, O&E, CRP, CSU all share the same client list but OC Warmline and PEI do not

 Resource data

 Statuses: Will use current statues used in universal referral portals.

title: RingCentral/Nice InContact screen pop testing
content:
Background
 Instead of integrating with RingCentral/Nice InContact via API, we decided to go with the screen pop as this is a simpler approach versus using the RC/Nice API, which could lead to delays in connecting both systems. This page focuses on the outstanding issue we'd like to escalate to Engineering, which was tested internally on 1/9 after RCs initial testing and successfully provisioning Chorus with an RC/NICE test account. 
 Test steps and outstanding issue for Eng
 In order to test the screen pop setup, we completed the following steps:
 Set up screen pop parameter in the OC Warmline app at https://www.chorusplatform.io/m/oc-warmline to be able to take calls from RC/Nice ( see user story ) 

 RC team provisioned Chorus with a RC/Nice test account at https://na1.nice-incontact.com/apps/#/myprofile/ ( mayra@joinchorus.com ; contact for pw) 

 Once 1 & 2 were in place, we completed the following test (Note: RC team tested on Windows, Chrome; Chorus team tested on Mac, Sonoma and both got the same results) :
 Logged in to Chorus Warmline app https://www.chorusplatform.io/m/oc-warmline 

 Logged in to RC https://na1.nice-incontact.com/login/ 
 Selected Max agent and set up Warmline's RC/Nice inContact test number 442-204-1504

 Set myself as available

 Project Overview 
 Project Overview & Objective 
 MVP 
 Project Resources 
 Project Phase 
 Forecast 

 Overview: 
 Chorus will build a tool to streamline Treatment Authorization Request (TAR) processing by:
 Invoking key user groups in OCHCA, hospitals, and Carelon

 Address issues such as inefficient communication, time consuming paper-based processes, lack of TAR status visibility, cumbersome data collection

 Goals :
 Reduce the need for paper TAR packets

 Decrease the amount of time spent processing a TAR

 Decrease mistakes and oversights in processing a TAR

 Decrease the number of deferrals and appeals

 Increase the speed of accurate payment to hospitals

 Streamline access to TAR data for outcome reporting

 Risk Mitigation: 3 weeks of emergency buffer room included in forecast dates
 TAR Packet Portal (Hospitals) 
 A portal where hospital staff can create a client and enter necessary medical documentation for processing TARs. This feature will ensure that all required information is included in the TAR packet and prevent unnecessary documents from being included in packets sent to HCA.
 TAR Packet Portal (OCHCA) 
 A portal where OCHCA staff can confirm receipt of a TAR and view TAR documents submitted by the hospital. Staff will be able to perform their review in Chorus, assign the TAR to a reviewer, input TAR data, and store the TAR.

title: Treatment Authorization Request PRD
content:
Chorus team 
 Product Manager: Thai Nguyen

 Program Manager: Mayra Solano

 Technical Project Manager: Jason Lunde

 Design: Jacob Heer

 Research: Angelina Majeno

 Lead SA: Christy Lee

 Roadmap 
 https://chorusapp.atlassian.net/jira/polaris/projects/CLIENTRM/ideas/view/7028954 

 Figma file 
 https://www.figma.com/design/MeUODRNfm3LtVaGz8Wl0ci/TAR---Design-File-02--R4-~-Current-?node-id=9293-172212&p=f&t=GZCkyDhT87sT9dd8-0 

 Client impacts 
 OCHCA
 OC Hospitals
 Carelon (OC Contractor)

 Client deadline 
 Go-Live by August 2025

 What is TAR?
 Treatment Authorization Requests (TARs) are a DHCS process for approving reimbursement costs to service providers for Medi-Cal beneficiaries. A TAR is created when a client is discharged after receiving services for inpatient hospitalization.
 User Research Synthesis 
 Pre-build research: 
 2 hospital shadowing sessions

 3 OC HCA shadowing sessions

 Product beta testing: 
 2 hospital sessions

 2 OC HCA sessions
 Office Support Staff

 Clinical Staff

 Key Insights: 
 There are different types of TARs, each with different requirements.

 Concurrent review is a key part of the process.

 Hospital users often do not know what is required to submit a TAR. "Tribal knowledge" is invoked, and gives some hospitals an unfair advantage over others.

 Clinical staff in OC look for the same key information consistently, but struggle to get that information from some hospitals.

 Problem 
 The current TAR process is inefficient, outdated, and frustrating for both counties and hospitals. Common challenges include:
 Excessive Documentation: Hospitals often submit more information than necessary, complicating the review process and slowing approvals.

 Inconsistent Submission Methods: Hospitals use varying formats and methods for TAR submissions, creating confusion and inefficiencies.

 Paper-Based Submissions: Many TARs still rely on physical packets, often sent by mail or courier, leading to delays and lost documents.

 Limited Status Transparency: A lack of real-time visibility into TAR status leads to frequent follow-ups between hospitals and county offices, wasting time on both sides.

 All of the above issues mean cumbersome submission and review processes and delayed reimbursement to service providers.
 Personas
 Hospital Case Management Staff: Collect all documentation and submit TAR for discharged clients to receive reimbursement for services.
 OC HCA Office Support Staff: Confirms county receipt of the TAR and ensures client Medi-Cal status. Enters client into database. Assigns to OC Clinician for processing. Additionally, sends payment approval to DHCS.
 OC HCA Clinician: Reviews TARs for medical necessity and eligibility. Approves, defers, or denies payment for providers service delivery depending on audit. 
 Other:
 Carelon (OC Contractor): Perform concurrent review while client is hospitalized to ensure medical necessity and appropriateness of treatment plan. Authorizes or denies service delivery for clients and sends reports to hospitals and OC HCA.
 Terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 Treatment Authorization Request (TAR)
 In the context of our project with OC, a TAR is created when a client is discharged after receiving services for inpatient hospitalization, and is one of the mechanisms in which DHCS (Department of Health Care Services) approve reimbursement costs to the service provider.

 Concurrent Review
 Checking in daily with hospitals to authorize treatment

 Retroactive Review
 After a client's stay in hospital, looking over paperwork to confirm correct authorization of treatment

 Vision 
 The TAR Portal simplifies and digitizes the Treatment Authorization Request process, transforming it into an efficient, transparent platform that streamlines submissions, accelerates processing, and ensures timely reimbursement for Medi-Cal providers.
 Goals
 Eliminate the need for paper TAR packets

 Decrease the amount of time spent processing a TAR

 Decrease the number of deferrals

 Increase the speed of accurate payment to hospitals

 Strategy 
 We will start with county-contracted providers to validate the product's efficacy before expanding out to additional hospitals.

 Success metrics
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Decrease amount of time spent processing a TAR
 Decrease administrative burden for hospitals & OC
 Time from receipt to approval/denial.

 User satisfaction.

 Decrease number of deferrals
 Rate of deferrals for Chorus submissions vs. non-Chorus.

 Increase speed of accurate payment to hospitals
 Time from submission to reimbursement.

 Eliminate need for paper storage
 Percentage of TARs received digitally (in Chorus)

 entered into Chorus by OC users.

 Core Workflow
 https://www.figma.com/board/MWRb5hoHfO2zDtApBswA6N/TAR-Proposal-And-Strategy?node-id=1170-1521&t=uWlLdPFYFfBhsFs5-4 
 Statuses 
 Below are the that will be used for the build. Note that the decision of the TAR is only shown as the "status" for the hospital user while OC HCA will use "complete" no matter what the decision of the TAR is
 Hospital Status 
 Description 

 Draft
 The hospital is assembling the TAR fields with documents

 Sent
 The hospital has sent the TAR over to OC HCA

 Approved
 OC HCA has approved the TAR

 Approved as modified
 OC HCA has approved the TAR, but with some days denied

 Deferred
 OC HCA is requesting more information from OC HCA

 Denied
 OC HCA has denied all requested days

 Archived
 The hospital no longer needs the TAR and wants to remove it from all reporting. This is typically used for testing as well as accidentally created TAR's. 

 OC HCA Status 
 Description 

 Received
 The hospital has just sent a TAR over to OC HCA

 Office Review
 An OC HCA user has started the office review

 Clinical Review
 Office review has been completed and a clinician has been assigned to start the clinical review

 Final Processing
 Clinical review has completed and the office support staff will now check and review the TAR before sending this back to the hospital.

 Complete
 The TAR has been returned back to the hospital.

 Void
 The TAR has been voided and should no longer be recognized. This is important for when a replacement TAR is submitted.

 Feature Priorities
 Note: please see the roadmap in JPD (linked at the top of this document) for the most up-to-date features and descriptions. 
 Must Have 
 Features 
 Description 

 TAR Dashboards (Hospital, OC)
 View all new, in progress, and completed TARs

 Hospital: Create a new TAR
 Enter necessary client + medical documentation for TARs. 

 TAR Details Page
 View all client info and medical documentation.

 TAR Status Tracking
 Track the live status of the TAR while it is being processed

 Office Support: Link TAR to client record
 Link the TAR to a client in the database to allow TAR's to be tracked per client

 Office Support: Review and Decision
 Check to see if all documentation has been added before sending to clinical review

 Clinician: Review & Decision
 Review the TAR and provide a decision for the authorization

 Office Support: Final Processing
 Before sending the review over to hospitals, check the tar one last time.

 Should Have 
 Features 
 Description 

 OC HCA submit TAR on behalf of hospitals
 Allow OCA to submit TAR's for hospitals that are out of network and will not be using TAR's

 E-sign and e-stamp digital TAR forms
 Sign and stamp TAR's digitally to download and send to the state

 Automated deferral and denial (NOABD) letters
 Create generated letters to provide a formal communication to hospitals for decisions

 Re-submit deferred TAR's
 For TAR's that are deferred, allow hospitals to update documents and resubmit.

 Appeal denied TAR's
 Hospital appeals for completed TARs can be submitted through Chorus.

 Nice-To-Have 
 Features 
 Description 

 Generate fax cover sheets
 When TAR's need to be faxed over, create a cover sheet to go on top of any faxed documents

 TUT's
 When a TAR has been submitted to the state, allow users to send a change request.

 Replacement TAR's
 For TAR's that need to be replaced due to changing Medi-cal eligibility, allow TAR's to be submitted that can replace TAR's that should be voided.

 Mark invoices as received
 For unfunded TAR's that have been approved, track when a hospital has sent an invoice.

 Out of scope for launch
 Features 
 Description 

 PDF Parser
 Users can have pdf documents parsed into Chorus fields

 eFax
 Users can eFax the signed and stamped completed TARs to the state.

 In-app notifications
 Implement elegant notifications to alert users of key activities in processing.

 Activity Log
 Users will have a holistic view of the TAR's history.

 Concurrent Review
 Contractors who perform concurrent review will be able to enter the results of their reviews in Chorus for OC to easily access.

title: PRD - SUD - Revised 2024
content:
Chorus team 
 PM: Thai

 Project Manager: Mike

 Design: Todd

 SAs: TBD

 QA: TBD

 Timeline 
 UAT by end of Q2 2024

 Roadmap 
 TBD

 Jira epics 
 TBD

 Figma file 
 TBD

 Before we begin: a note on terminology
 Term 
 Definition 

 Drug Medi-Cal Organized Delivery System (DMC-ODS) 
 The Drug Medi-Cal Organized Delivery System (DMC-ODS) provides a continuum of care modeled after the American Society of Addiction Medicine (ASAM) Criteria for substance use disorder (SUD) treatment services, enables more local control and accountability, provides greater administrative oversight, creates utilization controls to improve care and efficient use of resources, implements evidenced based practices in SUD treatment, and coordinates with other systems of care.
 This approach provides Medi-Cal members with access to the care and system interaction needed in order to achieve sustainable recovery.
 Background 
 In 2015, California's DMC-ODS program was the nation's first SUD treatment demonstration project approved by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) under a Medicaid Section 1115 authority. A UCLA evaluation conducted on DMC-ODS found that the pilot program yielded significant improvements in quality of care within counties that opted into the program, when compared with Drug Medi-Cal (DMC) only counties. UCLA found that participating in DMC-ODS led to an increase in access to treatment by 7 percent, as well as enhanced care coordination and integration with physical health services for DMC-ODS counties. Furthermore, 80 percent of DMC-ODS counties have implemented a Beneficiary Access Line connecting individuals to treatment or referrals, compared to 44 percent of DMC counties. Overall, DMC-ODS services have high patient satisfaction, with 93 percent reporting positive ratings of their treatment. 
 In December 2021, DHCS received approval from CMS to reauthorize DMC-ODS, shifting the managed care authority to the consolidated CalAIM 1915(b) waiver and using the Medicaid State Plan to authorize the majority of DMC-ODS benefits. Authority to provide reimbursable Medi-Cal services for DMC-ODS members residing in institutions for mental disease (IMDs) remains in the 1115 demonstration through December 31, 2026. To learn more about DMC-ODS program and updates pursuant to CalAIM, please see BHIN 23-001 .
 Additional resources for DMC-ODS counties, including free assessment tools, can be found on the County Resources page 
 Source: https://www.dhcs.ca.gov/provgovpart/Pages/Drug-Medi-Cal-Organized-Delivery-System.aspx 

 American Society of Addiction Medicine (ASAM) 
 Established in 1954, ASAM is a distinguished medical society that encompasses more than 7,500 physicians, clinicians, and related professionals who specialize in addiction medicine. DMC-ODS is modeled after ASAM Criteria for SUD services
 The ASAM Criteria Assessment Interview Guide from DHCS 

 Bed Board (aka Bed Availability Board) 
 Shows availability at different programs, so that referrers (e.g., Police, CAT Team, etc.) know if they can refer a client to a program

 Referral 
 When a client is given a recommendation in writing to a specific service provider for care and treatment

 Linkage 
 Client participates at least once in the treatment to which they were referred. Since CRPs are residential stays, "Linkage" has been defined as when the client is admitted to the service

 Closed Loop Referral 
 Referring and receiving providers are able to track the status of a referral and confirm client status between both providers

 Authorization for Residential Treatment (ART) 
 BHS staff responsible for authorizing residential treatment. ART team staff are healthcare professionals with appropriate clinical expertise in treating the beneficiary's/client's condition or disease

 Authorization 
 The approval process for DMC-ODS services prior to the submission of a DMC-ODS claim

 Withdrawal Management

 Residential Treatment

 Recovery Residence

 Outpatient Clinic

 Objective
 Allow programs involved in the current SUD care pathway (ART, Withdrawal management, residential treatment centers, and recovery residences) the ability to digitally receive/record referrals from current sources, review the 
 Create a system that allows SUD programs to receive, manage, and send referrals to other OC programs (both county contracted and county operated). This includes the ability to: 
 Receive and manage incoming referrals

 Send and track outgoing referrals

 View bed availability across SUD programs in OC

 Broader Context
 Personas
 SUD Supervisor (Maria) 
 Goals: Maria wants to be able to care for her client and quickly view and manage all the referrals

 Clinician at Phoenix House (Leon) 
 Goals: Leon wants to be able to care for his client and help clients find ongoing care after their stay at Phoenix House

 Client at Phoenix House 
 Goals: Richard wants to work on his mental health by staying at Phoenix House

 Permissions
 Functional Workflow - Future state
 For most up to date current and future state functional workflows please see figma: https://www.figma.com/file/jiB7XsMs5F0KfZUHFNT4x9/CRP-Workflow?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=9LGRpyVue4FJitc1-1 
 Critical User Journeys & Requirements
 See Q4 Product Plan for high-level requirements
 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_gXk4ybpvtzTAQ8TLvD9MuQJhgkOXULGm_-SKvkQyF8/edit 
 Dependencies & Questions
 Scope 
 I believe that we're building a Bed Board + R&L system (similar to CRP & CSU) for 46 locations within four program types. Is this accurate?
 This also includes ATD + ASAM

 Are we also building a patient portal for clients to self-manage their own ATDs?

 Workflow 
 When in the workflow is the ATD signed?

 When in the workflow is the ASAM conducted? 

 Client List & Permissions 
 Can we have one client list across all SUD programs?

 Can we have one client list across all MHRS Programs & SUD Programs?
 Which programs (both county operated and county contracted) from MHRS are allowed to see SUD clients? Which programs from MHRS are allowed to see SUD history?

 How much information should SUD programs be able to see from other SUD Programs and from MHRS programs?

 What is a program receives a referral for a client that they do not have access do, should they create a new client?

 How are we going to manage duplicate clients?

 Are there any special requirements for Youth permissions

 Referrals 
 Do programs send referrals to all locations within the program groups (e.g., all 11 locations that provide residential treatment) or do they select a specific location? Or should they have the option to do both?

 Are these programs restricted to receiving referrals from specific programs?

 Are these programs restricted to sending referrals to specific programs?

 Users 
 Will these programs use SSO?

 R&L Data Architecture
 Please click here to view data architecture needs: R&L Data Architecture . This includes: 
 Client and referral data
 OC Links, CAT, O&E, CRP, CSU all share the same client list but OC Warmline and PEI do not

 Resource data

 Statuses

 Success metrics
 Goal 
 Metric 

 Capture key data points in the R&L workflow that is required for state reporting
 From the time that the first referral was sent for a client:
 How long does it take for a referral to be accepted?

 How long does it take for a referral to be linked? 

 Reduce the burden of phone calls and data entry by:
 Displaying bed availability

 Sending referrals from one program to another

 Staff satisfaction 

 80% faster than traditional referral processes
 Provide bed availability over the phone or through email

 Review a referral

 Send a referral

 Follow up on a referral

 Track the percentage of successful linkages to care over time

 Onboard additional programs to Chorus to facilitate easy referrals
 8 additional programs on Chorus by EOY

 Referral response rate
 50% of automated referrals responded to within 30 minutes

 Competitors
 Bamboo Health 
 Product: Open Beds https://bamboohealth.com/solutions/openbeds/ 
 Case Study: https://bamboohealth.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/Blinded-Case-Study_OpenBeds.pdf 

 Out of Scope
 External data dashboard that consolidates various reporting tools

 Files
